PARA.TAB: Mr SPEAKER (Hon. Stephen Martin) took the chair at 12.30 p.m., and read prayers.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Nehl Mr G.B.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That this House expresses concern over the future of Australian forest families, particularly in New South Wales, because of the uncertainty facing the forest industry.

SPEECH.PARA: Mr Speaker, that uncertainty is monumental. The families of forest and timber workers are at great risk. The reason they are at risk is because of the policies of the present federal government. I say with respect to my friend the member for Eden-Monaro (Mr Snow) that with the exception of one or two enlightened people in that government they are going out of their way to destroy the forest industry and they are being aided by the Carr government in New South Wales.

PARA.TAB: I want to make some reference to a publication which was launched last Thursday, Australian Plantations: Industry Employment Environment. I will also refer to the draft forestry reform structural adjustment package from the New South Wales government, dated 2 August 1995, issued by the Department of Land and Water Conservation and written by John Halket, the Deputy Director of Forests. I start by referring to one significant paragraph in that document:

SPEECH.PARA: The rescheduling strategy approved by Cabinet for logging in native hardwood forests provides for the 1995 quota quality sawlog supply to be sourced predominantly from regrowth forest over the next twelve months and the notification of a 30% sawlog supply reduction to be effective from July 1996. It is possible that the allocation of quota quality sawlogs to industry could be reduced by up to 50% by 1998.

I suggest, despite that qualification of `could be'that in reality there is going to be a reduction of 50 per cent. The reality is—probably most honourable members who do not come from a forest area will not understand this—that if we are going to stop logging sawlogs now and go into regrowth, that regrowth will be cut too early, it is not going to be satisfactory, because it takes time to grow forests. It seems that some people in this government, in the Carr Labor government in New South Wales and in the fanatical Greenies do not have a clue that it takes time to grow trees. If you start harvesting regrowth forests which will not be fully grown to the point where they could be harvested for another 10 years, it will destroy the forest industry as a whole.

PARA.TAB: Having said that, the thrust of this motion relates to forest families, the families of timber workers. I want to make a fairly detailed statement of comments by a bloke called Bill Gilbert from the Bostabrick mill, out from Dorrigo in my electorate. The problem, as he and all the other forestry workers see it, is total uncertainty for forest families, with absolutely no resource security. I will make mention of that plantation report. You can put in all the plantations under the sun but unless there is resource security, unless there is a guarantee of harvesting those plantations, it is a wasted effort. What is likely to happen is that you put in the plantations, the trees grow and, all of a sudden, some unknown frog appears, then you have got a ban put on and you cannot go ahead and harvest them.

Nobody in their right mind is going to invest millions of dollars—and that is what it is all about—putting in new plantations which take 20 or 30 years to grow, with the upshot being that they cannot cut down a single tree because a koala has been seen in there. If we are serious about having an ongoing and continuous forest industry, we have to take action. First and foremost, we have to provide resource security and a guarantee of harvesting. That word `security' means a great deal to the men and women involved in the timber industry.

I turn back to the Bostabrick mill. After September this year—and Friday is 1 September—the mill does not know where it will be. It does not know where it will get a single log after September. The Carr government had stated that it would guarantee quotas until 30 June next year, but this is not happening. As we have already seen from that draft document published on 2 August, they are going to source them from regrowth. The quality of the bush that they are allowed into at the moment is very poor. Mr Carr is going back on his election promises to the forest industry, just as the federal government has done. The belief not only at Bostabrick but in many other small timber milling communities right around Australia—I speak specifically of the north coast of New South Wales—is that before too long their mills will close, they will be out of jobs and their families will have nothing to do.

Many of these mills are in quite remote areas. The difficulty will be in finding some other form of employment for the employees. As Bill Gilbert and others have said, it means going to work every day not knowing whether they will have a job or not. The stresses and strains on the family are very significant—they are not sleeping. If we are really fair dinkum, we have to look at the possibility of paying some form of compensation for the stress this is causing to forest families. In the Gilberts's case, they have been married for 26 years and they are under great stress because of the financial problems they face with trying to make ends meet, not only now but also into the future when the jobs are gone. Bill is 51 years of age. He still has a mortgage and five children, with three still to be educated. He is the third generation that has been working in the timber industry in northern New South Wales. His grandfather was a forester in the area back in the 1930s.

The situation with the locking up of the forest is such that right now the electricity commission wants cross-arms for telephone poles that have to be made from quality tallowwood but those logs are not allowed to be harvested anymore so they cannot be supplied. Bill Gilbert said that he has never seen a greater muck-up of the forest industry as that which we have at the present time. He believes—and I think he is right—that no-one has told the side of the forest industry. Nobody has gone out and spoken for the forest industry people, the timber workers. The government is bowing to very loud, vociferous green groups.The media coverage is totally directed to the aims and the issues of the environmentalists. Education in schools is all about the preservation and conservation of the environment. Great. We need to conserve our environment; we need to look after our resources, but people have to remember that timber is a renewable resource. Timber is the most environmentally friendly resource we have. It is not like mining for iron, copper or coal; it regrows. Forestry is definitely a renewable resource.

I want to provide some facts about forestry. Australia's native forests are not—I emphasise `not'—under threat from the timber industry. Old growth forests are not—I repeat `not'—being cut down for woodchips. The facts are that Australia has 43,200,000 hectares of forest. Of that 43 million hectares, only 7.1 have been set aside to meet Australia's current and future timber needs on a sustainable basis—and I emphasise `sustainable'. Only one per cent of that area is logged annually. Right now, 65 per cent of Australia's forests have been set aside and reserved. Another 10 per cent is only limited access for firewood and things like that, which leaves 25 per cent available. Seventy-five per cent is not available and of that 25 per cent only one per cent is logged each year on a sustainable basis.

The timber industry's efforts are directed towards maintaining continuity in the supply of sawlogs but it does not want to go out of business. It is managing the forest areas sensibly and will continue to do so. It wants to maintain continuity in the supply of sawlogs. It wants to produce the maximum of timber from each log. It wants to add value to that timber and minimise waste.

Let's make it very clear: woodchipping enables the industry to dramatically cut waste by providing an economic outlet for offcuts, material which was once burned but is now used and not wasted. The timber industry does not cut down old growth trees for woodchips, and no roundwood which could be sawn for timber becomes woodchips.

I want to conclude by quoting from someone I know very well, a woman called Paula Lindsay. She used to work in a sawmill at Briggsvale. Unfortunately, it burnt down and many people lost their jobs. She was in charge of 11 people at Briggsvale, which is now relocating to Tasmania—(Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Speaker, I second the motion. Whereas my rhetoric will be a bit different and more optimistic than that of the member for Cowper (Mr Nehl), I acknowledge his concern and agree with him that there is still far too much uncertainty for timber families in the timber areas in his electorate and mine in New South Wales particularly, as well as in other areas of the country. For instance, we have a member from Tasmania in the House and there is still uncertainty there.

PARA.TAB: A lot of the uncertainty in New South Wales is due to the fact that we have had a change of government. The items listed under the national forest strategy and the national forest policy statement have to be rediscussed with the new New South Wales government. I can express some optimism because I have been meeting with Minister Yeadon, the New South Wales minister in charge of forests, and Minister Allan, the New South Wales minister in charge of the environment, and I now know that they sincerely want to discuss with the industry, with unions and with local communities the future of the timber industry.

There are certainly some challenges but some of them, including some from the environment movement, are not logical. Some of the noises coming from the environment movement call for a stop to woodchipping, thinking that will stop the problems in the forest, but all the time they are targeting particular areas that are basically sawlog driven.

This happened last year when the federal government was put in the position—which, I hope, never happens again—of having to consider individual coupes and deciding which could be logged and which could not. Invariably, those coupes which were most likely to be set aside from logging were mainly sawlog coupes. The coupes that were not so strongly opposed by the environment movement were more likely to be woodchip coupes. But some of the members of the environment movement will not admit this because it suits their position.

I know that the environment movement has been hard-pressed for membership and funds and it has taken this strategy because it knows it can gain a lot of sympathy from the community by opposing woodchipping. But, as the member for Cowper said, woodchipping is part of an integrated logging system and we should be talking about adding value to our forests by diverting less timber towards woodchipping and more to the sawlog industry.

The national forest policy aims to persuade people in the industry to add value. There have been some fruitful discussions and there will be even more. But there is no doubt that there is uncertainty in the industry.

Some weeks ago I made an announcement about a study which I know you have had a bit to do with, Mr Speaker: the Australian National University internship program. You, the President of the Senate and members of parliament have cooperated in giving students some very useful opportunities to develop their own academic records as well as providing information to members of parliament, information that we need.

Gerry Cirulli was assigned to me to study the effect on families of changes and uncertainty in the timber industry. He did a comprehensive survey. Even though the education department—under a previous government—refused to allow him to talk to teachers or to go into schools, he was able to establish, by talking to families and groups of people who were prepared to discuss with him the issues in the timber industry, the effect on families of the uncertainty in the timber industry. While there was not strong evidence of family breakdown among those families, there was strong evidence that people were very apprehensive and uncertain; and that uncertainty was having an effect on family life, school work and the economic viability of local communities. He quite clearly established, in what I felt was a very truthful and honest study—

TALK.START.PARA: —An excellent study.

—Thank you. I am pleased that the opposition acknowledges the study. It was an excellent, dispassionate study which made it clear that there was still great uncertainty in our timber industry families. We are in the process of doing a couple of things. One is to ensure that we have a viable industry and the other is to ensure there is adequate compensation for people who are hurt through restructuring. That compensation has worked to some extent in that there have been people who have been able to receive social security benefits if they have been hurt. But there have also been people who have not been able to receive compensation.

PARA.TAB: I appreciate the cooperation I have had from the minister's office in trying to make sure that these people have access. I am thinking particularly of people who are contractors. An example might be a self-employed husband and wife team owning a trucker's business. They have not been able to access compensation because they have formed a company. It is quite clear that these people should be able to be compensated. If they want to relocate to another area, as some do, they should receive compensation to assist them in relocating.

Through government policy we are changing the picture in our forest areas. It is not going to be totally pessimistic. I believe that the fiasco of last year in the approval for woodchip export licensing will be replaced by a cooperation between state and federal departments—at least two state departments and at least three federal departments—to ensure that a scoping study is performed which provides our regions throughout Australia with assessments. That means they will know where they stand and there can be early approval of woodchip export licences, based on the current policies of state and federal governments. They will know where they stand and there will be early approval of woodchip export licensing based on the current policies of state and federal governments.

I am pleased that the industry has shown a cooperative attitude. It has recognised that a government which many in the industry did not want elected has been elected in New South Wales and it is prepared to cooperate with that government. It has made the sounds and approaches to government which say, `Yes, we are prepared to cooperate with you to the benefit, we hope, of our industry, taking into account the important environmental concerns.' The state government has responded. State ministers have been prepared to say to the industry, `Yes, we want a viable industry. We are prepared to work with you to get that. Let us get stuck into it.'

At the moment, there is uncertainty about whether or not that will happen, but at least the state governments are saying, `Yes, we're prepared to cooperate and to take into account the federal government's requirement to maintain 15 per cent of the original value that existed in our forests prior to 1788.' That is quite a legitimate request, as long as the studies enable a proper assessment of the coupes to ensure that the assessments are made on a fair basis right throughout Australia.

There is another cause of the uncertainty, but it does not come from government. I refer to the industrial sabotage that has occurred throughout some of the regions of Australia. This industrial sabotage was drawn to the attention of the House when the member for Cowper and I were involved in a media conference which showed that the sabotaging of equipment has hurt families in that it has stopped people from working in the industry.

More recently, I heard of a fencepost cutter near Shallow Crossing in Batemans Bay—he uses very few logs in his work—whose equipment was also sabotaged. That is totally illogical. If people are working in an area with the permission of the government, then they should be allowed to continue to work in that area. Our main aim, which will give certainty to families, is to make sure that we add value to our industry. The cooperation that now exists between the industry and the state and federal governments must yield us that result. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Miles Mr C.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to support this motion, which states:

PARA.TAB: That this House expresses concern over the future of Australian forest families, particularly in New South Wales, because of the uncertainty facing the forest industry.

SPEECH.PARA: I rise to express not only my concern but also my disgust at the uncertainty facing the second largest manufacturing industry in this country which employs so many people in Australia. Over 70,000 people are employed in the manufacturing industry. In my home state of Tasmania, one in seven people are employed in work associated with forest industries. In other words, over 22,000 Tasmanians are employed in this industry.

PARA.TAB: The reason I rise to speak in this debate today is that I am so annoyed about and frustrated by the position of the federal government. Over the past 10 or 12 years, they have procrastinated, they have backed and filled, and they have done nothing about this huge industry in Australia. At the moment, we have a huge overseas debt and an import deficit because of this particular industry. Considering the fact that Australia is such a huge area with such a small population, we could be using those large areas for forest plantation areas and regrowth forest areas and exporting timber products to the world. Instead, this country imports over $1.5 billion worth of timber products. That is just incredible.

The federal government has done nothing about this situation. Over the 12 years or so that the Labor Party has been in government, it has left the forest industry people, their families, their children and their grandparents to dangle at the end of a rope without doing hardly a thing about it.

Last week a statement was released which indicates that we ought to be going into plantation forests. That is part of the answer. I have always advocated that plantations have a role to play, but the frustrating thing for so many timber industry people is that over the past 12 years this government has never backed them. It has never done anything about the problem. It has always given in to the radical environmental movement. This is one of the problems in political debate in this country which could be solved if the government would just look at the scientific facts.

The regrowth forest industry is a beautiful industry because you can replant the resource that you take away. In the process, you are helping the greenhouse effect. Young trees pump out huge amounts of oxygen and they suck in so much carbon dioxide. The old growth forests hardly do any of that; they are neutral.

Here is a great opportunity for our country, but when it comes to the forest industry the federal government always panders to what is politically important. In this country most people are very aware of the Wesley Vale pulp mill debate. It was an opportunity for downstream processing, doing away with a 50-year-old pulp mill, putting in new technology with a much cleaner output, downstream processing almost two million tonnes of woodchips out of Tasmania, putting it into pulp, and then making it into fine writing paper.

What did this federal government do? It said, `No. We will not build that.' Why? Because the green movement in Tasmania convinced then Senator Richardson to oppose the building of that pulp mill. So today we have children in our schools being told that it is a terrible disaster that we are exporting all these woodchips. Why are we exporting woodchips? Because the federal government said that you cannot build a pulp mill to make pulp. Therefore you cannot have enough pulp in Australia to make fine writing paper. So at the end of the day we have thousands of families out there in Australia who do not know where this country is going in regard to the second largest manufacturing industry in this country. That is an absolute disgrace.

At the beginning of this year the national forest policy moved on. The national forest policy statement by the Federal Labor Party was actually brought out in 1992. Nothing was done with it for two to three years. Then they moved on it, a year away from the next federal election—better try to bed down the CFMEU union in Australia. `We have to keep them on side so that we get money pouring into the coffers for the next campaign. We have to decide which coupes are to be logged and which are not.' The government came in here and said, `The state governments have not given us enough information on which coupes should be logged and which should not.'

The south-east forests were investigated by the state government. New South Wales, in particular, sticks in my mind. They had a pile which was that high in documentation of scientific data on the flora and the fauna, the millipedes, the crustaceans and all the rest that lived in the forest, quite apart from the big marsupials. The federal government came in here and claimed that it had to excise 513 coupes. It came in with 14 pages for the whole of Australia justifying these coupes. That is the level of investigation, of superficiality, that this government has given to the forest industry.

In the meantime you have men out there saying, `I am in this industry. I need to buy a new rig, $250,000 or $300,000. I need a new scooter, $200,000 again—half a million dollars worth of investment. Will I put the money into it or not? The federal Labor Party sits on its hands, when for 12 years it has had a great opportunity to bed down an important industry in this country, downstream process it and get our plantations going. If it had started a plantation program 12 years ago it would be halfway down the track by now with those plantations. Eucalyptus nitans or Eucalyptus globulus can be grown in this country ready for pulp milling in about 20 years. Of course, that does not solve the timber or the veneer side of it. We may be able to grow those trees and peel them in a certain way so that we can produce veneer.

The real problem for Australian families is that they do not know where they are going in the timber industry. Just talk to the people who were out here in February from Orbost, a town in Victoria totally dependent on the timber industry. They do not know what their future is. The shopkeepers do not know. The post office mistress does not know. Why? Because the government has not sat down, looked at the scientific evidence and then set about a specific program to do something about it for this country of ours.

We now have a national forest strategy which is going to drag on while we get our regional agreements in place. They should have been in place by now. I tell the Australian people listening to this debate that that policy was brought down in 1992. We have had one federal election since then and there will be another federal election before a TAP is done effectively for Australian families.

The people out there who fell trees are ordinary guys. They are the battlers of Australia. They earn good money. They work hard. It is a tough job if you have been out on the end of a chainsaw for 10 or 12 hours. They are the heart and soul of many towns in Australia. They deserve certainty and security, particularly in an industry which can be made to work for the benefit of Australia.
Labor Party members come in here and say that they support the forest industry, but when it comes to voting they do not. For example, a motion was moved in this House in February which said:
That this House, recognising the damage to regional economies and jobs, reaffirms its commitment to the national forest policy statement—

SPEECH.PARA: the government's statement—
and requests the government to bring about its immediate implementation.

What do we find? If we go to the record of Hansard, we find that all the Labor members voted against it. They come in here and say, `We fight in Canberra for you people. We go there and fight for you.' But when it comes to voting they do not fight; they vote against the workers. It is really a tragedy that we are having this debate because the government could have done something about providing security and certainty for Australian forest families. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Smith Mrs Silvia

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise today to speak about my concern for Australian forest families, particularly those in Tasmania and in the electorate of Bass, which I represent. I have been, since my election, confronted with problems in my electorate with regard to forest industries. My primary concern at all times has been the jobs of individuals and the welfare of the families involved in local forest industries.

PARA.TAB: I stress, as I have always stressed, that my view is a balanced view. I am concerned for the jobs and I am concerned for the industry, but I am also concerned for an appropriate level of environmental protection. The hard line Greens in Tasmania refuse to recognise my balanced approach. They refuse to recognise it because they have moved from being a movement of environmental concern with a genuine agenda to being a cynical, political movement concerned only with power and the election of their own candidates.

For instance, I am totally opposed to the road through the so-called Tarkine wilderness, which the state Liberal government is constructing. It is an absolute waste of money and truly a road to nowhere. Regardless of my opposition to the project, the Greens still protest outside my office and write untruths about me in their journals. Why? It is because I hold Labor's most marginal seat and they are trying to hold me and the federal Labor Party to ransom.

I truly do lament the passing of the Greens as a political watchdog. They are now probably the most cynical political party in Australia. They are no longer concerned with the facts and want nothing to get in the way of their lust for power. One thing I can say is that they also treat their voters with contempt over preferences at their peril. The average Green voter is very astute, as are all voters, and they will not give preferences to the coalition while Labor's track record on the environment is as good as it is.

I preface my speech on my concern for Australia's forest families with this because it is important. Families and jobs are more important than political agendas. They are more important than seats and they are more important than governments. When you boil it all down, families and jobs are what governments are all about.

Recently in my electorate 65 forest families have been put out of work, at least for the short term, due to the lack of a woodchip export licence. Regardless of the merits of that application or the details of how the applicant had conducted himself in the past, 65 families were reliant on this business for their livelihoods.
Let me quote from an article in the Launceston Examiner, written by one of its best journalists, Nick Clark, on 10 August 1995:

SPEECH.PARA: Lilydale shop proprietor, Rob Patterson says that his business will suffer a 35-40 per cent drop in turnover because of the federal government's refusal to grant Barry Arnold a woodchip licence.
He had ceased to employ the four or five people he normally did.
That is Rob Patterson, the shop owner. The article continues:
"About 35 per cent of my turnover is to Barry Arnold and his men in materials for their trucks," he said.
There will be a further effect because no-one is spending anything at the weekend for fence repairs or landscaping.
He said that Lilydale had been severely affected by uncertainty since April, the previous time that Mr Arnold had laid off his men.
Mr Patterson said the situation would put pressure on the business, Bardenhagens Hardware which he had operated for 14 months since leaving the Tasmania fire service.
"Other businesses in town such as supermarkets or service stations may not be as severely affected because their goods are essential but hardware items are discretionary spending," he said.
This is an example of how important the forest industry is to the electorate of Bass, which I represent.

PARA.TAB: Not only does the industry affect the individuals which it directly employs but it affects their families, their communities and the services and businesses which exist in these communities. Lilydale is just an example of the many small communities in northern Tasmania and the nation which are heavily reliant on the forest industry. I will never resile from doing all that I can to keep those people employed and their families safe.

The issue of forestry as an industry is incredibly complex and, naturally, highly emotive. Many of the people directly involved in the debate are incredibly polarised in their views on the forest industry either one way or the other. Not only is it difficult but it is almost impossible to bring the parties to the point of meaningful consultative achievement. Unfortunately, due to this polarity it seems constantly necessary for the federal government to arbitrate and rule on disputes.

None of us should think that there is a quick fix to the battle in our forests and none of us should lay all the blame on the other side of the debate. The fact remains that there are problems with forest practices, there are problems with chipping sawlogs and there are problems with a lack of investment in downstream processing—something I think we would all agree with.

Similarly, on the other side of the debate there are problems with misinformation and a rolling agenda which will never be satiated while the Greens remain a cynical political entity obsessed by gaining parliamentary power. However difficult it may be, we have to resolve these problems and we have to resolve them now. Those workers and their families involved in the forest industry must be able to be certain of their future and everyone must be able to be certain of their environmental future.

TALK.START.PARA: —Once again we are participating in a debate in this chamber that is emanating from the woes of a particular section of the community in Australia—average working families in timber areas. It is incumbent on this House to pass this motion—and seriously do it. The member for Braddon (Mr Miles) pointed out that earlier this year a similar motion was moved in which we tried to reaffirm this parliament's commitment to the government's own national forest policy statement. All the government members voted against their own statement—exactly what they are trying to hang their hat on for the future strategy of the Australian forest industry. It is just ridiculous!

PARA.TAB: What is it all in the name of? It is in the name of pandering to small fringe groups, such as the Greens, to maintain power in this parliament. That is what it is all about. At the last election and the election before that the government pandered to the Greens. It maintained the Green vote by locking up this forest and that forest and absolutely procrastinating with the forest industry.

As the member for Cowper (Mr Nehl) pointed out, 65 per cent of Australian forests are locked up for conservation. They are not being properly managed either. The Australian National Parks and Wildlife Service in New South Wales had a fire in the Werrikimbe National Park last year. Two weeks after being notified by the Forestry Commission that that fire existed, the service decided to do something about it and, in turn, lost thousands of hectares of old-growth forests—exactly what we are all about trying to protect in this place. It is just ridiculous.

We heard one of the previous speakers—I think it was the member for Eden-Monaro (Mr Snow)—talk about what the new Labor government in New South Wales is going to do for the forestry industry. We know what they are going to do for the forestry industry, but it will not happen, cynically, until after the next federal election. You wait and see. They will not make a move on New South Wales forests until after the next federal election.

In the draft forestry reform structural adjustment package, what sort of language do they use? They say things like `compensation to owner drivers of logging trucks and operators of logging equipment', `measures to assist employers affected by the immediate impact of mill closures and downsizing', `redundancy', `relocation', `training assistance' and `redeployment'. It is the talk of making a complete industry redundant, an industry that should be moving forward in this nation and doing something about that atrocious balance of payments deficit and the current account deficit that, strangely enough, in recent times the people of Australia have started to become more aware of and understand. National forest industries can make an enormous amount of difference if the government got off its backside, stopped sitting on its hands and did something about the national forest policy statement, which it implemented in 1992.

The Centre for International Economics has done a study on forest industries in Australia. Some very compelling statistics have come out of that study. The government should address the problems this industry is facing. In 1994, we produced $6 billion worth of product. In the year 2000, it will be $7.3 billion. In the year 2030, it will be $10.3 billion. The trade deficit in forest products will rise from the current $1.8 billion to $5.6 billion in 2030. That is if the government just leaves things as they are.

Just watch the Carr government in New South Wales try to close this industry down. It has the possibility of addressing our current account deficit and our balance of payments deficit. With the right opportunities, including more hardwood plantations, environmentally friendly pulp mills and other value adding, Australia's current $1.8 billion a year forest products deficit could be turned into a $413 million surplus within five years and a $6.5 billion annual surplus in the year 2030. These figures are from the Centre for International Economics; they are not our figures.

Employment in forest industries could grow from the present level of 70,000 to 211,000—all being sustainable in an industry that has a renewable resource. If a lot of the people in this place went out and spoke to the people operating in the forests and the bush in New South Wales, Victoria and Tasmania, they would realise that the management practices that are being implemented today ensure that this is an industry that has a renewable resource. They are managing our forests on a very sensible basis and we can achieve those sorts of figures in the future. We can employ those sorts of people in the future in the forest industries in Australia if we stop the procrastination that is taking place at the moment. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —I can assure the member for Lyne (Mr Vaile) that I do go out and talk with those in the forest industry. As he knows, the forest industry is significant in my electorate. What I find interesting about today's debate is that speakers have so far tended to indicate that the restructuring of Australia's timber industry is exposing a group of people in Australia to restructuring for the very first time. Of course, that is not so. We have seen a number of industries—the steel industry, the coal industry—undergo restructuring. The timber industry is another one.

PARA.TAB: If speakers opposite are honest, they will know that restructuring in the timber industry has been going on for decades. No longer is it the labour intensive industry that it once was. Mechanisation has replaced thousands of jobs in our timber industry. But it is important that the timber industry remain. I am fully supportive of that. While I may differ on the principles, I am very supportive that communities that currently support our timber industry must remain. They are an integral part of the fabric of our society. I have no doubt that they will be there.

Some of the things that must happen involve not so much government policy but industry policy. It is for industry to attack this with a will to succeed. So far, I have not seen that. What I see coming from industry is pressure to be allowed to continue to develop the industry as it will.

I fully support what the honourable member for Cowper (Mr Nehl) has said. There is good management practice by those involved with state forests. I talk with our foresters. I visit the forests. I see that what they are doing is responsible. But the point cannot be lost that currently 53 per cent of our hardwood product is exported from this country as woodchips. It requires minimal jobs to get it to that state. Once it leaves our shores, it does not create a single job. My argument is this: industry has to say that 53 per cent of woodchips is too much and that we can get more value out of that product. We can do that in different ways.

I know that I have quoted these figures before. A cubic metre of sawn hardwood scantling in Australia is today valued at about $300. Simply kiln drying that product and converting it into a seasoned kiln dried product makes it automatically worth $900. Not only have you trebled its value by doing so; you have also created jobs in the process.

A young craftsman lives in my electorate. He is currently selling hardwood furniture to Japan. For one table using a single slab of Australian hardwood, he can get $10,000. He is capable of taking a fraction of a cubic metre of timber and, by skilled craftsmanship, create jobs and value.

TALK.START.PARA: —It beats the hell out of woodchips.
—That is right. That message has to get through to our hardwood industry. Sustainability has to be the operative word.

PARA.TAB: I am certainly looking forward to the forest policy statement that is now due to come down in October. I believe that it has been put forward because consultation has taken place. From talking to Boral, for example, which is the major player in the timber industry in New South Wales, I understand that so far it is very happy with the progress that has been made.

While I fully support the sustainability of rural towns that are dependent on the timber industry, I believe it is important that the direction of our industry has to be value add, value add and value add. We should create jobs in those country towns by taking pride in the product of our forests. But there is no doubt that exporting 53 per cent of our hardwood product as woodchips devalues not only our forests but also the people who have the ability to turn it into a far better product by kiln drying, dressing, laminating and manufacturing furniture. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—First, I want to thank all members from both sides of the House who have participated in this debate. It has been valuable. A lot of views have been put. I do not entirely agree with everything that has been said. The essential thing that has come out of this is that from both sides of this House there is a great deal of goodwill for the forest families of Australia.

PARA.TAB: Again, in the time that is available to me, I want to make the point, as contained in the motion, that this House is concerned about the future of Australian forest families because of the uncertainty facing the forest industry. What the member for Paterson (Mr Horne) has said in many cases is absolutely true—we do have a sustainable forest industry but we are not going to be allowed to use it.

I make the point again that the unemployment that has been caused already—and that will gallop, unfortunately, when the New South Wales government brings in its forestry reform structural adjustment package—should not happen. We have a sustainable industry. We have forest workers, forest families, who are making a tremendous contribution to Australia and they should be permitted to get on with the job.

But regrettably—and I say this without rancour—the present Labor government, with the exception of some of its members, federally is working against the forest industries, as is the Carr government in New South Wales. The point must be made that it is one thing to talk about sustainability, and we all agree with the need for sustainable management of the forest but—and I come back to where I started—resource security is absolutely essential. There must be some certainty, some guarantee of harvesting. Whether it be old-growth forest, regrowth hardwood forest, plantation forests or the monoculture of pine, unless there is that certainty it will not happen. It is pie in the sky. It is all uncertainty.

Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER (Mr Jenkins)—Order! The time allotted for this debate has expired. The debate is adjourned and the resumption of the debate will be made an order of the day for the next sitting Monday.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Filing Mr P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That this House:
(1)notes that:
(a)11 May 1995 was the fifth anniversary of the issuance of the Manifesto of the Non-Violent Movement for Human Rights in Vietnam;

(b)the Manifesto, which calls upon Hanoi to respect basic human rights, accept a multiparty system and restore the rights of the Vietnamese people to choose their own form of government through free and fair elections, reflects the will and aspirations of the people of Vietnam;

(c)the author of the Manifesto, Dr Nguyen Dan Que, and thousands of innocent Vietnamese, including religious leaders, are imprisoned by the Socialist Republic of Vietnam because of their non-violent struggle for freedom and human rights; and
(d)the leaders of the Socialist Republic of Vietnam are seeking to expand diplomatic and trade relations with the rest of the world;

(2)calls on Hanoi to (a) release immediately and unconditionally all political prisoners, including Dr Nguyen Dan Que, with full restoration of their civil and human rights, (b) guarantee equal protection under the law to all Vietnamese, regardless of religious belief, political philosophy or previous associations, (c) restore all basic human rights such as freedom of speech, religion, movement and association, (d) abolish the single party system and permit the functioning of all political organisations without intimidation or harassment and (e) announce a framework and timetable for free and fair elections under the sponsorship of the UN that will allow the Vietnamese people to choose their own form of government; and

(3)calls upon the Australian Government to designate 11 May 1996 as Vietnam Human Rights Day in support of efforts by the Non-Violent Movement for Human Rights in Vietnam to achieve freedom and human rights for the people of Vietnam.

The socialist government of Vietnam continues to indulge in human rights abuses against its own people. Other countries share Vietnam's appalling record on human rights; some may actually be worse. But Vietnam is singular in our region in that the government in Hanoi is aggressively courting the world to accept it back into the arena of international trade and negotiations.

PARA.TAB: It is a fundamental right that people should be able to speak out about the government of their country without being thrown in gaol for inordinate lengths of time, often being forced into hard labour, being beaten or having their food extensively rationed so that they suffer from malnutrition. This is what is happening in the socialist republic of Vietnam. It is the height of hypocrisy for Australia to enter into trade agreements with Hanoi or to actively encourage local businesses to become associated with that country while abuses of human rights—which in Vietnam's case are numerous and of a particularly odious nature—remain.

Before I address the motion before the House directly, I would offer some brief historical background to the situation in Vietnam as it now stands. After the Vietnam war and the forced unification of the country in 1975, the government announced a policy of re-education for persona affiliated with the government and military of South Vietnam. Re-education was also applied to intellectuals, professionals and clerics in the south whose loyalty to the new order was suspect. For some, this experience consisted of a few weeks in classes of communist ideology; for tens of thousands of others it meant imprisonment in hard labour camps under conditions of extraordinary deprivation and hardship. Even today, prison camps in Vietnam are still called re-education centres.

In Vietnam detainees were often tortured. Many were simply executed—a sort of final solution for advocates of democracy who could not be re-educated. Those imprisoned were rarely given any medical care, and thousands perished through disease and malnourishment. International human rights organisations are not convinced that these practices are still not being carried out in Vietnam today.

In 1986 the Sixth Party Congress in Vietnam planted the seed of change. They adopted a policy of renovation heralding the shift to a market economy. The promise of greater political freedom was also made and enshrined in the new 1992 constitution, and laws on prison reform were introduced in 1993. But putting these reforms down on paper in Vietnam has had no obvious effect on the freedom of expression. It seems the Hanoi government is content to take the benefits of economic reform, without giving back anything in the way of relaxed attitudes to democratic expression and freedoms. These changes certainly increased Vietnam's economic activity measurably. However, the world has yet to see the human rights elements of these changes come to fruition.

As my motion notes, 11 May this year was the fifth anniversary of the drawing up of a manifesto by human rights activists in Vietnam. The manifesto of the Non-Violent Movement for Human Rights in Vietnam called on Hanoi to respect basic human rights and move towards a multi-party system of government. It called on the government to restore to the people the right to choose a system of government through free and open elections.
The author of that manifesto, an endocrinologist named Dr Nguyen Dan Que, was promptly arrested by Hanoi in 1991 and sentenced to 20 years in gaol. The publication Human Rights Watch/Asia writes:

SPEECH.PARA: Dr Ngyen Dan Que, an endocrinologist whose public called for political reform and respect for human rights earned him a twenty year prison sentence in 1991, was placed in solitary confinement in August (1994) and is reported to be in poor health.
Another Asia Watch article reports on Dr Que:
He (Que) suffers from a bleeding ulcer for which he receives no medical attention.
Many other prisoners in Vietnam like Tran Vong Quo are treated worse. In Quo's case, Asia Watch reports:

He is gravely ill and has an untreated kidney disorder and has experienced severe chest pains and difficulty in breathing recently, which may be indicative of heart attack. Despite his condition, he is still required to perform heavy labour such as digging ditches and clearing trees at labour camp K1-Z30D, Ham Tan.

As you are aware, Mr Deputy Speaker, a consultative delegation from this parliament visited Vietnam earlier this year during April. The report of that delegation contains a number of important recommendations and observations. In relation to Dr Que, the report stated:

One member of the delegation, Mr Sidoti, met privately . . . with Tam Van, the wife of Dr Ngyen Dan Que. She advised the delegation on Dr Que's present whereabouts and condition. Dr Que is now held at prison Z30A-KA, Xuan Loc, Dong Nai Province.
He is confined to a separate cottage where he is under close guard. Ms Van and four or five other members of his family visit him once a month for approximately twenty minutes.
The report goes on:
During the visit, about three prison guards sit close by and appear to listen in on the conversation.
Dr Que suffers from high blood pressure and has stomach problems . . .
Although the Vietnamese Government recently announced a series of amnesties over the next 12 months there has been no suggestion to Dr Que or his family that he will benefit from this.

This is an outrage. Dr Que is not a well man. His only crime was to suggest that a one-party system did not reflect the aspirations of thousands of Vietnamese who want a democratic voice in their own country. The delegation report goes on to make this important observation:
There is a general belief that the economic reform process is irreversible. Vietnam is aiming to maintain annual growth of nearly 10% and to double present GDP by the year 2000.

Recommendation 7 of the report echoes this motion today. Vietnam is looking to countries like Australia to help achieve its growth targets. Hanoi wants its neighbours to open up our economies to closer ties with Vietnam. We must make it plain that we will not do so until Hanoi demonstrates that it is willing to move towards political changes that will prevent the future persecution of its citizens for political purposes. Recommendation 7 says:

Australia should continue to use political, diplomatic and other channels to encourage improvements in the observance of human rights in Vietnam, including the implementation of international obligations.

But, remember, Dr Que proposed non-violent protest only. Hanoi's response to calls for human rights reform to date have been muted at best. In fact, in response to calls by Amnesty International for the release of political prisoners this month, Associated Press International wrote on August 17—just one week ago:
Vietnam will not accept American human rights demands as a condition for trade and economic relations, a Foreign Ministry Spokeswoman said.
Ho The Lan also said the Vietnamese Government's prosecution of six Buddhist dissidents and nine democracy activists had nothing to do with their political views or religion.

That is pretty hard to believe. It is Orwellian in the extreme the way the Vietnamese government attempts to justify incarcerating its own people on account of their political or religious views. Hanoi continues to claim these imprisonments are a result of breaches of law and have nothing to do with political motivation. Ms Lan continued:
. . . (the trials were) . . . normal trials . . . against those who have violated Vietnamese law, completely not in connection with their political views or religion.
A report by Human Rights Watch/Asia had a different view. Before the US Congress House Committee on International Relations subcommittee on human rights, Dinah Pokempner said:

Although there have been annual releases or amnesties of such prisoners, every year there are new trials of fresh dissidents as well. The legal system remains both institutionally weak and highly politicised, unable to provide a check to these abuses.
A US Department of State report on human rights of February 1995 painted the following picture of the human rights situation in Vietnam today:

The Ministry of the Interior is responsible for internal security, employing a large border defence force and the police to monitor persons suspected of involvement in unauthorised political or religious activities . . . Vietnamese citizens do not have the rights to change their government or to assemble, associate or speak freely.

The report went on to detail that, once arrested, people are often held for indefinite periods without formal charges or without access to legal help. But two Vietnamese were arrested in late 1983 for trying to organise a democracy conference in Ho Chi Minh City. A year later they had not been charged and were still being detained. Authorities arrested Pham Van Quang in 1992 for waving the former Republic of Vietnam flag during the Ho Chi Minh marathon. In 1994 he was tried and convicted of rebellion for this heinous offence and sentenced to 15 years hard labour. There are as many as 1,000 political prisoners in Vietnam. At least four film workers were sentenced to up to 16 months re-education for being involved with the making of a film which Hanoi considered was in violation of the criminal code by spreading information against socialism.

PARA.TAB: The Vietnam government cannot have it both ways. In wanting to open up that country to the rigours of international trade and the benefits that would flow to the Vietnamese, it must also open itself up to the scrutiny of the international community in relation to its appalling record of human rights atrocities and the benefits that will flow from that process. As a first step, Hanoi must free all political prisoners, beginning with Dr Que, with the full restoration of his civil and human rights, Hanoi must guarantee equal protection under the law to all Vietnamese, regardless of their political and religious beliefs and previous associations and Hanoi must abolish the single party system or at least be seen to move in that direction by the international community. Only through moving towards democracy can the application for admittance to the world be properly considered. (Time expired)
Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER (Hon. N.B. Reid)—Is the motion seconded?

TALK.START.PARA: —I second the motion and reserve my right to speak.

—I welcome the opportunity to put on record my views on the issue of human rights in Vietnam. A few weeks ago the honourable member for Reid (Mr Ferguson), who is present today, and I were criticised in the Australian by far right journalist Greg Sheridan, suggesting that we were obsessed with East Timor and that we were very quiet on issues such as Vietnam. So I welcome the opportunity to put my views. I might also add that I have been rung many times by journalists from all different forms of media about my attitude to human rights in East Timor, but not one journalist has ever rung me about Vietnam. Perhaps if they had, they might have got a response.

PARA.TAB: It is also important to remember that there is no league ladder of human rights abuses across the world. We should not be comparing unnecessarily different levels of humans rights abuses in one country or the other. East Timor has to be considered on its merits. We have a huge country invading a very small and defenceless neighbour and then repressing, killing and torturing its people. In my view, that issue stands alone on its merits.

In the case of Vietnam, we have an authoritarian regime which imprisons people for their political beliefs, represses religion and conducts a variety of other human rights abuses. It does, of course, have this in common with a number of regimes across the world in its region and elsewhere and more than anything else is reminiscent of the former regimes in eastern Europe. That seems to me to be the most similar model of repression with which one can compare the current regime of Vietnam.

I welcome the motion of the honourable member for Moore (Mr Filing). I do not agree with everything that is in it. For example, just as the United Nations did not conduct the elections in Czechoslovakia, Hungary or Poland, I do not see any reason why it should conduct elections in Vietnam. But I do support the notion of free, open and multi-party elections in Vietnam. I also do not support the suggestion of trade sanctions, just I would not and have not supported trade sanctions against Indonesia. In my view, that is a device that should only be used in very extreme circumstances and with a multilateral foundation rather than a unilateral foundation.

There is ample evidence with respect to Vietnam that there are people in prison for very lengthy periods for crimes of conscience—both political and religious—that repression of religion is very common, that unfair judicial and police procedures are common, that abusive treatment of prisoners is also widespread and that there is a general repression of human rights debate and free speech.

Amnesty International concluded last year that there are at least 60 prisoners of conscience in Vietnam. I would suspect that there are probably considerably more than that. I would like to list some of the more notable. The first is Dr Nguyen Dan Que, who was mentioned by the honourable member for Moore. He was in gaol from 1978 to 1988 and then subsequently from 1990 until now. He has been nominated for the Nobel Peace Prize and has been gaoled for founding a non-violent political movement.

Professor Doan Viet Hoat was gaoled from 1976 to 1988 and again from 1990 till now. He was formerly the Vice Rector of the Van Hanh Buddhist University in Ho Chi Minh City. He was gaoled for 15 years for founding the Freedom Forum, in which his key act was to circulate a typed letter to a number of people.

The Venerable Thich Huyen Quang, head of the Unified Buddhist Church of Vietnam, has been under house arrest since 1982. The Venerable Thich Quang Do, Secretary General of the Unified Buddhist Church, was gaoled just recently. Pham Van Quang, as mentioned by the honourable member for Moore, was gaoled for 15 years for waving the flag of the former Republic of Vietnam at an international marathon in 1992 in Ho Chi Minh City. Dang Phuc Tue, Deputy Leader of the Unified Buddhist Church, was recently gaoled for five years for organising flood relief unofficially for victims of floods in the Mekong delta in October 1994. A number of other people who were part of the Buddhist Church were also gaoled for three and four years for that act.

Finally, the Catholic Archbishop Francis Xavier Nguyen Van Thuan previously spent 13 years in gaol and was then exiled and prevented from taking up his post as a bishop Ho Chi Minh City. Other prisoners include Pham Van Thanh, Thai Thi Kim Van, the Venerable Thich Tue Sy, the Venerable Thich Tri Sieu, Father Nguyen Chau Dat, Do Van Thac and Do Van Hung. They are just some of the political prisoners and religious prisoners currently held in Vietnam.

The evidence also indicates that political prisoners are commonly mixed with ordinary criminal prisoners for reasons that we can only speculate upon. It is also clear that the government on occasions engages in classic tactics designed to mislead visiting delegations. So when the United Nations delegation visited the prison camp at Phu Yen in 1984 there were only four prisoners in the camp, the rest of them were allegedly out engaging in flood fighting activities. It just so happened that the four who remained thought that the administration of the prison was excellent.

Harassment of churches and religious activities is widespread, ironically, given that one of the main victims, the Unified Buddhist Church, was also very prominent in demonstrations and dissidence against the former Diem government in the early 1960s in Vietnam. We remember very well the self-immolations that occurred in that time as a form of protest against that government. Such things have occurred recently, including on 24 May last year when a Buddhist monk self-immolated and there was a following demonstration in which a number of people ended up receiving prison sentences for three to four years just for participating.

Prison conditions are generally poor and abusive treatment is not uncommon. The Human Rights Watch organisation last year described the provision of food and medicine for prisoners as `grossly inadequate'. As was outlined by the honourable member for Moore, both Dr Nguyen Dan Que and Professor Doan Viet Hoat have serious health problems. There are good reasons to believe that the level of treatment and medicine they are receiving for these problems is grossly inadequate. Convictions that have formed the basis of this imprisonment under the Vietnamese penal code are for crimes such as `violation of national security' and `anti-socialist propaganda'. Sometimes those trials last little longer than a few hours with minimal or inadequate representation of the defendant.

It is worth noting that there is not a great deal of evidence that there is any form of substantial organised violent attempt to overthrow the ruling regime. However, perhaps at some variance with the honourable member for Moore, I think there are some positive signs of change in Vietnam. Last year Amnesty and also Human Rights Watch noted that there had been a relaxation of restrictions on freedom to worship. In 1992, Amnesty noted that there had been a release of over 100 former officials of the former Republic of Vietnam. Subsequently, in 1993, a number of religious prisoners were released. Economic liberalisation has been accompanied by some relaxation in censorship with a significant increase in open debate permitted on issues like corruption and mismanagement and by some degree of freedom of discussion in academic institutions.

There are signs that it is easier to get an exit visa. The dissident writer Dinh Thu Huong was recently allowed to go to Europe for a conference for the first time. There are also pleasing signs with respect to labour rights. Strikes are legal in the private sector and do happen. There is at least some semblance of genuine labour management bargaining, although unions are still predominantly government controlled. The genuine union activity that does occur appears to be essentially on a localised basis.

Amnesty has reported that there were no executions in Vietnam in 1994, although eight people were sentenced to death—from memory, for ordinary crimes, although I cannot be certain of that. Significantly, in 1995 the United States State Department in a report on the state of human rights in Vietnam stated there are `no credible reports of torture of detainees' and `no reports of political killings', which, given the source, indicates that things are perhaps not as bad as they might be elsewhere.

With economic change we will continue to see, in my view, these improvements occur. I was very pleased to see that the government raised these issues recently in strong terms with the Socialist Republic of Vietnam. Closer ties and more aid will assist Australia in influencing better human rights performance.

Overall, I call on the government to ensure that human rights is always at the centre of our relations with Vietnam. Regardless of whether it is better or worse than any other country, we have to treat these issues on their merits. There is evidence of serious infringement of human rights in Vietnam. We have to look at those issues on their merits and put forward a very strong position on behalf of the Australian people that these sorts of things are unacceptable and that imprisonment of religious and political leaders is unacceptable in our region. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —I congratulate the member for Moore (Mr Filing) for bringing this motion for discussion before the House today. I know that he is one member in this place who has consistently exhibited a genuine concern for these sorts of issues. My involvement with Vietnam goes back a considerable time. I last visited there in about mid-1993. I am hoping to return on another private visit later this year.

PARA.TAB: The fact that my visits have been private visits—although I have had some official contact with the government there—I think overcomes the potential problem that the member for Melbourne (Mr Tanner) made reference to: the possibility that one may be less likely, when going on an official delegation from this parliament, of which there has been one, to get to see what is really going on there. I was fortunate because of the friends and contacts that I had there to be able to have a good look at what was going on as far as human rights abuses in Vietnam were concerned. Vietnam now has over 70 million people. I particularly noticed when I was there last that it was, and I am sure still is, very much an ordered society.

I was particularly interested in having a look at what was happening in the churches there. There is an official and an unofficial church very much in evidence. As has already been mentioned, in practice freedom of religious worship is restricted and controlled. On a Sunday that my wife and I were there we attended a Protestant church which was essentially part of the official church. This was in Ho Chi Minh City. I was informed afterwards by an American with whom I was able to converse privately outside the church that there would have been a state representative present at that service who would have observed who was there and what was said. The fact that we were there would have been duly noted, as I am sure most of our movements in the country were throughout the week we were in Ho Chi Minh City and in Hanoi.

I had a discussion earlier this morning with a friend of mine who is a pastor and has just returned from Vietnam. He has had some dealings with the Full Gospel Church of Vietnam. It operates with permission but with severe restrictions and ongoing persecution. There is still a number of Christian pastors from that denomination and a number of others who are in prison in Vietnam. When I was there I gave the government representative with whom I met a list of names of Christians who were imprisoned. I subsequently found that some of them, though not all, had been released.

The Vietnamese communists have a historical antipathy towards religion in general, and particularly to the Catholics and Buddhists. Reference has been made to the Amnesty International 1995 report which showed that there are at least 60 prisoners of conscience currently in Vietnam, and seven of those are Roman Catholic priests.

Since the mid-1980s Vietnam has embarked on a process of what is called their doi moi. This is a process of economic liberalisation and market reforms. It has come about for a very practical and pragmatic reason: the country has realised that its very, very low standard of living will only be improved by opening up to international trade. Vietnam has a desperate need for foreign capital and it is going full steam to attract foreign capital.

Australia has been a major beneficiary in many respects of that push. When I was in Vietnam in 1993 Australia's BHP was the biggest foreign investor in the country. Of course, at that particular time there were still very real restrictions on American investment in Vietnam. Those restrictions have since been liberalised and I have no doubt that the Americans have probably overtaken Australia as one of the most substantial investors in Vietnam.

Vietnam is also a beneficiary of Australian aid. The honourable member for Melbourne alluded to the fact that there needs to be a connection between Australia's aid program and human rights. In my view, it is quite unrealistic to do otherwise. Australia's aid program to Vietnam, introduced in 1992 on a four-year cycle, involved $100 million. That is a lot of money. Because we are so generous, and in many respects rightfully so, to some of our neighbours—particularly to Vietnam because, I suspect, of the history that we have there—we ought not to make aid entirely untied. We ought to make it contingent in some way on Vietnam accepting responsibility for improving human rights.

The republic of Vietnam is a one-party state, controlled completely by the Vietnamese Communist Party. Having seen it first hand, it is, in my estimation, a completely totalitarian state in almost every sense of the word. Freedom of speech and freedom of the press in practice are severely limited. I say `in practice' because in a lot of these things they make the right sounds and they write down the right words about these freedoms, but in practice those things are severely restricted.

There are certainly very severe limits on public criticism of the regime. As we have already heard, the right to assembly is restricted both in law and practice. Ultimately, we ought to be under no illusions about Vietnam because it is in no sense a democracy. Vietnam has gone only a few tentative steps towards what must be an ultimate goal—at least from our perspective—of seeing the country become a democracy. Women face deeply ingrained social discrimination.

As I have already said, Vietnam trades extensively with Australia. From 1987 to 1993 our exports increased at the rate of 50 per cent per annum. In 1993 our exports to Vietnam totalled $114 million. We imported goods worth $251 million from Vietnam. We have quite a noticeable trade imbalance with Vietnam but, as we have trading imbalances with almost all our partners, perhaps it is not worthy of particular mention. Most of the imports from Vietnam involved crude petroleum.

In the context of this debate let me observe, perhaps on a little wider basis, that our foreign relations with countries such as Vietnam, Indonesia and China are conducted on a remarkably pragmatic level. Obviously there is no point in cutting off one's nose to spite one's face. But—and it is a big but—East Timor has been mentioned in this debate and I think those of us predominantly taking part in this debate are members who have consistently taken up the cause of East Timor. It has not been particularly politically correct to do so and it has not got us anywhere.

The member for Reid (Mr Ferguson), who will be speaking after me in this debate on the other side of the House, is the chairman of that Friends of East Timor group. As has already been alluded to in this debate, I just want to say that obviously our relations with Indonesia are on the same level in many respects as they are with Vietnam in that we seem to somehow accept the status quo, and this motion is about changing it. I do not know in the end what will happen to the East Timorese people, but I hope that something sooner or later does happen to give them what I believe is their right to self-determination.

In our relations with Vietnam, however they go, and there is every indication that they will continue to improve as a country of that size and with a standard of living as low as it has, represents for us a potentially substantial trading partner. However, let us not forget the oppression—and there is no other word for it—that our Vietnamese friends live under. Let us ensure that action is taken to improve this situation whenever and however we can. I once again commend the member for Moore for raising this issue in the House. It is an important matter and I support strongly his motion and commend it to the House.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ferguson Mr L.D.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —Likewise, I congratulate the member for Moore (Mr Filing) for moving the motion and broadly support its wording. On 8 July the Economist magazine, a fairly free market publication, gave indications of economic advance in Vietnam—eight to 10 per cent growth each year; inflation reduced from around 300 per cent to 10 to 20 per cent; and the situation of increasing women's participation in the work force, up to 47 per cent. It indicated that it was the third largest exporter of rice, there had been an end to black market trading in hard currency, and the dong, the local currency, had a degree of stability with the US dollar.

PARA.TAB: On the point the previous speaker made about Australia once having been a major investor in Vietnam, the reality is that the growth of foreign investment in Vietnam is such that Australia is a minor player these days—in fact, $2,600 million of overseas investment in 1993, with both Hong Kong and Taiwan over $400 million individually. So the results of the 1986 doi moi renovation process are certainly being seen on the economic front. The country also has a degree of advantage with its educational system and the fact that there is a significant number of the population fluent in a number of languages. So, on the economic front, there has been some improvement.

In regard to political reform, whilst the state department annual report of various countries last year did indicate that there was no evidence of torture and no reports in regard to judicial murders—and one important reform in regard to trade union rights was that there had actually been a very significant improvement in the rights of workers—on a broad front Vietnam still leaves a lot to be desired. It is very timely because my colleague the member for Fowler (Mr Grace), the Deputy Prime Minister (Mr Beazley) and I yesterday were present at the opening of the Tien Hau temple in Canley Vale in western Sydney for Sydney's Indochinese population. Whilst the degree of support for the Koumintong political line at that event might not represent all of the population, I think their emphasis upon the need for human rights reform in Vietnam was of importance.

One of the matters raised in this motion is the question of a one party political state. There is no doubt that there is a situation where no-one can essentially set up parallel competing party organisations. Ninety-two per cent of the National Assembly are members of the Communist Party of Vietnam and the other eight per cent got there because they were fairly compliant or else they were of national importance. So, essentially, it is important that that political system be opened.

It has been claimed quite rightly that political prisoners are shoved in gaol with people who are in there for far different offences, that food and medical conditions within leave a lot to be desired and that quite obviously there is no or minimal international access to prisoners. Of quite serious concern is the failure of this system to allow proper review and proper access to political trials.

It is not as though the situation in Vietnam has not gained international attention. Amnesty International, a very reputable organisation, concluded in its 1994 report that there were at least 60 prisoners of conscience. It reported that, in late 1994, the United Buddhist Church of Vietnam again came under increased internal pressure for its refusal to become part of the state sponsored Buddhist federation.

The Buddhists have been a force for national identity. During the Diem, the pro-Vietnamese governments persistently said that Vietnam had a national identity and stood by national determination. The Buddhists are saying in 1994 and 1995 that they do not wish to have their religious freedom suppressed. They do not wish to be forced into a state sponsored organisation. We in Australia should stand up for those rights. Since 1982, a total of 13 years, their supreme patriarch, Thich Huyen Quang, has been virtually under house arrest. They have a situation where they cannot freely carry out their religious observances. They have been forced to the point where there has been self-immolation as well as a large number of arrests and incarcerations.

The situation in Vietnam has been such that it has attracted international attention. Amongst the activities that tried to press the Vietnamese government towards an improvement was the pressure exerted by the UN working group on arbitrary detention in October 1994. In May of that year, Amnesty International issued a special report entitled Socialist Republic of Vietnam: Buddhist monks in detention expressing concern about the situation there.

In November last year Amnesty International, again, wrote to the Vietnamese government seeking information. From February they had sought permission for a delegation to look at questions of the national security legislation, the imprisonment of prisoners of conscience, the fairness of trials and—this, unfortunately, applies to a large number of other countries—the continued use of the death penalty. By September there was no response and Amnesty International again reiterated its request to the government of Vietnam to allow access and to open the country, in a very real sense, to international scrutiny.
A 1994 United States Department of State report on human rights practices to the US Congress again reiterated the problem in Vietnam. The report stated:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . the Government was responsible for continued human rights violations in 1994. Vietnamese citizens did not have the right to change their government or to assemble, associate, or speak freely. The Government continued to prohibit establishment of an independent press and independent organizations. It also maintained its longstanding policy of not tolerating dissent.
It further stated:

PARA.TAB: Law enforcement personnel appear able to arrest and incarcerate people without presenting arrest warrants.
Those arrested for peaceful expression of their views are likely to be charged under any one of several provisions in the Criminal Code outlawing acts against the State.

SPEECH.PARA: There is some significant debate and conjecture about the number of people in detention, because we cannot totally rely on those people who have an axe to grind against the current regime. But the US state department itself supplied figures that are of concern. It stated in the report:

PARA.TAB: There is no reliable information on the total number of political prisoners in Vietnam. Anti-SRV exile groups have claimed there are as many as 1,000 political prisoners in the country; other reliable sources put the figure closer to 200. The secrecy surrounding the Vietnamese judicial and prison systems makes it difficult for outside observers to make an accurate estimate.

SPEECH.PARA: There are large numbers of people being detained because they seek to widen the political process, to put forward views that are found to be in contravention of very tight restrictions and to express their religious views.

PARA.TAB: Australia has raised this matter internationally. The Minister for Foreign Affairs (Senator Gareth Evans) has indicated that he has taken the opportunity of having contact with Vietnam to press home to them these matters. I, for one, associate myself with the previous speaker's view that Australia should, as far as possible, attempt to attach Australia's aid payments to good governance towards the liberalisation of political process and to fewer human rights violations.

It is worth noting that article 4 of the 1992 constitution is also of concern because it certainly drives home the reality of the need for a very significant opening of Vietnam's political processes. It says, `The Communist Party of Vietnam, guided by Marxism-Leninism and Ho Chi Minh's thought, is the only force leading the State and society.' As I say, we do have a large way to go.

Finally, I want to refer to Mr Greg Sheridan, who was cited by the last speaker on this side, the honourable member for Melbourne (Mr Tanner). This particular individual is a constant apologist for the Indonesian government and other suppressing regimes in this region. He is the same person who believes that Australia should take every refugee claimant that gets off a boat here and, as soon as they say that Australia is a better country than where they come from, they should be accepted as refugees. Our support for this motion today indicates that there should be some consistency. I again emphasise my support for this motion.

TALK.START.PARA: —The recent changes to the electorate boundaries in Victoria have extended the division of Bruce south from Police Road to the Melbourne to Dandenong railway line. The new areas in the division include north Springvale, north Noble Park and north Dandenong. Included in my new constituency is a sizeable number, perhaps several thousand, of people with Indochinese backgrounds, mainly from Vietnam.
