These new constituents of mine are now making a real contribution to the future of Australia with their commitment to family and the work ethic and with their multifaceted culture. It is an honour to represent these people in our national parliament.

PARA.TAB: Yet, despite the fact that two decades have passed since the end of major conflict in Vietnam, the political situation there remains troubled. Few nations have suffered more from politics and conflicts than Vietnam. It has the chance to become a centre of commercial and cultural life in the region because of the vitality and intelligence of its people and because of its natural resources, in part supplied by the presence of the Mekong, that mighty river in the area.

Regretfully, this potential is being frustrated by politics. Vietnam still suffers from a one-party state, lack of free elections, an oppressive bureaucracy and lack of respect for human rights, leading to arbitrary imprisonment of people for their political and religious beliefs.

In recent years the leaders of the Socialist Republic of Vietnam have sought our assistance and that of other Western democracies to help in rebuilding their economy, shattered after many years of failed socialist philosophy. They recognise that they need to introduce free markets into their country, but they do not realise that there can be no economic freedom without political freedom and respect for human rights. They need our help, but we should not give that assistance without making it clear that we expect moves towards political freedom and a greater recognition of human rights.

The imprisonment of Nguyen Dan Que for his role in writing and promulgating the manifesto of the non-violent movement for human rights in Vietnam is an international disgrace. The incarceration, within the last two weeks, of an officially defrocked Buddhist monk, Thich Quang Do, and several of his followers for the crime of `undermining the policy of unity'—presumably exercising their internationally recognised right of free speech—is also a shocking disgrace.

These violations of human rights and arbitrary imprisonments require an early and firm response from the Australian government. But the Labor Party in government has never shown itself to be sympathetic to the Vietnamese people. The Whitlam Labor government covered Australia in shame with its response to the cries of the Vietnamese people. Whitlam and his cronies abandoned those Vietnamese who worked for Australian missions in Vietnam in the 1960s and the 1970s. The Whitlam Labor government refused to take bona fide refugees from Vietnam, turning them back and refusing to allow them free passage through Australia to other countries.

When he was head of the trade union movement, R.J.L Hawke, later Labor Prime Minister, strongly supported the Whitlam line. Many senior officials in the Whitlam government wanted a communist victory. When it came, these officials refused to face the facts of oppression and refused to face their refugee obligation.

There are many Whitlam admirers in the present Keating Labor government, and these people would put commerce with Vietnam ahead of human rights in Vietnam. This is simply not acceptable. We must work together to try to improve the situation for the people of Vietnam. Many still suffer persecution, many have no civil rights and many are still in prison for their beliefs.

It is disappointing that many members of the Australian Labor government will not participate in this task. In particular, members of the so-called socialist Left are opposed to any relaxation of human rights in Vietnam, on the grounds that this would undermine the so-called socialist utopia in that country. However, the new constituents of Vietnamese background in my electorate can be assured that, in our national parliament, I will continue to press strongly for the restoration of full human rights in Vietnam.

TALK.START.PARA: —I had worked out what I wanted to say in this debate on human rights in Vietnam until I heard the stupid remarks by the previous speaker, the member for Bruce (Mr Beale). He ought to be ashamed to come into this House. With regard to the idea that I stand here today to support the member for Moore (Mr Filing) in a bipartisan manner—I notice the member for Bruce is leaving the chamber; and so he should, after making such disgraceful remarks—I say that I do so proudly, yet I have to listen to the gutter politics delivered by the member for Bruce. He has to answer his own conscience. Just because his boundaries have changed and he is worried about losing his seat, he gives this House a tirade about previous governments. Where was he when the two members of the socialist Left were speaking in this House? Is he deaf or something? Is that why he did not hear what they had to say? He made the stupid remark that they support what is going on in Vietnam today. That is utter codswallop. I certainly would not want to be associated with the remarks of the member for Bruce, but I proudly support the remarks made by the other members who have spoken today.

PARA.TAB: The member for Bruce has got me really worked up on this matter. I do not want to repeat what other people have said. Suffice to say that, as far as I am concerned, the events in Vietnam are coming under the proper scrutiny of international organisations—and so they should be, because the Socialist Republic of Vietnam is a one-party state controlled by the Vietnamese Communist Party. I make no bones about it: I am not a communist and I resent anybody coming into this place and casting aspersions on me or on any of my colleagues without carefully considering what he is saying.

We all know about the constitutionally mandated leading role and the occupancy of nearly all the senior government positions in Vietnam by the Communist Party, and we do not agree with that situation. All members of the House who have spoken to the motion today and on previous occasions have not agreed with it. Yet for some unknown reason we have to suffer the stigma of the stupid remarks by the member for Bruce that we are associated with that government.

The present government of Vietnam has shown no discriminatory preference with regard to arrests. For instance, 23 monks and lay Buddhists have been arrested since the end of October last year. Vietnamese authorities have been called in for questioning on more than one occasion by all types of organisations, not only by the human rights organisations but also by others.

Some of the stupid remarks that have been made are that people do not represent average members of the public on human rights. Of course, that is absolutely ridiculous. We all know what is happening in Vietnam. I have more Vietnamese in my electorate than the member for Bruce would ever hear about, but I do not make stupid remarks about them like he did. I will immediately be putting out a newsletter to my constituents on his attitude. I hope the Vietnamese people within the new boundaries of his electorate do not vote for him. If there is any way that I can help to displace the member for Bruce at the next election, I will do so.

Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER (Hon. N.B. Reid)—Order! The time allotted for this debate has expired. The debate is adjourned and the resumption of the debate will be made an order of the day for the next sitting Monday.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hollis Mr C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That this House:

SPEECH.PARA: (1)notes that 10 to 16 September 1995 is Adult Learners Week;
(2)commends all involved in Adult Learners Week for their initiative;
(3)recognises that learning is a life-long experience; and
(4)recognises that adult and community education is making an important contribution to skilling Australians, creating an informed and active citizenry and helping adults with special learning needs.

Adult Learners Week will be celebrated for the first time across Australia from 10 to 16 September. The aim of the week is to increase community awareness of the range and quality of easily accessible adult learning programs.

PARA.TAB: Adult education is the most popular, as well as the most misunderstood, form of education in Australia. It is usually underfunded and underresourced and, as such, is vulnerable to any funding cuts. Proof of its status can be found in the titles of publications associated with adult education, such as Mike Newman's The Poor Cousin and Come in Cinderella, a report of the Senate committee inquiry into adult education in Australia in 1991.

This Cinderella has been knocking on the door for long enough. To 1995, around nine million Australian adults have participated in adult education at some time in their lives, undertaking further education or training after and outside formal education. Each year, around three million adults participate in some form of further education or training. Of all the courses that people participate in, more than half are provided by employers. Some 20 per cent of all courses are in computing and business administration, and 13 per cent are in the area of health, fitness and caring.

With the exception of those professions which have introduced mandatory continuing education, adult education and training is a voluntary activity. However, changes in the economy and in work organisation have created growing pressures and incentives for all work force members to continually develop their knowledge and skills and to have their knowledge and skills formally recognised.

More and more of us are becoming lifelong learners, and this trend will continue. Gone are the days when we left school, did an apprenticeship or university course and settled into an occupation for life. Changing technologies mean that throughout our lives we will have many career changes, often necessitating learning new skills.

Adult education has always responded in some way to the learning needs of working men and women. Thus a very important part of the history of adult education is to be found in the development of the mechanics institutes, the schools of arts and the Workers Educational Association, with which I worked before I entered this place.

It is also true that there has always been tension between adult education for vocational purposes and adult education for its own sake—for personal enlightenment and deeper understanding of the world around us. In the past, there have been distinctions between technical or vocational education and general or, as it was called, `liberal' education. The former has been referred to as `training' and characterised as inferior to `education'.

In some ways, these tensions have been accentuated by the national training reform agenda, which has given such a powerful impetus to skills formation for the Australian work force. The Australian National Training Authority negotiates with the states and territories over the allocation of some $3.6 billion for vocational education and training. However, there is now a growing appreciation in some quarters that the distinctions between vocational and non-vocational education—or between training and education—are of limited usefulness.

Within adult education itself, it has long been recognised that whether a course is vocational depends on the learner's motives. A computer course may be recreational for somebody who wants to play computer games or surf the Internet. A flower arranging course may be vocational for someone interested in working at a florist. In foreign language classes it is typical to find a similar mix of motives. Keeping this in mind, there is a good deal of evidence to show that adult education is making a significant contribution to the national skills formation effort.

In the past, much energy has been wasted on debating what adult education really is. From a personal point of view, and as chair of my local adult education group, I accept the reality of vocational courses. Indeed, as direct government grants have been decreased, it has only been by running vocational type courses that groups such as the Kiama Adult Education Association have been able to survive. Yet, having said that, it would be to my mind a great loss if we did not continue courses referred to in the old jargon as `liberal' adult education—that is, learning for the sake of learning.

In my view, there is also a role for courses enabling adults to come to terms with our modern, changing society. In the main, children today are better educated than their parents. The Scandinavian countries have recognised this and use the term `catch-up education' in reference to parents wanting to catch up with their children's education—I guess if for no other reason than to help them with their homework.

In some societies, there is a suggestion that everyone, regardless of age or educational background, should have the opportunity to gain an education which can be taken at whatever stage of life the person wishes to take it. Unfortunately, given that the economic rationalists have been let loose in the education sector, as they have in so many other sectors, such ideas have been abandoned before their time has come.

Historically, adults have gathered together in order to change their lives. In the 19th century in Australia, people gathered together in schools of arts and mechanics institutes to learn to read and write and to learn the new mechanical arts in order to change their communities and to gain a greater understanding of the world and how they might influence it.

The Workers Educational Association was founded in most states of Australia in the second decade of this century so that working people—often from trade unions—could learn together and gain more control over their lives. I have always felt it was a pity that the WEA was adopted full scale from Great Britain and was never adapted to Australian conditions and standards. But I acknowledge the tremendous contribution that the WEA has made to adult education in Australia. The changes were a bit late in coming, but they were made in the end.

We must also recognise, especially this year, the role that the Australian Army Education Service has played in respect of adult education. I was delighted to play a very small part in obtaining some funding to assist in the publication of the book entitled A sweet use of adversity: the Australian Army Education Service in World War II and its impact on Australian adult education. There can be absolutely no doubt as to the tremendous impact that the Australian Army Education Service had on adult education in this country.
Dr Frederico Mayor, the Director-General of UNESCO, has said:

SPEECH.PARA: Lifelong learning is a basic human right and a universal human value; learning and education are ends in themselves, to be aimed at by both individuals and societies and to be promoted and made available throughout the entire lifetime of each individual. This recognises the essential role of learning throughout our lives, in our workplaces, our homes, our communities and in our retirement. We are all lifelong learners!

Mike Newman, in Defining the enemy: adult education in social action 1994, draws on Gelpi, who has been head of the lifelong education unit at UNESCO for 20 years, in describing adult education. He writes:

He sees lifelong education as "education for all and by all". He sees it as involving new and dynamic relationships between political systems, work and production, and social and cultural movements. He sees it as bringing together traditional and modern, formal and non-formal, institutional and self-directed forms of education and learning. He sees it as a potential means of redressing individual inequities, doing away with unfair divisions of labour, transforming whole nations, and putting to right the unequal relations between rich and poor countries. The idea of lifelong learning has become increasingly important in a rapidly changing world. Although the concept has always been the essence of the philosophy of the adult and community education sector. Adult community education is an activity orientated towards lifelong learning that:

PARA.TAB: provides opportunities for people (of all ages, regardless of employment status or previous education) or enhances their vocational, personal, cultural or social development.

SPEECH.PARA: It is important that in Adult Learners Week we are aware of the valuable contribution that adult education providers are making in order to enrich our society. Many activities have been conducted throughout Australia. Those people who work in the field of adult education do so with a dedication that is hard to imagine exists in any other field. I am proud that through much of my adult working life I have been associated with adult education, and I continue to be associated with it as Chairman of the Kiama Adult Education Association.

PARA.TAB: Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER (Mr Newell)—Is the motion seconded?

TALK.START.PARA: —I second the motion and reserve my right to speak.

—I thank the member for Throsby (Mr Hollis) for putting this matter on the Notice Paper of the House of Representatives and giving us the opportunity to participate in debate on this very important subject. I congratulate all concerned with Adult Learners Week 1995 for the initiative that it will bring into the Australian community.

PARA.TAB: Prior to my election to parliament, I had spent my life in education from the time I started school at the age of five. One of the areas of education in which I was personally involved as an educator was adult education. I can say to the member for Throsby, in commenting on his final remarks, that one of the reasons adult education is pleasurable for all concerned is that it has a totally motivated clientele. Having been a high school teacher—where the level of motivation amongst students can be mixed—it is certainly very welcome for an educator to be dealing with people who are in a learning situation because that is where they want to be and they are focused on it.

The broad goals of Adult Learners Week are to increase the profile and recognition of adult learning, to increase participation in adult learning, to enhance networks amongst all involved in adult learning and to promote national objectives for education and training. The three national themes that have been selected to provide a focus are creating opportunities for involvement in the areas of lifelong learning, women's ways of learning and leading, and access to learning for all.

I am sure that those who chose those themes must have had a very difficult task. It is always very difficult to reduce broad educational areas to narrower areas and to decide which of those areas need to be concentrated on. However, as the years go by and as the Adult Learners Week initiative is pursued—as I am sure it will be—there will be the opportunity to pursue other areas.

At the risk of being typecast, I intend to make some comment on the subject of women's ways of learning and access to education. Some years ago I chaired a subcommittee of the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Employment, Education and Training which looked at the subject of returning long-term unemployed people to the work force. We very quickly identified that the basic client group was women. That inquiry was conducted in 1987. The levels of long-term unemployment amongst men, particularly young males, has increased since that time. Nevertheless, overwhelmingly we were addressing women at that time.

Very early the inquiry clearly identified that the area of education on which one needed to focus in order to get long-term unemployed people into training and back into the work force was adult education. This was for a number of reasons that are quite central to adult education. Its programs are usually short and do not have any academic prerequisites. They are designed as bridges, in many cases, to further courses of education and skilling. They can, in themselves, provide the opportunity to learn discrete areas of skill. These are characteristics of education and training relevant to people who are experiencing long-term unemployment.

People who have been unemployed long term tend to be undereducated in the first place—undereducated in terms of the demands for education and skill that presently apply in the work force. They may be undereducated by virtue of having left formal education prematurely or they may be—as in the case of women in our society, particularly older women—women who have been out of the work for a very long time. Whatever appropriate skills or education they previously had are no longer in demand or else are so rusty as to be considered not viable for employment.

I would not want it thought that, because I am talking in terms of employment, that is all adult education is about. However, when one deals with people who have been long-term unemployed—whether voluntarily or involuntarily—you very quickly identify that the matter of self-esteem is central to the ability of these people to adjust their skills, attitudes or whatever is necessary to get them back into mainstream society.

The simple fact is that employment by somebody else is an objective value of your worth, or it is seen in that way by most people. The matter of collecting a pay packet is a way of seeing that you are of value to someone else. Or, if you are self-employed, the matter of making a profit, and therefore having the equivalent of a pay packet, is proof that what you do is something that is of value to other people. That is the easy benchmark and, I think, the easiest—in some senses it is the most relevant—way to talk about it.

Therefore, when you talk about women who have been out of employment for a long time, particularly because they have had family responsibilities, you are dealing with people who, in most cases, have some difficulty with that concept because they have not been in what they see as an objective situation of remuneration. No matter how supportive a woman's family, her husband and her children are towards her role as a mother and wife, the personal nature of their attitudes may nevertheless leave her with the niggling doubt that she does not have any real, objective worth.

The step out of the home is often one that involves a major psychological hurdle for a lot of women returning to the work force. Adult education bridging courses—the so-called short courses—have long since proven to be extremely important to such people. A number of them have been devised over the years and were starting at about the time of the inquiry of that House of Representatives committee I just referred to.

That committee identified that the establishment of those formal bridging courses which were easy for the client group—in this case, women—to enter, which were non-threatening and apparently non-demanding, was important in easing someone into the learning situation. It is a matter of record that many women who started out on such courses as `New Opportunities for Women', which might appear to some people to be fairly low level courses, nevertheless have shown that they are capable of going on to very high levels of education indeed.

Of course, it is a little bit misleading to talk about higher education as though that is the area of true worth. As an educator in many different areas, including the tertiary area, I am aware that all levels of education and learning are of equal value. Because each level addresses a specific client group, success is measured with respect to that particular client group. Success at the adult education level is therefore every bit as worthy as is success at the highest possible educational level—let us say, supervision of someone doing a doctorate in philosophy.

The point I make is that it is important that society focus for a period of time—in this case, through Adult Learners Week—on the very real social, economic and educational relevance of adult education. Of course, in this day and age we receive a lot of education daily and informally through the television set. Things that once upon a time one had to read learned books about are daily and nightly presented to us in a very learned way on the television screen. Valuable as that medium is as a general educator of society—and maybe even as a specific part of a formal learning course—there is no substitute for the interaction of teacher with student in the first place, and of student with student in the second place.

Adult education, because of its ease of access and its apparently simple and limited objectives at point of contact and entry, provides that necessary encouragement to gaining education as well as the basis for gaining the confidence to go on to achieve further skills and higher levels of education, or maybe to just try out the skills one already has.

It is a matter of record that many people have become successfully self-employed—producing goods and services through their own initiative, intelligence and imagination for our society—after having undertaken a very basic adult education course which may have been considered non-vocational, just one that was designed only for personal growth. My time has expired. As I said at the beginning, I am grateful to the member for Throsby for putting this item on the agenda and raising it to a level of public prominence. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Adams The Hon D.G.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is a pleasure to speak on the motion relating to Adult Learners Week, which has been moved by the member for Throsby (Mr Hollis), and to follow the words of the member for Moncrieff (Mrs Sullivan). I am pleased to be taking part in Adult Learners Week, which is being held between 10 and 16 September this year, and I was honoured to be asked to be one of its patrons.

PARA.TAB: Learning is not just something people do at school; learning begins at school and continues for the rest of one's life. In some cases, like mine, learning really starts after leaving school. In my case, I was unable to participate fully in school programs because of literacy difficulties. After becoming involved in the union movement, I found it necessary to read and write—what would be called—properly, and I sought to find ways to learn. Learning to read and write was much more difficult for adults in those days, as they were assumed to have acquired those skills, and one really had to seek assistance throughout the education system and beyond.

Nowadays it is becoming much more acceptable to seek additional learning and training. The stigma of not having learnt at the right time is fading. In fact, Working Nation, the program geared to include additional training in all its employment schemes, is there and working very well. So, although there have been massive changes in the working structure of Australia, the government is in a greater part trying—and in a greater part succeeding—to take Australians through the changes for them to come out prepared for our next century and the challenges that lie there.
The member for Throsby quoted the words of the Director-General of UNESCO, Dr Frederico Mayor, when he said:

SPEECH.PARA: Lifelong learning is a basic human right and a universal human value: learning and education are ends in themselves, to be aimed at both individuals and societies and to be promoted and made available throughout the entire lifetime of each individual.

I think that is a very good quote; it says that learning in itself basically is worth while. I think that is a pretty good aim to have, and it is something worth saying. It is a great aim for all adult learners and a great aim for Adult Learners Week. It is a chance to give the basic right a good boost, and to make sure that learning is part of the agenda for all decision makers. It is essential in all aspects of our life, whether it be in the workplace, our communities, our homes or retirement—when we think about the third age universities and now open learning, which is part of the Australian way of life.

PARA.TAB: Learning will help us rebuild lives that have been damaged. It will help people with disabilities become part of our communities. Those from overseas can find ways of overcoming barriers to learning. Learning is also fun. Whatever areas we choose to develop our skills in, there are others who are also keen to develop skills in those areas. It is a way to make new friends and to set oneself challenges in friendly competition. Learning does not have to be `because you have to do it'; learning can be what you want to do, and that is stimulating and entertaining.

The idea of Adult Learners Week is a celebration and also a campaign. It is celebrating the contribution made by adult and community education to the empowerment of people, to the economic and cultural development of Australia and to social change. It is a campaign to broaden the awareness of the diversity of adult learning and to encourage more adults to participate.

I can readily say that I participated in adult learning and it changed my life; it will do the same for others who are prepared to throw away their inhibitions and have a go. Taking the first step is always frightening, but it is like the first swim: once you're in, you have a great time and you can't think why you haven't done it before. I congratulate the organisers and look forward to the tremendous week in September that is being planned. I also pay tribute to all those men and women who are the workers within adult education, who play such an essential role throughout our country. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —I am pleased to support the motion of the member for Throsby (Mr Hollis) today to recognise Adult Learners Week, and I commend adult learners around Australia. We know that education does not necessarily end when one leaves school. I came to this place with the desire to have further development in education. I studied until year 10 but, because money was short, I was not able to go on to further studies—that was 30 or 40 years ago. So it is with pleasure that I discuss this issue today.

PARA.TAB: People can, and do, continue to participate in some form of education throughout their working lives and into retirement. In fact, further education is often an enjoyable pastime during retirement. As Francis Bacon once said, `Studies serve for delight.' It is estimated that there are around three million adult learners in Australia participating in some form of education or training and that about 78 per cent of all Australians aged 21 and over are participating in further education. It is most interesting to note that about half of the courses they are participating in are provided by employers. So on this day we must recognise the essential role that employers in our free enterprise system play in the training and learning process. Employers recognise the importance of having their work force up to date and fully trained.

Individuals also recognise the importance of further training. The workplace is extremely competitive today and education and training qualifications provide a distinct advantage. For those looking for a definition of `adult learning', there are several main categories: formal education within our universities and colleges; private-provider education through business colleges and so forth; community provided education through non-profit organisations such as third age universities; education through unions and the professional associations; education through government agencies; and, finally, the everyday education of ourselves in our contact through the community, through the workplace and through careful winnowing of the media. That is the enormous diversity of adult education available in Australia.

It is increasingly recognised that at least 10 per cent of Australian adults have significant literacy and numeracy problems. Technological change demands that as many as possible become more computer literate. This is Australia's first Adult Learners Week, which seeks to promote all the positive aspects of adult learning that I have mentioned. The promoters of Adult Learners Week feel that, despite the vast number of people participating in adult learning, not a lot is known about it in Australia—a fact which is confirmed by my own experience in my electorate. Over the last couple of years a small band in Port Pirie has been particularly keen to promote adult learning, and I have been pleased to be able to support them. I have shared an hour or two with them in recent months, just watching, and have enjoyed their keen participation. I understand that guidance and advisory services for adults wanting to return to some form of education or training are inadequate. I hope that Adult Learners Week can start to redress some of these inadequacies.

I commend those adults who are participating in further education and are continually renewing their skills and finding new ones. I know there a number of mature age students and third age university students in my electorate who enjoy their studies immensely. To those who are participating in Adult Learners Week from 10 to 16 September, I wish you all the best in many years to come.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I will be brief. I want to thank all those who have participated in this debate today. As all speakers have said, it is an important debate which deals with a sector of the Australian education system that in many respects has been overlooked. I referred in my comments to Mike Newman's description of it in The Poor Cousin or in the report of the Senate Standing Committee on Employment, Education and Training entitled Come in Cinderella.

PARA.TAB: I sometimes think of adult education as a sleeping beauty waiting for the prince to come along. The prince may come along with the funding, but I think the time has passed for that because the economic rationalists have taken hold of the education system, like so many other areas, and now there is an emphasis on vocational training. Important as vocational training is—I always support vocational training—we must not get too carried away. There is the worth of education for education's sake. There is the worth of education to make us better participants in the community in which we live. The United States refers to this as civics. I know that the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) has said recently that money has been made available to teach civics, the political system—not in a partisan political way, but the general concept of politics in our schools. I support that very much. It would not go astray to have a more general view of that out there in the community as well.

One thing that always surprises us as members of parliament is the—dare I say it—ignorance that many people have of the political system, which comes out in things that they talk to us about when they see us at social functions and various other things. It is a great pity that people are not more aware of just how the political system in Australia, with all its strengths and weakness, works. That is a very important role that adult education can play.

I was particularly attracted to the comments of the honourable member for Lyons (Mr Adams) in which he said that adult learning can be fun. It can be fun. The honourable member for Moncrieff (Mrs Sullivan) made the point that those who participate in adult education are doing it because they want to participate. That is so important. Although schools are much better than when I went to school, there was often a reluctance by some people to learn and you had to force them to learn.

Adult education is an activity that people participate in of their own free will. They are there because they want to learn, whether it is because of a vocational interest or a general interest. They are motivated and, therefore, the exercise of education is much more enjoyable.

Like my colleague the member for Lyons, I am a patron of Adult Learners Week. I look forward to the week. I wish parliament were sitting in that week and we could have a fulsome debate on it in the parliament. We have to have the debate a fortnight before the week starts because this is the last opportunity we will have to do it.

I congratulate all those associated with Adult Learners Week. I think it was a great initiative. It is the first time it has been held and it most certainly will not be the last. I thank all those who participated in the debate today. I am sure that each of us in our own small way have made a contribution to the success of Australian Adult Learners Week.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! It being almost 2.45 p.m., the debate is interrupted in accordance with standing order 104A. The debate is adjourned, and the resumption of the debate will be made an order of the day for the next sitting Monday. The member will have leave to continue speaking when the debate is resumed.

—In the aftermath of the 15 July poor showing by the Queensland Goss government and its particular disregard for the people of the metropolitan south-east in respect of the proposed tollway, we find three members opposite starting to panic about the federal implications. Last weekend we read of their opposition to the Goss proposals. Of course, their pleas are not on behalf of the many thousands of affected Queenslanders but on the optimum strategy for their electoral survival whenever we go to the polls federally.

PARA.TAB: Whether Premier Goss eventually changes his mind is problematic, particularly where the ALP vote is at risk. That is in marked contrast to his and state energy minister Tony McGrady's arrogant and dismissive attitude on the Eastlink project, which is planned to join the Queensland and New South Wales electricity grids through the Lockyer Valley in my electorate and the southern part of the Darling Downs in the electorate of my colleague the honourable member for Maranoa (Mr Bruce Scott). While the federal coalition supports a national electricity grid, that support is conditional on appropriate environmental, health, economic and social impact studies.

To this end, we have supported an Eastlink Senate inquiry, approved in the other place a few months ago. Mr McGrady's reactions have been to press ahead willy-nilly and without any thought for people, most of whom he knows do not vote for his side of the political fence. I say to the Premier and Mr McGrady that the anti-Eastlink lobby is strong and effective. Just as it did in the Labor state marginal seats in Brisbane on 15 July, so it will do in the federal Queensland marginals in the coming months unless they listen to people at the grassroots.

TALK.START.PARA: —I take this brief opportunity to pay tribute to a marvellous woman who has made a remarkable contribution to community work. Lucy Ann Medhurst is one of the Hunter Valley's most popular ladies. There will be no shortage of congratulatory messages when Lucy celebrates her 100th birthday on Friday, 15 September.

PARA.TAB: The daughter of a carpenter and part-time undertaker, Lucy was born at Jerrys Plains in the Denman-Muswellbrook-Singleton area in 1895 and has spent all her life in the Hunter Valley. Daughter Hilda Andrews and grand daughter Sandra Olney have organised an afternoon tea for Lucy's century. Many friends, including this humble person, will be in attendance to sing happy birthday to Lucy.

Unfortunately, Lucy's husband, her two sisters and her five brothers are deceased, but Lucy will certainly enjoy the party to celebrate her long innings. My congratulations and best wishes go to Lucy Ann Medhurst. I am sure all members present in this House join me in wishing her the happiest possible day for her 100th birthday.
Honourable members—Hear, hear!

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cleary Mr P.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —Whenever the issue of tariffs is raised in this House the free traders extol the virtues of international competitiveness. Rarely do the proponents of free trade address the inequities or the export barriers that Australian manufacturers confront. I recently received a letter from a whitegoods producer in my electorate which illustrates the point. He had this to say:

SPEECH.PARA: Our competitors are currently subject to a duty of 8 percent which will reduce to 5 percent from July 1st 1996.
At the same time, 10 percent of our Australian production is exported to 27 foreign countries where we encounter a range of duties.

He lists the countries' tariff rates as being Canada, 11.7 per cent; Korea, 40 per cent; Indonesia, 65 per cent; Malaysia, 63 per cent; China, 80 per cent; Fiji, 35 per cent; PNG, 11 per cent; Pacific islands, 30 per cent; and Thailand, 45 per cent—not very level, that playing field. Here is a company, crucial to the local economy, which wants, in the words of the general manager, nothing more than `a playing field that is truly level'. He goes on to say:
As manufacturers the challenges will remain with us to combat the imports with our own skills in creativity, innovation and continuous improvement to world-class manufacturing.

All he wants is a fair go. Mr Speaker, I know you will understand this: when the Eagles went down yesterday, Micky Malthouse was very angry. He said that his team did not get a fair go. He said the umpires discriminated against his side. He said that but could not say much else because he would have got a fine. He basically wanted a fair go.

PARA.TAB: Mr Speaker, if you took Illawarra down to Newcastle, that famous Illawarra wind was blowing and you were forced to run into that wind for two halves, you would claim that a level playing field was not in existence. Imagine what the Prime Minister (Mr Keating), the great follower of the Collingwood Football Club, would say if Collingwood had to kick into the wind for four quarters. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —I might just say that we ran into the wind for the first half and still won yesterday.

—Today I would like to warn the House and the nation about an insidious degradation of our habitat and our environment. What I am talking about is ugly, it is big, it stands out, it disseminates mainly rubbish, it can plonk itself down wherever it likes and it takes absolutely no notice of public opinion. You might think I am talking about Jeffrey `Glib' Kennett, but I am not. I am talking about mobile phone towers.

PARA.TAB: They are destroying the aesthetics of our community and environment very rapidly. The majority of our mobile phones at present are analog. These require towers at approximately 80-kilometre intervals. We are changing to digital. These require towers at 30-kilometre intervals. Therefore, the number will more than double. You will not be able to travel anywhere without these ugly concrete and steel structures destroying your appreciation of our country.

I first raised this matter in February 1994. Optus, Vodafone and Telecom all said that they would be sympathetic to the views of the public. However, I believe they are going hell for leather to get these towers up before stronger guidelines are implemented. The government should instigate a moratorium on the erection of these towers and wait until the global satellite communications are implemented in the near future which will no doubt take over the distribution of all our phone communications.

TALK.START.PARA: —Today I wish to raise in the House the very important issue of the listing of drugs on the pharmaceutical benefits scheme—particularly the drug of pulmozyme, which has been rejected two or three times by the pharmaceutical benefits scheme board and by the Minister for Human Services and Health (Dr Lawrence). I would ask that she reconsider that position and that at this Thursday's pharmaceutical benefits scheme board meeting they list the drug pulmozyme on that scheme in order to reduce the outrageous cost to ordinary Australians of that drug.

PARA.TAB: At the moment, each month people are paying $1,125 for the drug pulmozyme—ordinary families who simply cannot afford to do it. For cystic fibrosis sufferers, the difference between this drug and many other drugs on the PBS for those people who have a positive response to pulmozymeis that it dramatically and manifestly increases their chances of having a normal life and increases their longevity. So I ask the minister and the board to reconsider that position and to list pulmozyme on the PBS to alleviate the concerns of so many Australians.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to express my disgust at the contribution made by the honourable member for Bruce (Mr Beale) in the debate earlier on today with respect to human rights in Vietnam. All of us on both sides of the House, other than him, managed to avoid the temptations to descend into cheap shots. He, unfortunately, made a number of wild and inaccurate assertions which reflect his desire, which he was quite open about, to curry favour with the Vietnamese community in his new electorate. Fortunately for the Labor Party and unfortunately for him they are more sophisticated than that.
—Order! The honourable member for Melbourne is offending the standing orders in that he is reviving debate, and I understand participated in that debate in the course of the day.

—Bob Carr, the good mate of the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) is just proposing to take away from local councils in New South Wales the right to control their own beaches. I take it as a fundamental democratic principle that local people should control local events and that citizens should have control over their own backyards. Bob Carr's move is designed to turn Manly's Reef Beach into a nudist beach. Because Bob Carr has done so little, he is now saying that it was actually an election promise to turn Reef Beach into a nudist beach. But the fact is that if it was an election promise it was one that he kept as a deep, dark secret from the people of Manly.

PARA.TAB: The fact of the matter is that for four years Reef Beach has been a family beach, not a nudist beach. Local people do not want it as a nudist beach; councils do not want it as a nudist beach; and, if Bob Carr took one of his famous walks, he would not want it as a nudist beach either. I say to the Prime Minister, `Have a whisper into the ear of Bob Carr.' Is this really the side of Sydney that we want to present to people in the run-up to the Olympics? Just because the Prime Minister thinks that Australia is the arse end of the world is no reason for Labor to turn Reef Beach into the arse end of Sydney.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! I might just say to the honourable member for Warringah that it is very clever to use unparliamentary language, but it offends the standing orders. Do not do it again.

—If the honourable member for Warringah (Mr Abbott) is there, I am sure that international guests will not go there. I would like to make a speech today about a group of Australians recently discovered by the opposition—that is, the small business people; the retailers of Australia; the people who, before the last election, were going to be made the taxpayers of Australia through the opposition's GST.

PARA.TAB: Last week, a delegation of these people was brought down from the Hunter region to confer with the shadow minister for small business. They spoke about predatory pricing and control of the retail market by supermarket chains. Did they get into issues that the coalition had been responsible for in New South Wales? Not at all. Those issues would have been the planning of regional areas and the hours which shops can open. We all know that the expansion of retail hours was brought in by Kerry Chikarovski, the former New South Wales minister.

That is the issue that the opposition refuses to address, because that is the issue which is causing most concern for retailers in Australia today. It is impossible for small businesses to compete with the expanded hours of retail chains. Until the opposition gets fair dinkum and addresses that as an issue, they should sit down and shut up. They are not doing anything more than trying to buy a few votes very cheaply and, just like with the GST, they will not succeed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Slipper Mr P.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I listened to the crocodile tears being shed a moment ago by the member for Paterson (Mr Horne) on behalf of small retailers. I would like to speak on behalf of a small retailer in the electorate of Dickson, soon to be represented by Tony Smith for the Liberal Party. A report in today's paper under the headline `When not enough staff is too many' states:

SPEECH.PARA: Bill Bowden's small supermarket is finally doing well enough for him to employ more staff—but if he does, the State Government will close him down.

PARA.TAB: In a quirk of Queensland's industrial relations law, Mr Bowden is caught between his struggle to survive as a small business "open all hours" and the requirement to employ no more than six people.
A government regulation prevents an independent retailer, such as Mr Bowden, rostering more than six staff on at any one time.

SPEECH.PARA: He has been warned by the Industrial Relations Commission. He can have only six people on his staff and at the present time he has queues eight deep. He is taking a petition to the Premier to seek permission to employ just two extra people so that he can provide an adequate service for the people of Brendale, which is near Strathpine.

PARA.TAB: We have a situation where a retailer in an area of high unemployment needs to put on extra staff and compete with the big chains, but the state Labor government is saying to him, `You cannot do this; you must keep people out of work.' What is more, he is not able to provide a continued reasonable service to his local community. The state Labor government stands absolutely condemned for preventing service to local people and for preventing employment in a local store.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to pay tribute to Steve Merrick and congratulate him on a decision he has made. You may not have heard of Steve Merrick, but he is a hero of the Hunter Valley who represented Australia—and played brilliantly—as half-back in the recent Bledisloe Cup challenge matches.

PARA.TAB: Steve could have had the rugby world at his feet, but he would have had to have gone to Sydney to continue as Australia's half-back. He has a wife and he has responsibilities, and moving to Sydney would have jeopardised his future in the coal industry, where he has a very important job coming up.

Many young people today—some of us here perhaps—would throw our kids and wives in the ocean to play football for Australia, but Steve got his priorities right. You only last as a footballer for a few years. He has ensured his whole future by staying in the Hunter and letting the fame and glory of rugby go by.

TALK.START.PARA: —The member for Lilley (Mr Swan) must have been a little embarrassed by the Queensland state election. He and the state director have the great distinction of turning a 19 per cent majority into a 16-vote majority. But it gets a lot worse than that. The actual number of votes that the Labor Party got in the Queensland election was 80,000 less than that of the Liberal and National parties. The two-party preferred vote was 53 per cent to the Liberal and National parties and 48 per cent to Labor.

PARA.TAB: I am pleased that the Liberal Party is going to be successful in their challenge in the Townsville seat. The Goss government has a mandate for nothing, and I hope there will be another election before long so they can be thrown where they should have been thrown before—onto the scrap heap.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! It being approximately 3 p.m., in accordance with standing order 106A, the time for members' statements has concluded.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Keating The Hon P.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —After question time last Thursday—
—What question time?

—After questions had been placed on the Notice Paper, after that question time, the member for Chisholm (Dr Wooldridge) rose to say that he had been misrepresented by me wherein I had quoted his remark about Dr Lawrence:

SPEECH.PARA: If she had exercised proper judgment, Penny Easton might still be alive today.
I also quoted the reported rebuke on the AAP wire of him by his leader, Mr Howard. He rose in the House and said:
For the record, I do not say, and have not said, that Carmen Lawrence caused Penny Easton's death.
I believe that to be totally untrue. I ask that it be referred to the Committee of Privileges.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will look at the issue raised by the Prime Minister and report back at a later date.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: Minister for Human Services and Health

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is to the Minister for Human Services and Health. Have you been asked to stand aside from the ministry by the National Secretary of the Australian Labor Party?
—I am sure that the Leader of the Opposition would like to know the nature of discussions that go on within the Labor Party.

PARA.TAB: Opposition members—Yes! Yes!

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! Those on my left will cease interjecting.

—I am sure he would like to know the answer to those questions. I would like to know the answers to a few questions too. I would like to know, for instance, whether the Leader of the Opposition discussed with Mr Court the establishment of a royal commission and its terms of reference and whether he involved the member for Chisholm in those discussions. I would like to know why Richard Court, the Premier of Western Australia, ignored the advice of his deputy leader, the Deputy Leader of the National Party, the leader of the Legislative Council and others who advised against the royal commission.

—Mr Speaker, on a question of relevance under the standing orders, it is not relevant for a minister to avoid a question by then presenting her own questions. She will be able to ask the questions when she is over here after the next election. At the present time she should try to answer the question or sit down.
—Order! The member for Flinders will resume his seat. The minister has the call.
—Mr Speaker, it is quite clear—
—There is no point of order.

—Mr Speaker, on the point of order: I seek your ruling, and the ruling I seek from you is on this point. The minister has been asked about discussions between herself and the National Secretary of the Labor Party. To give an answer which is relevant, she must refer to those discussions and say yes or no rather than ask questions about discussions between other persons not mentioned in the question.

—Order! As I have constantly said in this place, if the honourable member would like guidance given to the chair, not only in this parliament, then change the standing orders. In respect of the particular question, it may well be outside the standing orders to ask a minister about that, given it does not go to her responsibility. But I am giving the minister the opportunity to respond.

—Thank you, Mr Speaker. That just underlines the hypocrisy of asking it in the first place, if you do not want to have some questions put to you. Why did Richard Court act against the advice of his own deputy? He was acting on instructions from the Leader of the Opposition. This royal commission was set up on your advice, wasn't it? What discussions did you have with Mr Court?

PARA.TAB: Government members interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Are you looking over there, Mr Speaker?
—I again remind members early this week of the provisions of standing order 55. If the minister is not interrupted, she will conclude her answer far more quickly.

—As I indicated at the outset, there are a lot of questions I would like to have the answer to. We are not likely to get those answers from anyone over here. We are not likely to get the answers from members opposite.
—We are not getting answers from you.
—Order! I warn the honourable member for Mayo.
—We are not likely to get them in the royal commission because the report probably will not appear.
—Go on, sit down.
—Order! I warn the member for O'Connor.
—I bet you would.
—The members opposite will not answer the obvious questions, so I do not think they should have the temerity to ask me along those lines.
—My question is directed to the Prime Minister. Does the Prime Minister insist that ministers tell the truth?

PARA.TAB: Opposition members—Oh!

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! Those on my left. The question has been asked and the Prime Minister will be heard.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Keating The Hon P.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Having myself been here for 26 years and never having carried a `lies, lies, lies' banner around my back, I can say that I insist that, in the performance of their public duties, in their dealings with the public and in the parliament, ministers tell the truth and behave honestly at all times. Of course I do.
—What about Kirribilli House?
—Order! The Leader of the National Party!
—I beg your pardon? What about not interrupting?
—Order! Honourable members—
—What about getting down on your knees?

—The honourable member will be out the door if he interjects again. All members are entitled to be heard in this place, under the provisions of standing order 55, on both sides. The Prime Minister has the call and he will be heard.
—Last week we heard a great deal from the Leader of the Opposition about the truth. He said these things on the AM program:

ANSWER.PARA: We want to assert the very simple principle that truth is absolute, truth is supreme, truth is never disposable in national political life.
He then went on to say:
. . . we are talking about the principle of telling the truth in public life.

He then enjoins me to adopt that principle. Mr Speaker, that unctuous hypocrisy was in fact pricked the very afternoon he had been saying those things when a journalist had the good memory and perhaps the bad manners to remind him that the member for O'Connor had admitted to being a liar on national television.

TALK.START.PARA: —And that is the difference between me and Carmen.
—Order!
—Order! The House will come to order!

—Mr Speaker, the opposition front bench are celebrating the fact that they have a self-confessed liar in their midst. When asked about the fact that the member for O'Connor had publicly admitted to lying, he said:

ANSWER.PARA: Oh, that. Well, that did occur a very long time ago and it hasn't occurred while he's been a member of my front bench.
`Oh, that'! The journalist had the temerity to go on and say, `Oh, there's a statute of limitations here, is there?' The reply was:
Well, there's not a statute of limitations but I think quite a lot of water has flowed under the bridge . . .

Not the Hindmarsh Bridge, of course, but under the bridge. So the point that the news services made of it was that here he is, with this unctuous hypocrisy about the supreme truth, that truth is absolute, saying that the Prime Minister should not have on the front bench someone who he asserts is a liar. But when he has pointed out to him that he has an acknowledged liar, he says, `Oh, that.' There is no move to take him off the front bench. Let me go to a couple of recent instances about the Leader of the Opposition's penchant for the truth and his obsessive interest in absolute truth. On AM on 25 August he was asked this by Fran Kelly:
And what about Carmen Lawrence and John Howard though? Did you have any hand in urging Richard Court to do this?
Did you have any hand in urging Richard Court to do this?
. . . I have said to you that the initiative for establishing a Royal Commission came from Court. I've said that to you and there's a very good history for it. But . . .
And you thought it was a good idea?
. . . look. . . the Royal Commission has been established. It was his initiative to establish the Royal Commission, absolutely his initiative, and that was his decision. . .
Mr Speaker, on 18 April, before it was clear we were going to have a royal commission, Mr Liebmann asked the member for Chisholm:
Okay, but Richard Court keeps threatening to call a state parliamentary inquiry, but he hasn't. Doesn't that say something to you?
Well, it says that we've been liaising with Richard Court, we've been looking for the best way to do it.
So, Mr Speaker, here's the truth serum addict opposite, talking about how—

PARA.TAB: Mr Howard interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The Leader of the Opposition!
—Let me get these lines because I think they bear repeating—
—You had better get Don Watson's lines too.
—Order! The member for Gippsland!

ANSWER.PARA: . . . the very simple principle that truth is absolute, truth is supreme, truth is never disposable. . .

But when asked on a radio program whether the initiative for it came from Court, whether he thought it was a good idea, he said that the royal commission had been established, that it came from Court's initiative, ignoring the fact that Mr Wooldridge had already said that his opposition had been liaising with Richard Court and looking for the best way to do it. Now, we ask you this, John Howard: tell us the truth about this—if you can.

PARA.TAB: Mr Speaker, let me go to another recent example of the Leader of the Opposition's penchant for the truth. He said recently that he rejected the notion that he had associated himself with the legislation of the Western Australian Liberal Party in respect of industrial relations. He said this at his speech on 28 July in Perth:

ANSWER.PARA: He made this clear on that occasion. Graham Kierath put the lie to it in the West Australian on 17 August. Rejecting speculation that the federal coalition was pressuring him to delay or change his industrial plans on the second wave, he said he had outlined his proposals to Mr Howard a few weeks ago and that Mr Howard had supported the plans wholeheartedly. Mr Speaker, here is the drift of the press—

TALK.START.PARA: —You are the one who is drifting. You have yet to prove I am a liar.
—Order! The Leader of the Opposition in this place is given some leeway—
—And so is the Prime Minister.

—Indeed, so is the Prime Minister. If you keep on interrupting you are only giving the opportunity, I am sure, for the Prime Minister to respond. I ask you to sit there and observe the standing orders.

—Mr Speaker, you've got the front page of the Financial Review on 31 May, `Draft laws penalise federal switch for WA unionists'. You then have, `Kierath plans flawed says group', and that is the Western Australian Chamber of Commerce saying it is unworkable.

—Mr Speaker, I raise a point of order under standing order 145: the questioner was asking whether the Prime Minister required the truth of his ministers. So far the Prime Minister has not addressed that issue. In the interests of one of his own backbenchers who asked the question, I would ask you if you would get him to get back to the answer.

—Order! There is no point of order. As I have said, if the Prime Minister were not constantly interrupted, I am sure the answer would be concluded much earlier. The Prime Minister has the call and will be heard.

—Mr Speaker, it is very clear that this had been put into the press before the Leader of the Opposition went to his WA party conference, where he repeated his support for it. He then has Mr Kierath saying that he outlined his proposals to Mr Howard and Mr Howard supported the plans wholeheartedly. Then Mr Howard tells the federal parliament in a personal explanation:

ANSWER.PARA: The truth is that I said no such thing. I have never associated the federal coalition with any so-called new or second wave industrial laws in Western Australia.
This is his claim. Last Friday's West Australian confirmed Mr Kierath's earlier remark. Mr Kierath said:
He (Howard) said, `What constitutes a second wave are things the coalition feels very strongly about and agrees with wholeheartedly.'
So you have got the state minister in Western Australia saying in the West Australian on 25 August:
He (Howard) said, `What constitutes a second wave are things the coalition feels very strongly about and agrees with wholeheartedly.'
It was also in the West Australian earlier. Then we also saw it in the Western Australian Chamber of Commerce and Industry report, which says:
Mr Howard praised the industrial relations policies instituted by the WA Liberal government and promised to develop a similar environment at the federal level.

You have got the Western Australian coalition minister saying that Mr Howard endorsed his policies. You have got the Western Australian minister rebuking him—clearly against the references that he has made in the House of Representatives seeking to distance himself from these remarks. You have got the printed reports of this Western Australian minister's view in the Western Australian media.

PARA.TAB: Here are two instances. First, he says that he had no hand, act or part in drafting the terms or being part of the royal commission in respect of this petition in Western Australia. His shadow Attorney-General contradicts him and says that in April they were in touch with the Western Australian government and that they were working on it. Then you have got him saying in the federal parliament that he has no truck with the Western Australian industrial laws. You have got the Western Australian minister saying that he endorsed them.

How much more of this unctuous nonsense are we to take—this stuff about asserting the very simple principle that truth is absolute, that truth is supreme, that truth is never disposable? Come off it! This man has been stretching the truth now perpetually—week in and week out. Mr Speaker, need I go again to the lies, lies, lies—

TALK.START.PARA: —No, no. Order! The Prime Minister will put that away.
—Can I just go back a little bit in history. There is also one that he told on Friday; he told another one on Friday.

PARA.TAB: Opposition members interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The House will come to order.
—He had a real blow-out last week. On Friday he had a lie blow through. He wanted to clean out the pipes of his conscience.
—Time! Time!
—How much longer?
—Order! The Prime Minister will wait just a moment. The House will come to order. I would invite the Prime Minister perhaps to bring his answer to a conclusion.

—Catching up with his untruthfulness requires an account of the summary record. He is a little beauty; he is a little trimmer at it. But his last big whopper on Friday was to say—this is not a recent characteristic of him; this goes back in time—that he found out about the $9.6 billion the day before the 1983 election.

PARA.TAB: Opposition members—Oh!

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The Prime Minister has the call.
—Yes, he is an accomplished liar of longstanding.
—Withdraw!
—Order! The Prime Minister will withdraw that.
—He is an accomplished teller of untruths of longstanding.
—He didn't withdraw.
—Just a minute! The Prime Minister will withdraw that first comment.
—I withdraw. He is a distinguished teller of untruths of longstanding. He said—
—On a point of order, Mr Speaker—
—Order! The Prime Minister might just wait for a moment once more.
—Mr Speaker—
—I have a point of order, and when you sit down you will hear it.
—The member for Flinders on a point of order.

—In furtherance of your earlier comments to the Prime Minister inviting him to wind up his answer, I believe he is flagrantly abusing that direction to him. He has been on his feet now for 12 or 13 minutes. He is back 13 years. You ought to require him now to abide by your instruction.
—Order! I am sure the Prime Minister is winding up.
—I come to this point—I am. He said—
—Oh, Mr Speaker.

PARA.TAB: Opposition members interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Well, if you would shut up for a second I will get it out.
—Order! He is not being helped by those on my left.

—He said he had been told on the preceding Monday, not the Friday he mentioned last Friday. He had been told on the preceding Monday—that is, five days before a national election. When the budget deficit had doubled, five days before a national election, he sat on the information, and he is talking about absolute truth.

PARA.TAB: Opposition members interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! Those on my left!

—When asked, he said he had not disclosed the figures for `hardly surprising reasons'—hardly surprising reasons like telling the truth would disadvantage him electorally in the last week of an election campaign. He sat on information for five days, a critical five days of a national election campaign, when he new the budget deficit was doubling.
—Oh, come on, Steve; wind him up.
—Order! The member for Ballarat!
—He expects us to cop this nonsense about absolute truth and honesty in politics and truth being—

—Mr Speaker, on a point of order; I remind you of the ruling and admonition you issued on 9 May last year, 1994, with regard to the length of answers by ministers and the Prime Minister. You have twice invited the Prime Minister to finish his answer. I ask that you order him to do so forthwith.
—The Prime Minister has indicated he is winding up and he is.
—Oh, ha, ha!
—The Prime Minister is winding up.
—The two points recently and the third answer on Friday—whether he was involved in the establishment of the royal commission and its terms—
—Is this winding up?
—Order!

—On the IR connection in Western Australia and now the false trail he laid about his record back in 1983—mean that the Leader of the Opposition as recently as last Friday on three occasions told clear untruths. Let us hear no more unctuous nonsense and drivel—
—You will hear it.
—Order!
—About truth in politics, absolute honesty in politics. Let us hear no more of that while he has an accomplished liar sitting on his front bench.
—Mr Speaker—
—Just take a deep breath.
—The member for Bass is really delirious about that answer.
—She normally laughs on cue.

—Order! The Leader of the Opposition from time to time does try my patience in this place. I give him the benefit of the fact that he is in a leadership position, but I ask him, once again, to adhere to the standing orders.

—I inform the House that we have present in the gallery this afternoon the Chairman of Kuwait's National Committee for the Missing and POWs Affairs, His Excellency Sheikh Salem Sabah. On behalf of the House, I extend to him a very warm welcome.

PARA.TAB: Honourable members—Hear, hear!

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: Minister for Human Services and Health

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Human Services and Health, and I remind her of standing order 145. Does the minister recollect having said that, if the government's electoral standing were to be damaged as a result of her digging in over the Easton affair, she would, for the good of the Labor Party, stand down as a federal minister? Given that some of your senior colleagues are briefing journalists that the government is suffering and you should stand aside and that caucus pressures on you are increasing, when will you honour your commitment and stand aside?

—I am sure that the people of Australia would be impressed to know that you are concerned about the fate of the Labor Party. I am sure you are not. I am sure members opposite would be delighted if we were going backwards in the polls, but we are not. The standing of the Prime Minister is improving. The standing of the Labor Party is improving. Indeed, in recent days on ABC radio—and I will not name the journalist because it is a bit embarrassing—a journalist said that in Western Australia, in particular, Mr Court's approval rating is plummeting and you are doing worse than you are anywhere else, generally speaking—
—You are doing nothing to help.
—Order! I warn the member for Sturt.

—The falling stocks of the Liberal Party in Western Australia were partly a result of the Crichton-Browne affair and partly due to my involvement in the royal commission—a bit problematic really given that our standing is going up. I remind members opposite that what is happening in the royal commission is what is happening to you in Western Australia. It comes from the same source, the same cesspool of malice, and you will be dragged down by it too.
—My question is directed to the Prime Minister. Can the Prime Minister advise the House of the results of the recent visit to Australia by General Secretary Do Muoi of Vietnam?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Keating The Hon P.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The visit to Australia by the General Secretary of the Communist Party of Vietnam, Mr Do Muoi, from 29 July to 4 August, was an important one by any measure. Mr Do Muoi is the most significant political figure in Vietnam. He has presided over a dramatic opening of that economy, which has seen it grow by around nine per cent and develop a private sector which now accounts for 70 per cent of economic activity. It is a country of 70 million people in which Australia has now invested around a billion dollars.

PARA.TAB: Mr Do Muoi's visit was the first he had ever made outside of Asia. He was accompanied by the Executive Vice Premier, Phan Van Khai, who, we are told, is a possibility of becoming the next Prime Minister. It was the most important delegation ever to come to Australia from Vietnam.

The business group which accompanied Do Muoi was sponsored by three of Australia's most respected companies: BHP, Telstra and the ANZ Bank. All have major current or planned investments in Vietnam. On 28 July, Vietnam became the seventh member of ASEAN. On 11 July, it finally normalised relations with the United States. The General Secretary's program in Australia covered power generation, alumina refining, coalmining, telecommunications, dairy farming, shipbuilding and tourism. Mr John Prescott, the managing director of BHP, had 80 minutes with him in Hanoi a week before he came to Australia.

As is usual with such visits, the Leader of the Opposition was asked whether he wanted to meet the visitor and to support my speech of welcome at the official lunch. But, in an unprecedented snub, the member for Bennelong and his colleagues refused to receive Do Muoi and refused to send a frontbench representative to the official lunch. So far as protocol records show, this is the first time any Australian opposition has taken such a stand.

You have to ask: why did they do it? Was it because of some refined diplomatic sensitivities about him not being a head of government but rather a head of the party? If it was so, why, then, did Mr Howard see Hu Yaobang, who was General Secretary of the Chinese Communist Party, when he came? Why was Mr Do Muoi not received as other friendly governments have received him, including in Japan and New Zealand a couple of days before he came to Australia?
The shadow foreign minister, who also refused to see him, went on a visit to Vietnam as part of a parliamentary delegation. That delegation, the parliamentary consultative mission, said:

ANSWER.PARA: . . . there has been a gradual relaxation of political control over private behaviour . . . in Vietnam.

Its first recommendation was that Australia should continue its high level of engagement with Vietnam so as to further encourage change, both political and economic. It is true that the opposition have had problems with Vietnam, of course. Honourable members will recall that earlier this year the member for Mayo claimed in a press release that he had raised human rights issues during a meeting with the visiting foreign minister, Mr Cam. In an unprecedented response, the Vietnamese Embassy issued a formal denial that the issue had been discussed at all.

PARA.TAB: We get down to the real reason the Leader of the Opposition snubbed Do Muoi. It was because he thought there were a handful of votes in western Sydney and Melbourne amongst the Vietnamese community, for the same reason that he told those young people at St Joseph's College he would oppose the export of uranium to France—telling anyone he speaks to at any time that which they want to hear, as he told the Vietnamese community he would not see him. That is what was wrong.

Their policies are wrong. They are wrong for Australia and, worse than that, they are completely gutless. Let me make this clear: there is no doubt that the Leader of the Opposition has damaged, probably irrevocably, the Opposition's own capacity to deal with this and the next generation of Vietnamese leaders. Those who have been snubbed in this way will not easily forget.

This is from the Leader of the Opposition who wants the stewardship of Australia's policy in Asia. This is the person who says, `Don't have Keating and the Labor Party; have me. I believe in the monarchy, I believe in re-fighting the Vietnam war.'
Opposition members—Ha, ha!

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! Those on my left.

—Two days after Do Muoi left here, he received the United States Secretary of State in Hanoi. It was good enough for the US Secretary of State to meet Do Muoi; it was good enough for Jim Bolger to meet Do Muoi; it was good enough for me—but not for the Leader of the Opposition. This is the person who has the keys, he said, to the Asia relationship with Australia.

PARA.TAB: You can imagine what is thought by those inside of ASEAN who are going to sit down with Mr Do Muoi as a full partner. They are saying, `What's happening back there in Australia? We've got an opposition leader down there; they're basically re-fighting the fights of the 1960s, still have their heart back in the relationship with the monarchy in Britain, have no part of this, have said that the native title legislation was a day of shame'. And they are saying, `And not only that, they'll snub and not even meet one of our partners, a full member of ASEAN.'

After the government of Japan has received Do Muoi and after others in the region have, including China, what are they to say about Mr Howard's potential as the steward of the Australian relationship in Asia? They will say it is—this is an expression I have used here before—obscurantism, pre-Copernican obscurantism, nonsense. Mr Speaker, what could you expect with the whole sense of Australia's place in Asia—
Mr Filing interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The member for Moore.
—Every time this issue of multiculturalism has been raised, he always has a little fly at it. When he talks about one Australia, as some commentator said recently, he really means one Wollstonecraft.
—Mr Speaker, I raise a point of order. Under standing order 85 as to irrelevance and tedious repetition, I ask you to draw the Prime Minister's attention to the defects in his answer.
—The Prime Minister is being entirely relevant to the question that was asked.
—I am trying to put him out of his misery, quite simply, Mr Speaker.
—Resume your seat! I remind the honourable member for Warringah of the ruling given by the second Deputy Speaker in this place about taking spurious points of order.
—Australia was lucky that it was not marginalised by the White Australia policy, as South Africa was.
—It was your policy. Labor policy!
—Order!

—It was 20 years ago. We cannot turn our back on this Asian relationship at this point in Australia's history and not carry it through, not make the integration with the region. But to have the Leader of the Opposition refuse to see the most powerful person in Vietnam, to snub him and to not send someone to his lunch, all because he thinks he might pick a couple of votes up in western Sydney from those who remember the Communist Party of Vietnam unfavourably, it gives Australians some indication that, if this man were ever to be Prime Minister of Australia, it would be curtains to Australia's relationship with Asia, curtains to Australia's growing integration with the region and to the sort of relationship the Foreign Minister and I had last week with the Japanese counterpart ministers in the AJM meetings.
