All of that would go up the flue in the obscurantist views of the Federal Opposition.

PARA.TAB: Let us record again how unsuited to high office J.W. Howard is, particularly in respect of this important question of Australia's future, its place in Asia, its long running interest in the region, with the short-sightedness and foolhardiness of his current policies.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: Minister for Human Services and Health

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Prime Minister. I ask the Prime Minister: since you have just stated that telling truth is required of your ministers, is your position still that you will stand by your Minister for Human Services and Health, regardless of any adverse findings by the Marks royal commission?

—The Marks royal commission, first of all, has very limited terms of reference and very curious behaviour. Today they have refused the minister admission at a time when the giving of her evidence would advantage the commission and the public debate.
—That is her fault; she tried to stop it.
—Order!
—It is being run in a fashion which gives no confidence to this side of the House, particularly as the shadow Attorney-General has made clear that he had his sticky fingers in the terms of reference—
—The shadow Attorney-General?
—The member for Chisholm, I am sorry, had discussions with the Court government about the terms of reference. He said, `We're looking into how we'll do it.' That is what you said.
—I said I was `liaising'. That is different.
—I will get it out. It says, `We've been liaising with Richard Court.' Is that clear or isn't it?
—So what?
—So what? For someone with the morals of an alley cat, that is what it means.
—The Prime Minister might just withdraw that comment. It will assist the House, and then we can get on with it.
—I will withdraw it to emphasise the `So what?' comment he made. Then he goes on to say, `We've been looking at the best way to do it.'
—To do what?

—To establish a commission of inquiry against a political opponent. What are you saying by implication in your question? These terms of reference are narrow and confined, but let us record this: which was the first political party to breach the Family Law Act and bring this matter of the Easton marriage and its affairs to the state parliament of Western Australia? Richard Court and his Liberal Party. None of that is in the terms of reference—not any of it. Richard Court, Mr Masters, Mr Lightfoot and the others are the people who brought it in. Yet the terms of reference are cast only around this petition when the other side of the marriage, Mr Easton, has had—as is his right—a member of the Legislative Council of Western Australia present a petition. I do not know whether members in this place understand that, if a constituent comes to a member with a petition, it is the right of the constituent to have it presented.
—Even if it breaks the law?

—On that very point, there was also a Liberal Party inquiry with the presentation commission into whether there was a breach of privilege of the Western Australian upper house, and they found in the negative. There was no breach of privilege. So the other half of the marriage brings this matter of the petition, yet the royal commission is only about that and not about the fact that Richard Court brought the matter.

PARA.TAB: Just remember this: these people separated on 24 July 1986. On 31 July 1986—exactly seven days later—Richard Court is raising their affairs in the parliament in a five-page speech. Then on 25 November 1986, four months later, in a 14-page speech—14 pages of Hansard—Richard Court raises the affairs of this family in breach of a Family Court order.

TALK.START.PARA: —No, he did not.
—There it is. One week after the separation, he is into the parliament raising this issue.

—Mr Speaker, I rise on a point of order. The standing orders are quite clear: in dealing with a question, the material must be relevant. What is being dealt with here by this man—whose sanity I have questioned once before—
—No. The member for Mackellar will resume her seat. The Prime Minister is being entirely relevant to the question that was put to him.

—So here we are with these narrow terms of reference and—narrow as they are, confined as the processes of the commission are, contorted as they are—the Leader of the Opposition wants to condemn the minister without giving her the opportunity to put her view or her evidence. He then, by implication, wants me to disown her—while at the same time accepting into his breast an acknowledged liar. So I hold the question and all of its imputations, of course, in utter contempt.
—Mr Speaker, on a point of order: can we have those documents tabled? I think we will not find they read the way he said they did.
—Does the Prime Minister wish to table some documents?
—No.

—My question is directed to the Attorney-General. I refer him to the measures in the government's recent Justice Statement to expand access to adolescent mediation and family therapy services in rural and regional areas. What has been the response in the community to the government's decision to substantially increase support for these services?

—I thank the honourable member for his question. I am certain all members of this House are concerned about the issues of youth homelessness. I am sure many members have also received representations from time to time about this issue and the operations, say, of the youth homeless allowance, and there have been inquiries into that particular payment.

PARA.TAB: The Justice Statement attempts to direct measures at maintaining the family unit at the difficult time, which often occurs in many families, of adolescence where the level of communication between parents and their teenage children may be at its most difficult and where there is a potential for problems to arise which could, unfortunately, lead to children leaving the home.

The government currently funds 11 adolescent mediation and family therapy services throughout Australia. All but one of those are located in capital cities. The Justice Statement proposes to expand these services quite dramatically by the provision of $3 million over a four-year period. This will enable the services to move outside the capital cities into regional and rural parts of this country. Advertisements have already been placed in major newspapers for the first of the services, advertising the availability of funds. Well over 100 applications have been received for the expansion of these services.

It is hoped that we will see about 15,000 families assisted annually through these government funded services. Even if only a small proportion of those services maintain the family unit to enable parents to work through with their teenage children particular problems that that family may be going through and as a result we keep that family together and we do not have young teenagers leaving home, I think it is a very worthwhile endeavour.

The community response to the program has been very strong. I assure the honourable member that the government will be moving as quickly as it possibly can to establish these very worthwhile services beyond Australian capital cities so that as many families as possible can benefit from the provision of adolescent mediation and family therapy services.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Prime Minister. Does he share the view that the Chinese nuclear tests are somehow more acceptable because they are being conducted in China's own backyard? Is he satisfied that the Chinese people have made an informed and democratic choice to have these tests conducted in their midst? Why won't the parliamentary delegation led by the honourable member for Kingston, Mr Bilney, also visit Beijing to voice our protest against nuclear testing there? Are the environmental and health dangers posed by the Chinese tests as serious as those posed by the French tests or are the Chinese detonations somehow radiation free?

—I am not sure what imputations the honourable member is trying to make. Does he think that the French tests are somehow relatively less objectionable? Is that the point he is trying to make? The government has always said right through this is that it is opposed consistently to French testing in the Pacific. You haven't. Your side of politics—the party you used to belong to—has supported French testing and refused to sign the treaty of Rarotonga, which was the treaty of the Pacific island states which opposed testing of nuclear weapons in the Pacific.

PARA.TAB: The Leader of the Opposition, in an apologia for his own craven support of these things in the past, said, `Oh, that was before the Cold War finished', as if the state of the French nuclear arsenal had much to do with the Cold War by the middle of the 1980s. The objection that the government has always had to the tests by France is, firstly, that it is by a democracy.

TALK.START.PARA: —So China's are democratic tests?

—No, it is an affront to every nation—a greater affront when a democracy like France decides that it will test not even in its own metropolitan area but in a part of the world it has had the privilege of having stewardship of. That is in contravention of the wishes of people who live in that area and in flagrant disregard of the long-terms risks that might come from it. The interests of democracy these days should be against the proliferation of weapons.

PARA.TAB: We know there is already in terms of these defence forces a stock of competent weapons in the hands of the United States, France, Britain and Russia. The risk today is now proliferation of weapons; it is the proliferation risk. It is that which France offends by saying to all the would-be proliferators, `Don't worry. We're still having a few bangs ourselves.' That is the problem with it, as well he knows.

And here is France, which is now ringed by 14 nuclear reactors of identical design to the Chernobyl reactor which have inherent design faults, which are poorly operated and which present a genuine health threat and risk to western Europe. Instead of concentrating on dismantling those reactors and replacing them with light water reactors, safer reactors or coal-fired stations, what is it doing? It is worrying about the fact that it suffered the ignominy of the Nazis marching through Paris in 1940.

That is what this is all about: that that will never happen again. `Let us have a bigger bang at Mururoa to make it clear that it will not happen again' is what this is about, rather than France engaging the rest of world on things that really matter—that is, stopping the diversion of nuclear materials, stopping scientists from the old Soviet selling their wares around the world, stopping some of the smaller nations like Pakistan, Iraq and others from developing weapons and making certain that there is not a diversion of these materials. That is the objection.
The other objection of course is to China. We have made it as clear as day for a long period—every time—that we object to China testing nuclear weapons. But at least its tests are on its own soil.

TALK.START.PARA: —Oh, they choose to, do they?

—What is that—a commentary on Chinese democracy? What do you want me to do—talk about the rise of the Chinese Communist Party in the 1940s or something? What does that invoke from me—a little case study about the Chiang Kai-Shek and how it should not have happened? One thing is for sure: if the Liberal Party treats Jiang Zemin and the current leadership of China in the way in which it treated Do Muoi of Vietnam recently, their influence in that country will be exactly where their influence is with Vietnam—zero.

PARA.TAB: As far as we are concerned there will be no discrimination in treatment by us. We are flatly opposed to the further testing of these weapons. It is unnecessary. We will say that wherever we have the opportunity. We will make our protest as fierce with the Chinese as we have with the French.

When I did an interview with Liberation the editor said, `Don't you know this is French territory?' I said, `Oh, yes. There are Polynesians all the way down from Aix-en-Provence and Carcassonne. They pop out of the woodwork in the Loire Valley. They are doing Polynesian dances in the back end of the Loire Valley, in the walled city of Carcassonne, in the lovely humidity of Aix-en-Provence. There are Polynesians everywhere.'

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Human Services and Health. Could the minister advise the House whether the government is going to subsidise the use of the high cost drug pulmozyme for the treatment of cystic fibrosis?

—This is a matter which members have apparently had a considerable interest in, since I have had a lot of letters from members on both sides of the House and indeed from a great many constituents representing cystic fibrosis sufferers. I am sure that members will be aware that this is a disease that is genetically inherited. It impairs the functioning of people's lungs and often causes premature death and a great deal of suffering in the meantime. So anything that can appear to relieve symptoms is obviously going to be seized upon and I recognise that cystic fibrosis sufferers and their parents are desperate to try any new treatments that appear to work.

PARA.TAB: There has been a very substantial campaign waged, but this decision has to be made on the basis of science—basically, whether it does in fact provide significant clinical benefits to the majority of patients. If we are to list it on the pharmaceutical benefits scheme, it really does need to demonstrate that it is better than the existing remedies. To date the Pharmaceutical Benefits Advisory Committee, which advises government on these matters, has decided that the drug does not and has asked the company Roche to provide further information about whether there might be subgroups of patients who would benefit. That information is apparently to be provided to the PBAC later this week so that they can assess whether there are some circumstances in which pulmozyme might be made available to cystic fibrosis sufferers.

I have said to the pharmaceutical companies recently that it is most important, if they are to get drugs listed, that they do the science, they do the clinical trials and they provide that information to government. But government is not going to be swayed by campaigns. We have to get the recommendations from expert committees and act accordingly. I understand that Roche in particular has been encouraging the cystic fibrosis associations around the country to lobby to get pulmozyme listed.

As I say, their efforts are better spent providing the data which will convince the experts that it should be listed, rather than lobbying government to make political decisions in these very important and sensitive areas. I hope they will now provide the data that the committee has asked for. Other countries have also been slow to list this particular drug because they have not been convinced of its benefits either. It is up to the company now to provide the evidence.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Prime Minister. The advice of the Solicitor-General of 22 August is that government funds can be advanced for challenges to the Easton royal commission on the grounds that it goes to the issue of Dr Lawrence's continuing fitness for public office as a Commonwealth minister. You have asserted here on Thursday last that the commission is a kangaroo court. This afternoon you have refused to indicate you would abide by its decision. What is the position of your government: that the commission is relevant and you can advance funds or it is not relevant and you have no legal basis for advancing legal aid?

—There is a sort of appalling morality about these questions. This bloke over here has taken giggle gas. He is giggling away. The Western Australian royal commission will cost something like $5 million to $6 million.
—More.
—Probably more. It is arraigned essentially against one woman, whom you deny the right to have representation.
—What is your legal basis for paying her fees?
—Order! I warn the Deputy Leader of the Opposition.
—Oh, you only see it on our side.
—Mr Speaker, he has just had a go at you. Name him; knock him over.
—The Prime Minister will continue his answer.

—Mr Speaker, you say he should have the room that a Leader of the Opposition should have, but he does not behave like one. The view has been in the coalition that it is okay for a royal commission, with narrow terms of reference in which you have had a manipulative role and which the public of Western Australia can shell out $5 million to $6 million at a minimum, to arraign and to look at the motivations—mind you—of somebody who has been involved with, it is alleged, a petition; yet you deny the right of people to be represented there. That is the whole point of it. The record shows always, and it does not matter what royal commission there has been, that the Commonwealth or the states have covered the legal costs of those obliged to appear before it.

PARA.TAB: Mr Howard interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The Leader of the Opposition!
—They are challenging a different thing, are they? Clarence Darrow, the refugee from the suburban solicitor's office—

PARA.TAB: Mr Howard interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The Leader of the Opposition! This is not a debate.

—Can I just say that this matter will be debated at length in the Senate, which the honourable gentleman knows, but the government has, as it always does after 12 years in office, acted with complete authority and propriety in this matter. That will be revealed to you. But what we won't do is take an individual person and arraign $5 million or $6 million and the processes of the state, however corruptly devised, against that person and not give that person aid. That is what you are arguing.
—I seek leave to table the advice of the Solicitor-General of 22 August—
—No, it is not granted.
—Leave is not granted. Resume your seat.
—It's your own legal advice.
—Resume your seat!

—My question is to the Minister for Defence Science and Personnel representing the Minister for Defence. Is the minister aware of calls to support the total ban on landmines? Furthermore, what is the government's response to those calls?

—I thank the honourable member for Bass for her question. On previous occasions I have spoken to this House about the terrible human, social and economic cost that the misuse of antipersonnel landmines has caused around the globe. On this national day of action it is incumbent upon all of us to remember that and to have a discussion on how we might best go about lessening this problem and ultimately ending it.

PARA.TAB: The landmines that cause the most problems are the long-lived antipersonnel mines. Further, it seems that the bulk of these are being sown in various parts of the world by insurgent forces during largely internal conflicts. That is why this government is very strongly pushing for a ban on long-lived antipersonnel mines and a tightening of the inhumane weapons convention to prevent the indiscriminate use of mines.

Last month I led a delegation from this country to an international conference on this in Geneva. This country committed another $5 million, bringing our total to $20 million since 1989 in the fight against the misuse of landmines. Add to that our specialist human resources that we have thrown at the problem. We were amongst the first into Afghanistan and we were the last to leave. Our people are currently still in Cambodia and Mozambique. As well as the ban on the long-lived landmines, we are urging a ban on all non-detectable mines, a cut-off of the supply of all mines to insurgent groups and to all states which are not party to the convention, and the extension of the convention to cover internal conflicts. We are hopeful, in the lead-up to the coming inhumane weapons convention review by the UN next month, that our position is gaining strength.

On the question of a total ban, the government sympathises very much with those calling for that total ban on landmines. Indeed, last year we supported in the United Nations General Assembly a resolution adopted by consensus that affirmed `the ultimate goal of the eventual elimination of antipersonnel landmines as viable and humane alternatives are developed'. However, the problem is, quite bluntly, that many nations are not prepared to forgo the use of landmines because they see them as legitimate defence weapons in their own national interests. My advice is that only nine countries internationally have indicated that they will support a total ban; the vast majority of those nine, it is important to note, with significant qualifications.

The verification and enforcement issues are very great problems. But it must be said also for Australia that, with our vast amount of territory to defend, the task of protecting vital installations in a conflict would be much more difficult if the Australian Defence Force were denied the use of landmines.

The crux of the matter is simply this: there seems very little likelihood—if, indeed, any at all—that a universal, verifiable and enforceable ban on anti-personnel mines could be achieved in the near future. Any unilateral gesture by this government will simply make more vulnerable Australian lives in any potential future conflict. We believe the government's position addresses the problems of the international proliferation and misuse of anti-personnel landmines in a realistic and cogent manner. We will continue to endeavour to push our view in the international forums in the hope of bringing about a better world for those who, hitherto, have dwelled in populations that have suffered from that misuse of landmines.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: Minister for Human Services and Health

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask a question of the Minister for Human Services and Health. Are you prepared to confirm to the House today the accuracy of the statements you made regarding the Easton affair during your National Press Club address of 13 April?
—You asked that last week.

—Speaking to the point of order, Mr Speaker: a question in similar form was asked but it was not answered. It has long been the practice of this House that when ministers avoid giving answers to questions they are normally asked again, and that extends to prime ministers as well.
—If the Leader of the Opposition is so interested in truth and honesty in politics, let him fire the member for O'Connor.
—Oh, Mr Speaker—what kind of—

—Order! No, no. We have had enough to the point of order. The question last week was a very similar question to which the minister gave a response. I will allow her to give a response to the question put to her today.
—What did you just say to Kim?

—I did not say a word, actually; Kim said something to me, if you want to eavesdrop. As members well know, because members opposite asked the question twice last week, I gave the answer in the parliament last week and I suggest that they refer to that answer.
—You never answered it.
—Why don't you answer it?
—They went out of this place, Mr Speaker—

PARA.TAB: Opposition members interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order!

—I said that I stood by my recollections. I said very clearly that I stood by my recollections. Go back and have a look at the Hansard. These members went out of here immediately and tried to put a spin on my answer to suggest that I had not answered the questions; hence they are coming back again to ask it.

PARA.TAB: Opposition members interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order!
—It is absolutely clear that I stand by my recollections. I said it a week ago, I say it today, and it is in the Hansard. Members opposite, as I said, want to run a parallel inquiry.
—I warn the Leader of the Opposition!

—Not satisfied with taking part in setting up a commission in Western Australia, with narrow terms of reference determined by the Leader of the Opposition and the member for Chisholm, they now want to run one here as well.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: Minister for Human Services and Health

TALK.START.PARA: —I will just add to the answer. I do not know whether the Leader of the Opposition would scrub up too well if we had a committee of inquiry into whether he knew—

Can anybody believe that in an opposition frontbench where the question of the day has been organised with the leader, John Howard did not know that when the member for Barker accused the Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs of disseminating information he knew that to be untrue and false?

—Mr Speaker, a point of order: you have extended a privilege to the Prime Minister to add to an answer, which is not a privilege to get up and make a speech impugning the reputation of whoever you like to impugn—
—Order! Resume your seat!
—I ask you to bring him back to the relevance of the question that was asked—
—Order. The Deputy Leader will resume his seat.
—and you should be stricter on this than you are normally.

TAB.EMPHASIS: The honourable member for Casey thereupon withdrew from the chamber.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Speaker!

—No, I am ruling on this issue. The Prime Minister is perfectly entitled, as the Prime Minister, to add to an answer. Again, I say to members of this place, in terms of the response that comes from ministers, I do not know what they are going to say. I ask him to come to the substance of the question.
—I am concluding on this point—

—On a point of order: as I understand it, I asked a question of the Minister for Human Services and Health relating to a speech she made at the Press Club on 13 April. She, in the view of the opposition, did not answer. The Prime Minister then purported to add to her answer by referring exclusively to matters relating to what—untruthfully, but exclusively—the member for Barker, whose reputation soars above yours, mate, any day—
—And your point of order?
—My point of order is: how on earth can an addition by the Prime Minister about the member for Barker be adding to the answer given by the Minister for Human Services and Health?
—Order! I just said that the Prime Minister had begun his response and I asked him to come to the substance of that matter.

—Mr Speaker, the relevance of it is simply this: the minister has given a very clear answer and she has done so on a number of occasions. But when asked whether the member for Bennelong knew of these sly, snide and deceptive tactics of the member for Barker, he has had no such honesty, no such forthrightness—
—Mr Speaker—
—There is no point of order. Resume your seat.
—No such honesty and no such forthrightness which he demands of the minister. That is my point.
—You are going to let him get away with it?
—The Prime Minister has concluded his response.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Development Cooperation and Pacific Island Affairs. Can the minister explain the status of relations between the government and CARE Australia following the recent audit into its activities and the referral of matters identified in the audit report for legal advice?

—I thank the member for his question. I very much appreciate his work, along with that of the member for Aston, on the committee on the code of practice for voluntary organisations. When I tabled the follow-up audit report into CARE Australia in the House on 11 May, I said then I had accepted the report's recommendation to seek legal advice in relation to two projects—firstly, a food aid project in Mozambique and, secondly, a health care project in Sudan. I had hoped that advice would be available pretty quickly and that, with that, the matter would be finalised one way or the other. In the meantime I took the decision that CARE Australia should receive no new government funding until I had received the legal advice that I had sought.

PARA.TAB: Unfortunately, it is now clear that that advice is not going to be available for some considerable time. That delay implies nothing about the nature of the inquiry or of the advice. It is simply an unfortunate, unforeseen delay. Neither the government nor CARE Australia is interested in anything less than a full and proper investigation of those matters. But CARE Australia must be able to get on with its business of providing humanitarian aid to some of the world's most disadvantaged people.

I am also pleased to note that CARE Australia has taken positive action to address the problems it faced. Mr Tony Eggleton has been appointed as national director of CARE Australia and will take up his position there next week. CARE has restructured its operations, involving closing down state offices and restructuring management, with an increased emphasis on internal audit. AusAID and CARE are engaged in constructive discussions about follow-up action arising from the audit findings and, as well as that, all outstanding funds have been returned by CARE to the government.

Because of CARE's positive actions and the unforeseen delays in finalising the legal inquiry, I have decided that from today normal funding arrangements through AusAID will be resumed with CARE Australia. There are some very important principles of natural justice involved in this. CARE Australia is a fine organisation with a proud record of achievement, particularly in delivering emergency relief and longer term development programs. Its efforts in recent months to restructure and rebuild should not go unrecognised.

Furthermore, this is a situation where it can truly be said that judgment delayed could mean justice denied. Further delay in that judgment, through nobody's fault, and the consequent denial to CARE of government support for its work, could severely affect CARE's capacity to carry on. That is an outcome which nobody wants and which I could not justify. Nor is it in anybody's interest, in Australia or in those countries where CARE is active, for this organisation to continue to suffer from any lack of public confidence in its capacity.

This announcement today that government funding will be restored is a mark of the confidence which I and the government have in the organisation. CARE Australia will have access to funding through all programs for non-governmental organisations which AusAID administers. The situation will be reviewed when I receive the outcome of the legal inquiry and when the auditors, BDO Nelson Parkhill, complete their follow-up audit of CARE, which is scheduled for November. In conclusion, Mr Speaker, may I say that I hope this decision will assist CARE Australia to continue its process of rebuilding and to continue its tremendously important work for poorer people in developing countries.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: Minister for Human Services and Health

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask the Prime Minister: do you accept that the Minister for Human Services and Health told the truth about the Easton affair when she addressed the National Press Club on 13 April?

PARA.TAB: Opposition members interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order!

—Mr Speaker, I have been in public life here for 26 years. This man has left a trail, for 20 of them, slipping and sliding through a criminal evasion of the tax system, budget deficits undeclared—one after the other.

PARA.TAB: Opposition members interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! Those on my left!

—As a consequence, having outlived most of his opponents—politically—and seeing them all off the block, he is back here. He has no less virtue. He is the same old shop-soiled, shop-worn political hack he has always been.

—No, no, because it takes a sensible—
—Order! The Leader of the Opposition!
—You don't tell him that—call him—

—Mr Speaker, where there's no brains, there's no feeling. I could not devastate him. You've got to have sensitivities and sensibilities to be devastated, and he does not have any. Mr Speaker, the minister is entitled to put her views in the Western Australian—

PARA.TAB: Opposition members interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order!
—We'll read it to you.
—You can go and read it now, if you're not careful. The House will come to order. The Prime Minister has the call and he will be heard.

—Mr Speaker, I have shown twice in question time today where in recent times the Leader of the Opposition has grievously misled the Australian public. On wages, he endorses the Western Australian draconian labour programs—he endorses them and then denied in parliament that he so endorsed them after the minister in Western Australia blew the whistle on him, saying that he acknowledged and supported his policies.

PARA.TAB: Then there are the other matters I referred to in respect of the member for Chisholm earlier today. These are the standards of John Howard's opposition. Yet he's got the unctuous front to be up asking me questions about whether I endorsed something the minister said in a long speech to the Press Club—how many months ago?

These things will be tested in this commission if the commissioner provides the opportunity for that to happen. But I cannot say that I have ever seen any more unfairness than about this. Here is this huge mechanism set up at public expense—essentially politically—for no breach. The only law breached here is the federal Family Law Act, which has been breached by the Liberal Party. There has been no other breach of a law, yet a royal commission has been established which will cost probably $5 or $6 million—or maybe more. Yet, the Leader of the Opposition—having himself been involved with the terms of reference and seeking to politically manipulate this thing against an opponent—makes very clear that he will not even see the processes run their course. He wants to try to run the processes of the commission in the House of Representatives under cover of privilege. He would not be so cocky if we had a royal commission into some of his goings on; he would not be.

TALK.START.PARA: —Go ahead. Come on; go ahead.
—You are wrong.
—Order! Those on my left!

—As I said, we would only have to go back to the member for Barker's last little altercation in the House without going back into other things. It is not very often that an opposition asks a minister something it knows to be completely untrue and that fits the minister up with a charge which was serious and grievous and which they knew to be untrue at the time of it being asked. That question was obviously set up with the approval of the Leader of the Opposition. That is the sort of morality on that side of parliament. Do you think I came down in the last shower? Do you think I am going to say, `Oh well, John; I'll give you a serious answer to that'? You are a joke and, worse than that, you are an immoral fraud.

—Since the Prime Minister has not read it, I seek to table in the parliament the speech that the minister did make to the press club, together with the questions and answers on her letterhead, so he can read it overnight.

PETITION.TITLE: Family Law Act
PETITION.PARA: To the honourable the Speaker and members of the House of Representatives assembled in parliament.
The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia draws to the attention of the House the need for changes to the Family Law Act of Australia and to the Child Support Scheme.
Your petitioners therefore pray that the House enact the following changes:

PARA.TAB: 1. That the existing Family Law Act be scrapped and replaced by a more simplified version together with the minimum of rules and regulations necessary.

2. That The Family Court be replaced by a Tribunal and that all matters resulting from divorce and family breakdown be heard before, and determined by a panel, the panel to be made up of persons qualified in matters arising from family breakdown.
3. That legal professionals be barred from appearing before the Tribunal resulting in vast savings to the disputing parties.
4. That a modified fault clause be re-introduced to Family Law primarily designed to discourage adultery and to stop rewarding adulterers at the expense of deserted and innocent parties.
5. That the Child Support Agency be scrapped and replaced by an appropriate administrative procedure within the Tribunal.
6. That apart from cases of exceptional circumstances parental-child access become the inalienable right of all parents.

7. That alternative counselling, (Government funded) be made available through the churches and that much more emphasis be placed on mediation in resolving disputes prior to the commencement of legal proceedings.

PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr Adams (from 406 citizens), Mr Andrews (from 308 citizens), Mr Costello (from 124 citizens), Mr Forrest (from 2,976 citizens), Mr Griffin (from 136 citizens), Mr Halverson (from 350 citizens) and Mr Ronaldson (from 36 citizens).

PETITION.TITLE: Refugee Status
PETITION.PARA: The Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives assembled in Parliament:

PETITION.TITLE: Building Materials
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled:
The Petition of the undersigned shows:

PARA.TAB: We the undersigned citizens respectfully submit our opposition to the announced imposition of Sales Tax of 12% on basic hardware and building products by the Federal Government from July 1 1995. The petitioners note particularly that:

1. This new tax will directly affect ordinary Australians in the form of rising prices of building, maintaining and improving their home and by consequential job losses and company closures in an industry which has faced many economic pressures over recent years.
2. The new tax offers no net benefit to Australia and should be abandoned.
Your petitioners request that the House should not pass this legislation when it is presented and/or work to prevent this taxation measure from being implemented by the current Federal Government.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr Downer (from 401 citizens), Mr Ruddock (from 29 citizens) and Mr Somlyay (from 170 citizens).

PETITION.TITLE: Postgraduate Courses: Fees
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives assembled in Parliament.

PARA.TAB: The petition of citizens and residents of Australia points out to the House the adverse impact of fees for postgraduate courses. Fees:

(i)Are a major barrier to the participation of women, mature aged students, Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander students, and students from other economically, socially and geographically disadvantaged backgrounds in postgraduate education.

(ii)restrict the educational options of students. Students with large HECS debts from their previous education may be inclined to avoid undertaking valuable postgraduate courses, therefore leading to a premature closure of career choices.
(iii)contradict the Government's stated goals of lifelong learning and retraining.

Your petitioners therefore request the House ensure the equitable provision of postgraduate education in Australia's Universities by fully funding postgraduate course offerings and amending the Higher Education Funding Act to preclude the imposition of fees for postgraduate courses.

PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr Adams (from 20 citizens) and Mr Crean (from 34 citizens).

PETITION.TITLE: Information Superhighway
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled.

PARA.TAB: The petition from the undersigned citizens of Australia draws the attention of the House to the grave concerns we hold regarding the dangers inherent in the communications Superhighway, with its potential to corrupt and deprave our present and future society if material containing depictions of indecent or obscene material is not proscribed.
Your petitioners therefore request that in regard to Computer Bulletin Boards the House will frame legislation to ensure that the system cannot be used to:
(1)(a) transmit,
(b) advertise as available for transmission,
(c) possess, objectionable material regardless of intended use.
(2) the definition of `to transmit' includes `to obtain' or `to acquire'.
We further request that the legislation ensure that `objectionable material' means material which in any way
(3)(a) depicts indecent or obscene material

(b) describes, depicts, expresses or otherwise deals with matters of sex, drug misuse or addiction, crime, cruelty, violence or revolting or abhorrent phenomena in a manner likely to cause offence to a reasonable adult person
(c) depict in a way that is likely to cause offence to a reasonable adult a child who is, or who appears to be, under 16 (whether or not engaged in sexual activity)
(d) depicts child abuse
(e) promotes, incites or instructs in matters of crime or violence, or which depicts denigration of religious beliefs
(f) depicts material which is unsuitable for a minor to see or play (definition of `minor' is the same as in the Classification (Publications, Films and Computer Games) Act 1994)

PETITION.PARA: and that the legislation ensure

PARA.TAB: (4) that requests for classification by investigating or prosecuting Authorities shall be completed by the Censorship Board within 60 days, and
(5) provide that proceedings for an offence under section 1.(a), (b) and (c) may be commenced at any time after the material has been refused classification.
Your petitioners also request that all of the above be included in section 85ZE of the Crimes Act 1914.

Your petitioners therefore request the House to enshrine legislation containing the above to ensure that the information superhighway be used to contribute beneficial knowledge which will enrich the lives of all Australians.

PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr Andrews (from 16 citizens) and Mr Filing (from 234 citizens).

PETITION.TITLE: Nuclear Testing
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives assembled in Parliament:

PARA.TAB: This petition of certain residents of the State of Queensland draws to the attention of the House the grave environmental and health consequences arising from the recent decision by the Government of France to resume nuclear testing in the South Pacific.
Your petitioners therefore request the House to note that those petitioners whose signatures appear below:
(a) are appalled at the political arrogance of the recent decision by the Government of France to resume nuclear testing in the South Pacific;

PETITION.TITLE: Nuclear Testing
PETITION.PARA: A Petition to the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives assembled in the Commonwealth Parliament of Australia:
This petition of certain residents of Australia draws to the attention of the House our anger at the recent decision of the French Government to resume nuclear testing in the South Pacific.

Such action threatens the health and environment of Australians and the people of other South Pacific nations. It increases the danger of a return to widespread nuclear testing and weapons development.

Your petitioners commit themselves to not purchasing any French made goods, or services delivered by majority-owned French companies, until the French Government's nuclear testing decision is reversed.
We request the House to call on the Government of the Commonwealth of Australia to continue with the strongest possible condemnation of, and action against, the French Government's decision.

PETITION.TITLE: Croatia
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives assembled in Parliament:

PARA.TAB: The petition of certain honourable citizens of Australia draws to the attention of the House that Croatian armed forces invaded the Republic of Serbian Krajina and displaced Serbs from their ancestral homes where they have lived for centuries.
The undersigned citizens object because:
(1) Croat forces committed genocide during the invasion as acknowledged by the United Nations.
(2) Certain member nations of the United Nations are not taking any action to condemn the Croat aggression on innocent Serbs.
(3) 240,000 Serbs have been and are being displaced, as reported in the international media.

(4) Australian Government recently hosted the visit of Franjo Tudjman, President of Croatia, despite the earlier invasion by Croat forces in Serbian Western Slavonija and pleas by the Serbian community in Australia against the visit.

(5) No aid has been provided to Serbian refugees by the Australian Government despite their recent prompt action to assist the Bosnian moslems to the amount of 3.5 million dollars, considering that Croat aggression on Serbian Krajina has generated the single greatest humanitarian crisis in this conflict, as reported by the United Nations and widely in the media.
Your petitioners therefore dutifully pray that:
(1) the House condemns the Croat aggression on the Republic of Serbian Krajina and Western Slavonija;
(2) the House acknowledges the genocide committed on the Serbian people;
(3) the House urges the United Nations to impose sanctions on Croatia for their aggression and the war crimes committed on fleeing Serbian refugees;
(4) the House recognises the genuine fear of Serbs living under Croat authority as evidenced in World War Two and now by this aggression;
(5) the House urgently instruct the Government to provide immediate aid and humanitarian relief to the Serbian refugees displaced by the Croat aggression;
(6) the House urges the Government to take immediate steps to facilitate the resettlement of Serbian refugees into Australia;

(7) the House investigates all Australians of Croatian background returning to Australia to determine whether they participated, contrary to Australian laws, directly or indirectly in the invasion of Republic of Serbian Krajina and brings them to proper justice.

PETITION.TITLE: Croatia
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives assembled in Parliament:

PARA.TAB: The petition of certain honourable citizens of Australia draws to the attention of the House that Mr Franjo Tudjman, President of Croatia, has been in Australia recently.
The undersigned citizens object against Mr Tudjman's visit because he:

(1) Ordered and/or authorised the attack on the Western Slavonija region, including Jasenovac, on 1st and 2nd of May during which some 4000 fleeing Serbian refugees were massacred by Croatian ground and air forces.
(2) Called on Australian-Croatians to return to Croatia, presumably to be recruited into and to strengthen the Croatian Armed Forces.
Your petitioners therefore dutifully pray that:
(1) the House declares the above act anti-Australian;
(2) the House acknowledge that Mr Tudjman is being investigated as a war criminal by the War Crimes Tribunal for the Former Yugoslavia in the Hague.

(3) the House investigates any Australians of Croatian background who return to Croatia to fight in their war against Serbs and who so doing commit war crimes against innocent civilians, the aged, women and children, and thereby contravene Australian laws.
(4) the House refuse entry into to Australia of any Croatian who has participated in any way in the war against citizens of the Republic of Serbian Krajina.

PETITION.TITLE: Child Support
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives assembled in Parliament.

PARA.TAB: The Petition of the Citizens of Australia draw your attention to the lack of commitment of the "non custodial parent" in child support cases when this parent is of low income or in receipt of benefits from the Department of Social Security. The citizens feel that this "non custodial parent" should be obliged to pay a financial contribution towards the cost of rearing the child/children, whether it only be a nominal amount of $10.00/fortnight.

It is felt that this will make the "non custodial parent" accept some of the responsibility for the child and may assist in stopping many who are known to have terminated their employment in order to become a beneficiary of the Department of Social Security and thereby evade paying child support.
Your Petitioners request the House to consider the above so that the "non custodial parent" cannot neglect the responsibility of their child.

PETITION.TITLE: Noise Management
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable The Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled:
The petition of certain citizens of Australia draws to the attention of the House that:

PARA.TAB: (a) Unacceptable noise levels have been foisted on innocent residents of Sydney, damaging life styles and devaluing property and
(b) the Civil Aviation Authority has been given directives and instructions by the Minister for Transport without regard for aircraft noise and without full regard for safety factors.

Your petitioners therefore pray that the House of Representatives will call on the Government to re-establish the most efficient and safe processes for using all three runways at Mascot for the benefit of the people of New South Wales.

PETITION.TITLE: Postgraduate Courses: Fees
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives assembled in Parliament:

PARA.TAB: The petition of citizens and residents of Australia points out to the House the adverse impact of fees for postgraduate courses. Fees:

are a major barrier to the participation of women, mature aged students, Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander students, and students from other economically, socially and geographically disadvantaged backgrounds in

restrict the educational options of students. Students with large HECS debts from their previous education may be inclined to avoid undertaking valuable postgraduate and undergraduate courses, therefore leading to a premature closure of career choices
contradict the ALP Federal Government's stated goals of lifelong learning and retraining
Your petitioners therefore request the House ensure the equitable provision of undergraduate and postgraduate education in Australia's Universities by:
fully funding postgraduate course offerings and amending the Higher Education Funding Act to preclude the imposition of fees for postgraduate courses
input more public funding into higher education, abolish HECS and stop increasing HECS

PETITION.TITLE: Nuclear Testing
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in parliament assembled:

PARA.TAB: The Petition of the undersigned expresses the widespread community outrage throughout Australia at the decision of the French Government to resume nuclear testing in the South Pacific.

Your petitioners ask that the parliament note and endorse the concerns expressed in this petition and convey to the French parliament in the strongest terms of Australia's opposition to this decision.

PETITION.TITLE: Adult Migrant Education
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives assembled in Parliament:

PARA.TAB: This petition of certain residents of the state of NSW points out to the House that the Government is currently planning to close down the Adult Migrant English Program courses offered by the Adult Migrant English Service (AMES) in the Sydney suburb of Auburn and transfer funding for the programs to a new building in Parramatta, which is also intended to accommodate existing Parramatta based AMEP and DEET programs.
This action would limit access to the program by many residents of Auburn who require English language programs, especially students with children.

It would also result in DEET funded courses offered by the AMES at Parramatta being forced into off-site accommodation, resulting in unequal access to educational resources for the students enrolled in those courses.
Your petitioners therefore ask the House to direct the Department of Immigration and Ethnic Affairs to continue to provide AMES English classes at Auburn with at least the current levels of funding.

PETITION.TITLE: Nuclear Testing
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives assembled.

PARA.TAB: The Petition of the undersigned shows:
We, the undersigned citizens of Australia submit our complete opposition to the announced decision of the French government to resume nuclear testing in the Pacific and require the Government to
(a) join with New Zealand and suspend military cooperation with France, except for surveillance, United Nations and humanitarian activities;
(b) cease refuelling all French non-humanitarian military transit flights;
(c) recall the Australian Ambassador to show the depth of our concern, and to develop in association

PETITION.PARA: with the South Pacific Forum a regional plan of action to embarrass and if possible hinder French nuclear testing, including action in the United Nations condemning French nuclear testing as a gross abuse of colonial power and, along with similar tests by the People's Republic of China, as gross violations of the world environment; and

PARA.TAB: (d) discuss with the USA the possibility of data sharing to remove the public French excuse for the tests.
We wish to register our strongest objections and protests to the decision by the French Government which shows arrogant disregard for the people and nations of the South Pacific.
We now call upon the French Government to abandon any further nuclear testing in the Pacific and to honour the essence of the United Nations Nuclear Non-Proliferation Treaty.

Your petitioners therefore ask that the House take note and endorse the concerns expressed in this petition and convey to the French Government in the strongest terms Australia's opposition to the decision.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Republic of China
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives assembled in Parliament:

PARA.TAB: The petition of certain citizens of Australia, draws to the attention of the House the facts that:
The Republic of China—Taiwan, is a Founding Member Nation of the United Nations, which along with other 50 Nations who met in San Francisco in 1945 to sign the Charter of the United Nations;
The Republic of China—Taiwan, was recognised by a majority of nations until 1979, when the United States' shift of recognition from Taipei to Peking in 1979;

The UN Resolution 2758 passed in 1971 only settled the issue that the Republic of China represented all the Chinese people and did not, in any way, recognise the People's Republic of China's sovereignty over Taiwan;
The Republic of China—Taiwan, is recognised by the International Community in various spheres, for example in Sports and in Trade;

The Republic of China—Taiwan, as an independent identity, has one of the strongest and growing economies in Asia with undeniable international responsibilities as member of the Asian Development Bank, of APEC and of the World Trade Organisation;
The Republic of China—Taiwan, as one of the developed nation of the world, is progressively embracing democratic freedoms for its 21 million people;
The establishment of the People's Republic of China in 1949 did not lead to the disappearance of the Republic of China found in 1912 by Dr Sun Yat-sen;

According to international law, the fact that the Republic of China lost most of its territory and population does not affect its status as a sovereign state, nor its legitimacy as an independent nation;
The Republic of China—Taiwan, in addition to its 21 million people, is regarded by the tens of millions expatriate Chinese as their rightful representative on the international stage.

Your petitioners therefore pray that the House request the Australian Government actively assist the Republic of China—Taiwan, to restore its legitimate recognition as a Nation within the United Nations

PETITION.TITLE: Nuclear Testing
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled.

PARA.TAB: This petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia opposes the testing of nuclear weapons in the Pacific region.
We further note that during WW2 General Charles de Gaulle declared that following the end of the war all French colonies in the Pacific region would be granted independence.

We therefore respectfully recommend that the Australian parliament declare that it will recognise any such nation that declares its own independence and that together we will all oppose French nuclear testing in the Pacific.

PETITION.TITLE: Safe Sex Guide
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled:

PARA.TAB: The petition of certain citizens of Australia draws to the attention of the House that:

(2) We believe that the sex guide encourages dangerous sexual practices which could have serious medical and moral effects.
We call on Minister Lawrence to withdraw her endorsement of this sex guide and for the Prime Minister, Mr Keating, to indicate his disapproval of it.
Your petitioners therefore pray that the House requests Minister Lawrence and Prime Minister Keating to take note of our serious concerns and to act on this petition.

PETITION.TITLE: Safe Sex Guide
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled:

PETITION.TITLE: Austudy

PETITION.TITLE: Family Day Care

The petition of certain citizens of Australia, being—Family Day Care Caregivers and/or Parent users of Family Day Care services,—draws to the attention of the House to

PETITION.PARA: before making any decisions.

PETITION.TITLE: Vietnam: Human Rights
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives assembled in Parliament:

PARA.TAB: The petition of certain citizens of Australia draws to the attention of the House various concerns related to Vietnamese asylum seekers in South East Asia and Hong Kong camps. These are: Firstly, that there is strong evidence that their refugee status determination (screening) by the first asylum countries under the Comprehensive Plan of Action (CPA) was flawed by widespread corruption and/or prejudice by screening and appeal panels, and procedural faults. Secondly, that the UN High Commission for Refugees is not seen to take active nor systematic steps to identify and review wrongly screened out refugees. Thirdly, all asylum seekers are now facing or will soon face forced repatriation against their will, amounting to refugee refoulement in the case of refugees among them. Fourthly, all asylum seekers have for some years now been deprived of basic needs by measures such as closing of secondary and primary schools in camps, cutting of essential medical facilities, and restricting communications with relatives outside the camps, which are seen as designed to coerce asylum seekers to repatriate against their will.
Your petitioners therefore pray that the House

(1) Request the Australian government, as a signatory to the Comprehensive Plan of Action (CPA), to raise the question of whether their screening was flawed by corruption, prejudice, and procedural faults resulting in refugees being wrongly rejected as economic migrants; and to require investigative and remedial actions within the CPA

(2) Request the Australian government to follow up on the UNHCR's admission (as reported by the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs Nick Bolkus to the Senate on 1st February 1995) that there has been corruption in screening in Indonesia, with the view of:

(a) ascertaining why in 1994 the UNHCR replied to Minister Bolkus that it was not aware of any corruption, while prior to that time according to its own internal documents the UNHCR should have been aware of it

(b) requesting the UNHCR to state whether it is aware of any corruption or any other reason why screening in other first asylum countries might have resulted in refugees being wrongly denied refugee status
(c) requesting the UNHCR to take corrective actions, and report same to the Australian government
(3) Request the Australian government to request first asylum country governments to investigate whether there were flaws in the screening of Vietnamese refugees, and to take corrective actions
(4) Request the Australian government to request the first asylum country governments to immediately stop the planning and/or execution of plans for repatriation of non-consenting asylum seekers

(5) Request the Australian government to request the first asylum country governments to immediately stop restrictive measures such as closing of secondary and primary schools in camps, cutting of essential medical facilities, and restricting communications with relatives outside the camps, which are seen as designed to coerce asylum seekers to repatriate against their will

(6) Request the honourable member for Blaxland, Mr. Paul Keating, MP, to consider petitions signed by approximately 24,000 Australian citizens related to this topic that were submitted to his electorate office in March 1995 by the President of the Vietnamese Community in Australia and the President of the Council of Vietnamese Refugee Supporting Organisations in Australia

PETITION.TITLE: Logging and Woodchipping
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled.

PARA.TAB: We the undersigned express our disgust at the decision of the Resources Minister to renew export woodchip licences for 1995.
Your petitioners pray that the House will call on the Prime Minister, the Cabinet and the Australian Government to:

(2) use all other powers available to it to ensure the protection of all 1300 forest areas recommended for exclusion from the woodchip licences by the Federal Environment Minister.

PETITION.TITLE: Logging and Woodchipping
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled

PARA.TAB: The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia points out to the House:

That the ancient and irreplaceable native forests in the South West of Western Australia, and many species in these forests, are in danger of extinction, and that Federal Government intervention is urgently needed to protect our natural heritage.
Your petitioners therefore request the House of Representatives to call on the Federal Government to:

PETITION.TITLE: Kingsford Smith Airport
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives assembled in Parliament:

PETITION.TITLE: Employment: State Forests
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives assembled in Parliament.

PARA.TAB: A petition organised by the Central Queensland Job Creation Association (Inc) draws the attention of the House to the unacceptable treatment of the long-term unemployed.

This available work would be a real boost to employment. We need to give our people an opportunity to earn a living and develop their potential, please change your attitude to those being displaced by mechanisation and technology.

PETITION.TITLE: Uranium

PETITION.TITLE: Nuclear Testing
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives assembled in Parliament.

PETITION.TITLE: Nuclear Testing
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of the Representatives assembly in Parliament assembled.

PETITION.TITLE: Marriage
PETITION.PARA: Your petitioners ask that the House of Representatives should call on the government to:

(2) Marriages of parties within a prohibited relationship are marriages—

PETITION.TITLE: Nuclear Testing
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives Assembled in Parliament:

PETITION.TITLE: Nuclear Testing
PETITION.PARA: Petition to the Honourable The Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives assembled in Parliament:

PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker of the House of Representatives assembled in Parliament:

PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives assembled in Parliament:

PETITION.TITLE: Child Care
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members in Parliament assembled:

TALK.START.PARA: —Ministerial responses to petitions previously presented to the House have been received as follows:

INTERJECT.PARA: RESPONSE TO PETITION PRESENTED TO THE HOUSE OF REPRESENTATIVES ON 29 MAY 1995 BY MR P.M. RUDDOCK MP RELATING TO THE ESTABLISHMENT OF A MEDICARE OFFICE IN THE NEWCASTLE SUBURB OF HAMILTON.

The Health Insurance Commission, which administers Medicare, has developed criteria to determine the need to open new Medicare offices. One criterion for establishing a Medicare office is that it operates efficiently. To operate efficiently it must be able to sustain a minimum volume of 150 cash payments per day.

Of all general practitioner services provided to residents of Hamilton, 75 per cent are direct billed. This means many patients have no need to claim the Medicare rebate. Of the remaining services, 45 cash services are generated daily, well below the minimum required.
As there are Medicare offices located at Newcastle, Kotara, Wallsend and Charlestown, another office in the region could not be justified in the foreseeable future.

Alternative claiming methods are available to people who do not have access to branch offices. Unpaid accounts can be posted to Medicare and a benefit cheque in favour of the doctor will then be sent to the patient's address. Claiming in this manner ensures patients do not need to pay for the total expense of the medical service.
RESPONSE TO PETITION PRESENTED TO THE HOUSE OF REPRESENTATIVES ON 29 MAY 1995 BY HON DR C M LAWRENCE MP
The petition relates to a request that the drug IMIGRAN be subsidised by the Federal Government under the Pharmaceutical Benefits Scheme (PBS).

Under the PBS, drugs and medicinal preparations are made available as pharmaceutical benefits on the recommendation of the Pharmaceutical Benefits Advisory Committee (PBAC). This is the expert body that advises me which drugs and medicinal preparations should be included in the Schedule of Pharmaceutical Benefits.

The PBAC is required to consider both the clinical effectiveness and the cost effectiveness of proposed additions to the PBS. Value-for-money is becoming an extremely important means of making objective decisions about the relative benefits of new medical care.

The PBAC recommended to the Government that, on medical grounds, IMIGRAN is suitable for inclusion in the PBS. However, it expressed its grave concern about the prices being asked by the company, Glaxo Australia, for IMIGRAN products and advised that the high prices could not be justified. Other countries have come to the same conclusion.

To date negotiations are still continuing with the supplier with a view to having IMIGRAN listed on the PBS. This is not an easy situation given the considerable difference in the price the company is prepared to sell for and the price the Government is willing to pay.
The costs of the PBS are finally paid for by all taxpayers and it is essential that prices of benefits are acceptable.
From the Minister for Human Services and Health, Dr Carmen Lawrence, relating to a petition lodged by Dr Carmen Lawrence on 29 May 1995.
