SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Mr R.D.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I cannot match the dramatic appearance of the PLO's Yasser Arafat brandishing a loaded gun before the General Assembly of the United Nations, nor can I match the calibre of Arafat's weapon; however, I can reveal an equally dangerous means of destruction that each one of us—and, in fact, a majority of Australians—has in our own homes: this rather innocuous, almost cheerful, green, user and environmentally friendly weedspray, `Roundup 360', bought over the counter at any local supermarket. But, like Arafat's weapon, Roundup is similar to so many other readily available herbicide products in that it is a killer.

PARA.TAB: This is no idle claim. A recently published report from the Western Australian Department of Environmental Protection clearly shows that Roundup 360 is capable of killing Australia's native frogs and their tadpoles. Roundup 360 is being innocently used to destroy the very fabric of our environment: our native frogs.

This report, the brand name `Roundup' and the death of native frogs are only an introduction to the herbicide jigsaw. In fact, Roundup 360, although the target of this startling report, is only one of the range of herbicide products freely available in all retail outlets across Australia.

These products contain a cocktail of different chemicals, chemicals that have the potential to have a massive destructive impact upon our environment. Roundup 360 itself is made up of two basic chemical agents: a herbicide known as glyphosate and a wetting agent, or surfactant, which assists in plant penetration. It is great in killing weeds, I am told by my colleagues, but a terrible chemical for the native fauna.

Another commonly used product, Yates `Once-a-year Path Weeder', contains three different herbicides; namely, 22DPA, Simazine and Amitrole. Other seemingly innocent herbicides, too numerous to discuss today—one is Zero Weedspray—contain still other herbicides including Atrazine, Flauzifor and Hexaxinone, and almost certainly contain various surfactants as well.

As to the effects of these lethal chemicals on our frogs and, in fact, any other group of native fauna, I was appalled to find that we have absolutely no direct information available—no data, no information, nothing on the impact these chemicals have on native fauna, particularly frogs. But we do know, from laboratory tests on animals such as laboratory rats and ducks, that most, if not all, of these substances are substantially more toxic than the glyphosate found in Roundup 360. As to the wetting agents found in virtually all these mixes, these are also known to have harmful effects in their own right—especially on many creatures using gills for breathing, including native fish.

Personally, I was astounded and very concerned to learn of these facts. I was even more astounded to learn that these potentially harmful effects of herbicides on native animals have been known to the scientific community for more than 20 years. For 20 years we have known that the common herbicides we use in Australia are harmful to our native fauna. This is an absolute disgrace.
For example, an article published in 1977 in the Herperogica, one of the international reference journals of study in this area, stated:

SPEECH.PARA: Further investigations of the effects of herbicides to amphibia are clearly needed.

That is, clearly needed almost 20 years ago. It also stated that in a study undertaken 86 per cent of frogs died after being exposed to a herbicide that was only one-eighth—I repeat: one-eighth—the solution recommended for agricultural spraying at that time in the United States of America. It is interesting to note that in other parts of the world some positive action appears to have been taken as a result of similar research. In the case of Roundup, for example, a report of the Department of Environmental Protection (WA) states:
Much tighter controls apply to the use of Roundup in aquatic environments in Britain and . . . it is no longer permitted to be used in aquatic environments in the USA.

As Australians, how are we supposed to interrupt this information? Are our registered standards lower than those employed in other countries? Is our current government complacently sitting by and watching Australia becoming either a testing ground or possibly, more tragically, a dumping ground for chemicals either abandoned or used with greater caution in other countries? Does the government pay only lip-service to the true meaning of environmental protection?

PARA.TAB: In order to fully appreciate the magnitude of this issue, we need to take stock of herbicide use in Australia. I am not speaking of a few litres of herbicide being used in the backyard; I am saying that Australia uses some tens of thousands of litres of herbicide each and every day, a substantial proportion of which goes straight into the atmosphere or filters through into our soils and waterways.

Over the last two decades herbicides have become an integral part of many primary production industries such as forestry, broadacre agriculture and market gardening. They have become a fundamental tool in conservation strategies, where they are used to control both land based and aquatic weeds. Indeed, I understand that a significant proportion of the limited funds available from federal sources for nature conservation in nature reserves is used to purchase herbicides for weed control.

What an irony—federal funds being used to purchase substances that are almost certainly harmful to our native fauna. Sadly, the people who work in these industries and who participate in these conservation programs in good faith believe that these substances have been tested thoroughly for Australian conditions and are, therefore, perfectly safe to use—and doing no harm at all to any aspect of the environment. How wrong this assumption is turning out to be.

It seems that we have all placed an inordinate amount trust in—well, in whom? To whom do we go to ensure that the products we use are safe and that we are given accurate information on the labels and warned as to any possible dangers to our natural environment?

In an attempt to unravel the bureaucratic tangled web that underpins this appalling situation, I got an unprecedented run-around. The health department put me on to the agriculture department which, in turn, put me back to the health department. I then contacted the Environmental Protection Authority which suggested that I should contact the local council—which, by the way, uses Roundup 360 on street verges in my own electorate and possibly even on the verges in your own electorate, Mr Deputy Speaker. I finally got on to the National Registration Authority which provided a complex suite of information that discussed everything from schedules to warnings, to labels, to legal contracts—all marvellous stuff, but who is responsible?

I must state categorically that I found the people with whom I dealt to be responsible public officers who seemed to perform their duties with efficiency and provided me with as much information as they could. However, there exists a void of accountability in the Labor Party thinking when it comes to the environment on this particular issue. Actually, the current government is void in many areas.

Being a realist, though, I freely acknowledge that the issue of herbicides in our natural environment is a large and complex one which cannot be solved through simple legislative change. Moreover, we must acknowledge that herbicide use may be essential to maintain production in many primary industries and that it has an important role in both domestic life and conservation. However, it is also clear that we need to know more about the effects of these substances on our native fauna, particularly our frogs, so that we can determine the most effective way in which they can be used. A regime of use, perhaps based on accurate information derived from Australian conditions as well as sound management and educational practices, is urgently required.

This is an issue that will test the mettle of the Labor government. If they care—and I suspect that this is a very big `if'—they will need to take some immediate action. At the very least, I call upon the Labor government to promote local Australian based herbicide studies as a priority; to work with industry, conservation groups and the community to ensure that the needs for all groups are met, without unnecessary environmental degradation; to ensure that an effective program of education on herbicides is in place; to undertake a thorough and independent investigation into recognition and labelling standards in use by the National Registration Authority; to promote the effective monitoring of the impacts of herbicides on the natural environment; and to research into other forms of weed control in Australian conditions.

The onus for protection of our native fauna is on the government, as it should be. If they do not do not look after our environment and clean up their act on this particular issue of herbicides, our native fauna, such as our frogs, will be destroyed. I should remind members that the Liberal Party have just these strategies; we have the policies. If they do not do it, we will.

TALK.START.PARA: —The issue of the eastern tollway, which has been proposed as a second road from Brisbane to the Gold Coast, continues to dominate political debate in Queensland. As a local federal member, I have had no direct involvement in this debate up to this time because the matter is a state government decision and, as was evidenced at the recent state election, it is the state government which is responsible and accountable to the people on this matter.

PARA.TAB: Further, it was only a few months ago that part of the area affected was transferred into my electorate as a result of the 1994 federal redistribution. The community of Rochedale, where the eastern tollway commences, is now part of Moreton. In recent weeks my constituents in that community and the neighbouring suburb of Wishart, who would suffer some effects if the tollway proceeds, have expressed their concerns to me about the state government plan and have asked my views on the matter. I believe that it is my duty to examine the issue and to offer my advice to the state government and to my electorate on this question, which will have a direct bearing on the quality of life of many of my constituents.

The starting point for consideration of the issues surrounding the eastern tollway proposal is an acknowledgment that action must be taken to address the problem of traffic congestion on the Pacific Highway between Brisbane and the Gold Coast. Anyone who travels along this highway at most times of the day or evening knows that the road is almost at its private vehicle capacity. At certain key points along the corridor, delays due to congestion are frequent and unacceptably long. I travelled this road regularly for five years, from 1985 to 1990, as union organiser responsible for Logan City and the Gold Coast region for the Queensland Teachers Union. It was significantly congested at times in those years, and the problem has grown considerably in the last five years.

The next question to consider is whether the current proposal to build a second highway east of the Pacific Highway is the optimum solution for the traffic needs of communities living along this corridor as well as for the communities at each end—the southern suburbs of Brisbane and the northern suburbs of the Gold Coast. In my view the answer is no. There are a number of reasons behind my conclusion on which I would like to elaborate.

I do not believe that sufficient analysis has been undertaken by transport officials into alternative strategies for reducing private vehicle usage on the Pacific Highway. Much of the necessity for the construction of the eastern tollway is due to the poorly developed local road network serving the communities along the Pacific Highway. There are only a few roads interconnecting the suburbs of Logan City in north-south or east-west directions with each other or with the communities on the other side of the Logan River. Apart from the Pacific Highway, there is only one bridge crossing the Logan River—at Waterford. Forty per cent of the vehicles on the Pacific Highway between Eight Mile Plains and Beenleigh are local traffic. Seventy-five per cent of vehicle trips in the region are not related to employment or business purposes. For people to move around Logan City communities, they frequently have to use the Pacific Highway for some or all of their journey.

A proper local road structure would significantly reduce the use of the Pacific Highway for local trips and would, therefore, alleviate a sizeable proportion of the congestion. The already purchased corridor for development of the tollway south of the Logan River can easily be converted to form the basis of part of a local road network.

Associated with this problem are the poorly resourced and structured public transport services for these communities, as well as between Brisbane and the Gold Coast. The federal government has made a significant contribution to the development and construction of the new rail link between Brisbane and the Gold Coast. I want to ensure that this important new facility is fully utilised and forms a vital part of the optimum transport solution for the region.

There needs to be an expanded, coordinated and integrated public transport strategy. The Queensland government has announced funding for a $100 million busway system, including a busway system from Southport to Coolangatta. A similar service needs to operate in this transport corridor, with busways linking in with railway stations to connect all local communities with the rail service.

Timetables of local bus and train services should be synchronised, and a one-ticket system needs to be introduced without delay. `Smart signalling' should be incorporated along all roads that are busways so that public transport services do not suffer long delays from traffic signals at intersections.These measures would significantly improve the service and efficiency of public transport and provide a real incentive for people to utilise such services in preference to private vehicles.

Public transport will be an attractive service if it delivers on the problems of time lengths of journeys, reliability, safety and amenity of service. Travellers locked in long traffic jams watching their work colleagues speeding by in a bus along a busway or in a train will soon learn that the perceived advantages of commuting to places of employment in their own vehicles have disappeared. The investment in bus and rail stock, improved ticketing and timetabling, and synchronised traffic signals, is minuscule compared with the costs in social, economic and environmental terms of building more freeways for private vehicles.

There also needs to be further development of the rail link to enable it to provide a dual service between Brisbane and the Gold Coast. The rail service needs to be a fast, reliable and affordable service direct to and from the Gold Coast, linking in with local bus services hubbed at key railway stations. It should also be a local commuter service, transporting workers and shoppers to the various communities along this corridor. The rail service direct to the coast will only compete with private vehicle traffic if it is as fast as, if not faster than, a car.

An express service must be introduced, with stops at Nerang, Coomera and Beenleigh. It should then go nonstop to Brisbane city, with only three to four stops before Central Station in the CBD. Such a service will require the duplication of the track in some areas. The preserved corridor is wide enough to allow a third track north of Ormeau and a second track south to Robina. Further railway stations should be developed for the multistop commuter service, particularly at Yatala, where a growing industrial estate requires service from the railway line. With all of these public transport proposals, I believe there would be a significant easing of current and future private vehicle usage on the Pacific Highway.

One other measure is also needed. The Pacific Highway should be expanded to six lanes as a matter of priority. The highway corridor is wide enough to accommodate such expansion without land resumption or property losses. This would enable a priority vehicle lane or busway to be introduced to improve accessibility and movement along the highway, particularly at peak congestion periods.

Work on the proposed eastern tollway should be suspended immediately. The environmental costs of this proposal in terms of loss of native fauna and flora, of degradation of local communities, and of loss of quality of life along the route are unacceptable. All of the people living in the path of the proposed tollway have made their views abundantly clear, and the state government should heed their message. The alternative is cheaper, more environmentally and socially sound, and will unite rather than further divide these communities.

In conclusion, I sum up my proposal: firstly, widen the Pacific Highway to six lanes from Springwood to Nerang; secondly, build a third rail track to Ormeau to enable an express service to be introduced; thirdly, develop a better local road network to remove local traffic from the Pacific Highway; fourthly, expand and coordinate public bus services and rail services in the region, and introduce synchronised timetabling and one-ticket services; and, finally, introduce busways along major roads and the highway with `smart signalling' traffic signals for free movement of buses. With these measures, there will be no need to consider additional road corridors to the Gold Coast for many years to come, if at all.

TALK.START.PARA: —Too often over the last few decades we have heard people talk about the issues and some of the problems in regional Australia. People simply say, `Well, you choose to live there. That's your problem. Bad luck.' It is a pretty callous and convenient approach when we consider that 70 to 80 per cent of our exports come out of regional Australia. For the privilege of producing this export income, the people in regional Australia end up with the lowest incomes. Whether you happen to be self-employed, on social welfare, in a small business, or an employee, in net terms you end up with a lower income.

PARA.TAB: Let us look at the family in regional Australia. If you have to make use of the Child Support Agency, you do not have access to the central office; you have to wait on the telecentre for up to 30 or 40 minutes before your issue is dealt with. Those dealing with HACCA, the parental allowance which replaced the dependent spouse rebate, know that that involves another penalty for regional people.

If you come to education, you will find, once again, that the percentage of students from regional Australia with a tertiary education is well below the national average. If you look at the school system, many of the regional high schools have at least a 50 per cent turnover rate. Let us just look at Austudy and the number of students going on to tertiary study. It is tough enough these days for families with a student living at home to make ends meet; we all understand that. But, if the student has to go away and live on the living away from home allowance, it becomes very much a matter of survival. So that is another disadvantage for regional people.

We are told in regional Australia that we must adjust—`Adjust or perish; after all, you choose to live there, so that is your problem.' Not only do we have lower employment opportunities, and the higher unemployment that goes with it, but we have studies by the smaller labour market groups which admit that they cannot get on top of the actuality of the issues in regional Australia. We do not even measure the CPI in regional Australia. We do not even understand how the economy might impact on regional Australia.

I just move on to health, even though I do not really have a lot of time. We are told by the current Minister for Human Services and Health (Dr Lawrence) that we have an oversupply of doctors and that there should be fewer people going through university. Yet, in many of the smaller communities of my electorate and throughout Australia, it is very difficult, sometimes impossible, to have just one GP in a community. I wonder how many Australians would think about that for a while and say, `I live in a community without a doctor.'

It is not only a case of whether we are lucky enough to get a doctor, but it also relates to the stability of that service—the changeover and the ability of, say, a young mother who has a young family to develop a relationship of trust with her GP so that when the children get sick she has confidence to know that the child will be cared for. If we can get a GP into that community, we have this constant turnover. It is very difficult for a young family to survive in the confidence of a stable medical service.

I will move on to taxation, which is a pretty tedious subject. I mentioned that we do not even know what the effect of the CPI is in regional Australia. We certainly would not know what the taxation aspect is. We can guess that the fuel tax moved from 26c a litre up to 34c or 35c a litre and what effect it might have on regional Australia where this great export industry is trying to compete with world markets. We might guess what the impact of the wholesale sales tax has been since the government told us that there would not be any increase in taxation. Yet immediately it came to power in 1993 it lifted the wholesale sales tax and it has been steadily lifting it over the last three budgets. We might guess what the impact of the fringe benefits tax might be.

One of the big taxes in the last budget was the wholesale sales tax increase on cars. If you happen to be on a lower income, as I have already said, you tend to reside in regional Australia. Part of that lower income is very much due to the taxation regime of the current federal government. If you have a five to six per cent increase in sales tax—actually it is more like a 30 per cent increase in sales tax, but it is a five point or six point increase in the wholesale sales tax on cars—imagine how difficult it is to buy that car that might have to last you a decade.

Regional development is the catchcry since Kelty discovered regional Australia in recent times. He pioneered that great expedition out of Melbourne and found his way around Australia. It was a wonderful effort, Bill. Do you know what he said about the indirect tax system? He said it is too difficult and we cannot solve it. One of the greatest impacts on the standard of living of regional Australians is the indirect tax system, particularly the fuel excise. I keep coming back to the fact that we do not even measure the CPI in regional Australia. But if you choose to live there, bad luck.

I will quickly touch on services and mobile phones. Today I tabled a petition with 1,600 or more signatures. We were not even thinking about it. We left it to three big operators. They were so flat out looking after the urban community, they did not even think about the smaller community or even highway 1, where perhaps you would get a reasonable return. What about SBS? Some of the bigger cities are getting it, but what about Port Lincoln and places such as that, which would be numerous around Australia? Triple J? No way. It might come in in some of the cities in 12 months. What about STD rates? Every time you use a telephone in the region you pay STD rates to go outside your own community. Even in some communities you have local timed calls. It is political rhetoric.

TALK.START.PARA: —And don't you know it.

—Exactly. We need a spirit and a vision which shows far greater respect for our country and for our regional areas. No-one epitomises that more than a fellow by the name of Ian McNamara of Macka on Sunday, one of the great programs on the ABC. What a pleasure to listen to him actually speak up and stick up for regional Australia. We need all the advocates we can get. It is a little different from the stuff that Mungo MacCallum used to peddle about the whingers from regional Australia. I understand that Mungo now lives in regional Australia. I wonder whether he has changed his attitude.

PARA.TAB: I turn to the environment—the great catchcry over the last decade or so. Who actually lives with the land of this country? Regional Australia. Who has taken the initiative over the last 50 years in conservation? Regional Australia. Who was part of the pioneering in land care? Regional Australia. Where do the Aboriginal people predominantly live? They live in regional Australia.

This urban dominant culture has much to answer for. The lowest quarter of the electorates in Australia by income are mainly represented by the coalition and all but two are in regional Australia. The time has come for a far greater respect for the contribution of regional Australia to the economy, to the national life, sport and culture. We must do more for access to education, health, legal services and treatment under the tax system. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Smith Mr Stephen

TALK.START.PARA: —This afternoon I wish to speak about the state of democracy in Western Australia and persistent refusals by the Liberal and National parties in Western Australia to place the Western Australian parliament on a truly democratic basis. This House would be well aware that the Western Australian state parliament is the subject of a massive malapportionment. That malapportionment applies both to the Legislative Assembly and to the Legislative Council. That malapportionment exists and applies today because the conservatives in their modern day guise—the Liberal and National parties—have always controlled the Legislative Council of Western Australia and have refused persistent and repeated attempts by the Australian Labor Party to seek to place the Western Australian state parliament on a one vote, one value basis. Very many attempts by Labor over the years have fallen foul of the Liberal-National domination of the Legislative Council.

PARA.TAB: The malapportionment in Western Australia is quite clear and quite stark. In the Legislative Assembly there are 34 metropolitan seats and 23 non-metropolitan seats—the metropolitan boundary drawn effectively by the Legislative Council. The average enrolment for a metropolitan seat in Western Australia is about 23,000. In the non-metropolitan areas the average enrolment is about 12,000. So you can see the stark nature of the malapportionment which occurs in the state parliament: 34 metropolitan seats, with an average enrolment of 23,000; and 23 non-metropolitan seats, with an average enrolment of 12,000.

In the Legislative Council that malapportionment rings true as well. The Legislative Council is divided into a number of regions—three regions from the metropolitan area and three regions from the non-metropolitan area, with 17 members of the Legislative Council from both the non-metropolitan region and the metropolitan region. An equal number of legislative councillors are elected to the Legislative Council of Western Australia—17 from the metropolitan area and 17 from the non-metropolitan area—and the maths are quite stark. If you want to be a member of the Legislative Council, you are looking at a mathematical equation of 34 by 23,000 and if you want to be a member of the Legislative Council from a non-metropolitan area, you are looking at a mathematical equation of 23 by 12,000.

I have argued repeatedly in Western Australia that the model which the Western Australian parliament ought to adopt is the model which the Commonwealth parliament adopts: namely, in the House of Representatives, a system of one vote, one value and equal enrolment with a 10 per cent plus or minus disparity; and in the Senate, a system of effectively proportional or regional representation.

I will concentrate on the Legislative Assembly model. The royal commission into executive government in Western Australia—commonly known as the WA Inc. royal commission—recommended that a commission on government be established by the state government. The Court state government was most reluctant to embark upon that course, but, after being dragged to the barrier, established a commission on government. One of the terms of reference which the Western Australian royal commission recommended be considered by the commission on government was the electoral system. It is clear that the WA Inc. royal commission saw a clear link between standards of propriety and conduct and the basis of a state parliament's electoral system.

Last week the Commission on Government reported on very many of those terms of reference in a weighty tome entitled Commission on Government: Western Australia: Report No 1: August 1995. It is interesting to see the recommendations that the Commission on Government has made in respect of the basis of the parliament in Western Australia, the composition of the Legislative Assembly and the composition of the Legislative Council.

The commission conducted public hearings. At one public hearing I appeared to speak on the term of reference that relates to the electoral system and argued then, as I argue today, that the model that we adopt for the House of Representatives is the appropriate model for the Western Australian parliament. I refer to the recommendations of the Commission on Government. The commission deals with the Legislative Assembly of the state parliament in chapter 8 of its report. Recommendation 42 deals with malapportionment and vote weighting. The recommendation by the Commission on Government is as follows:

SPEECH.PARA: 1. The present metropolitan and non-metropolitan zones for the Legislative Assembly should be abolished.

2.The quota of enrolled voters for each Legislative Assembly electoral district should be determined by dividing the total State enrolment, projected four years in advance, by the number of seats to be distributed. A plus or minus 15 per cent deviation from the quota should be permitted based on the criteria listed below.

The Electoral Distribution Commissioners, when exercising their discretion over the deviation of plus or minus 15 per cent from the quota, should be required to place the primary emphasis on community of interest as a criterion for the allocation of voters to electoral districts.
Secondary criteria are:
(a) means of communication and distance from Perth;
(b) geographical features; and
(c) existing boundaries of regions and districts, including local government boundaries.

So the clear recommendation of the Commission on Government is that the Legislative Assembly in Western Australia should be determined on the basis of one vote, one value with a deviation from the quota or differentiation of 15 per cent, plus or minus. It is not as good as the House of Representatives model but a massive improvement on the current basis.

PARA.TAB: When the Commission on Government reports on the Legislative Council, which is dealt with in recommendation 52 of chapter 9 of the Commission on Government's report, it formally recommends:

SPEECH.PARA: 1.The present regions for the Legislative Council should be abolished.
2. The five, seven member electoral regions should have numbers of electors in each region determined as follows—

It then goes on to effectively cite the criteria for the Legislative Assembly. The Commission on Government also recommends that, because it is recommending five seven-member electoral regions, the Legislative Council in Western Australia be increased from 34 to 35, which is not something that causes me any great difficulty.

PARA.TAB: At the same time, the Commission on Government recommends that the number of seats in the Legislative Assembly should be increased by four, from 57 to 61. I must say I find this recommendation somewhat bemusing. On my reading of the various submissions just about every recommendation or submission to the Commission on Government was that the number of seats in the Legislative Assembly and parliaments generally ought to be less rather than more.

The conservative response to the commission's recommendation is as we expected: disappointing. Today's West Australian—that is, of Monday, 28 August—under the heading `Cowan firm on voting reform' carries an article which reports the response of the Deputy Premier of Western Australia and the Leader of the National Party, Hendy Cowan, on the Commission on Government's report. The article states:

SPEECH.PARA: DEPUTY Premier Hendy Cowan says he is still unwilling to accept changes to WA's electoral system but a model which allowed electoral quotas to deviate by about 25 per cent might be more palatable to him.

PARA.TAB: Mr Cowan, the leader of the National Party, said his party was happy with the current system of vote weighting—which the body studying post-WA Inc reforms wants abolished.

SPEECH.PARA: The article goes on to say:

PARA.TAB: Mr Cowan said that the COG's recommendation of a deviation of 15 per cent was inadequate.
"They . . . have effectively modified the system we've got, so it can't be all bad," he said.
"I'd say plus or minus 50 per cent is just right but somewhere between the two is a compromise.
"It will be interesting what the National Party would accept; my answer is, at this stage, I wouldn't accept any compromise.

SPEECH.PARA: So the formal position of the National Party leader in Western Australia is that you can have equal voting provided you have a 50 per cent plus or minus differentiation—in other words, no effective change from the current system.

PARA.TAB: In that same article the leader of the state parliamentary Labor Party, Mr Jim McGinty, is quoted as saying that he thought the 15 per cent tolerance suggested by the Commission on Government was probably excessive but `it's so enormously better than what we've got that we would be prepared to accept that'. The article concludes by saying:
Most of the other States had a deviation of only about 10 per cent.

SPEECH.PARA: If I can quote from the body of the COG report, page 274, the commission says:

We believe there is a strong link between the prevention of corrupt, illegal and improper behaviour in the public sector and the electoral system. This view was supported by public submissions to the Commission from across the political spectrum.
That is a clear indication by the commission that the adoption of a sound democratic basis to a parliament is necessary to ensure scrutiny of public standards.

PARA.TAB: Members might be aware that Mr McGinty and others are currently challenging the Western Australian system before the High Court in a case which is due to be heard next month. I call on the Premier of Western Australia to do the right thing and to publicly state that, despite the objections of the National Party, he will implement immediately the recommendations of the COG report and save Western Australian taxpayers the expense of the Western Australian state government defending in the High Court a massively unfair, massively malapportioned and massively undemocratic state parliamentary system, which the Commission on Government, established by Premier Court, says quite correctly ought to be thrown out and thrown out now.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hicks Mr N.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The word `entrepreneur' has been given a rough time lately, particularly when we refer to people like Skase and Bond as being entrepreneurs. The term originated in France and meant `public officials who were in charge of large building projects', and it gradually came to refer to those who take risks. Unfortunately, it has come to refer to high-flying speculators rather than entrepreneurs as defined in economics.

PARA.TAB: In economic theory, an entrepreneur is `one who exploits an economic profit opportunity under the presence of uncertainty'. But I believe it should be confined to individuals who bring new products on to the market and who adopt innovative production techniques knowing there are uncertainties. I think these people are to be encouraged.

It is a known fact that we owe the development of the United States and Australian economies to entrepreneurs. They have given us our present standard of living. Where entrepreneurs do not exist, economies stagnate. Often inventors have to be entrepreneurs because there is no way that they can find money from other areas and instead have to use their own.

Today, I would like to talk about the entrepreneurs and inventors of my electorate who have made the quality of life within the Riverina and no doubt throughout Australia much better. A number of those whom I am about to mention put their own money forward in the first place and sometimes, if they were lucky, were able to obtain money from other areas.

The first person I mention is a man by the name of John Cullen, who is a tiler in Wagga Wagga. I do not know how many members have read the Bulletin of 20 June, but an article in it talks about an invention called the `Protecta-Point'. The reason that John Cullen invented it is that his best mate's three-year-old son died when he stuck a fork into a power point. How many of us have seen children go to power points and start probing them? He recognised this problem and invented `Protecta-Point', which is, as the article states:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . a power point that becomes live only after a power plug is inserted and half-turned to engage positive and negative terminals. Cullen thought it was such a goer that he sold his home, spent $250,000 taking out patents around the world, $50,000 on a die and another $50,000 on tooling up to have the points manufactured in China.
Others thought John's idea was a good one, including the Ray Martin Midday Show. The article continues that John:
. . . then achieved a prestigious gold medal at last year's Salon des Inventions in Geneva as the world's best invention in the electrical safety section.

PARA.TAB: He reckons he has spent about $400,000. And the return? "I've got a royalty cheque for $329.11 so far . . .

SPEECH.PARA: As you can see, most people who are inventors or entrepreneurs do take some risks, but he has gone on from there. The Wagga Daily Advertiser of I think 23 August states:
Mr Cullen, who invented the "Protecta Point" safety device two years ago, believes his new creation—
which is known as a `super stick fixing bracket'—
. . . is a variation on the common bracket which is fixed to wall studs where powerpoints are to be placed.

PARA.TAB: Mr Cullen's bracket has a mechanism which allows the screw to penetrate the hole in the bracket but stops its front from falling out, meaning the screw does not have to be screwed in all the way for the powerpoint or switch to be secured.
"It's faster than an electric screwdriver and the user doesn't have to waste any power from a battery drill," he said.

SPEECH.PARA: He goes on to say:

PARA.TAB: "The initial deal will be to supply half a million pieces per month.
"This is considered by the Americans to be the most significant breakthrough in that area of the construction industry for 20 years."

SPEECH.PARA: That is an inventive genius from Wagga Wagga. We move on to the issue of scaldings about which I have some facts that people may not know. Scalds account for two out of three child burn admissions to hospital; three out of 10 require skin graphs; more than 1.5 million children are at risk; and bathrooms are the location of the most serious tap water scalds. For some time people have been trying to work out a way to prevent scalds. In its edition of July 1995, Choice tested some of these implements known as anti-scald devices to see which one was most suitable. Its verdict was:

In view of the poor results from some models and the variability in results from others, from both product ranges, we don't feel confident recommending any of them—certainly not as a substitute for vigilance and other hot water safety measures.

While we would all agree that the best way of preventing your child from being scalded is by strict supervision while they are in the bath, a couple of gentlemen in my electorate have come up with a device known as a tap cap. It fits on the tap, you put this seal over the top, which only an adult can shift, and that prevents a child in the bath from touching the tap at all. Joe and Dom Sergi are to be congratulated on this device. It is now on the market. It is a simple device which they saw a need for and they set about to overcome the problem of the scalding of children.

PARA.TAB: A gentleman from Wagga Wagga in my electorate has invented a system he calls DARTS—disabled arm rest toilet support. As we know, there is a lot being done for people who are disabled and in most airport lounges or wherever you go where there is a lot of public movement there are toilets for the disabled. In those toilets, alongside the WC, you usually have a metal arm piece so that people can pull themselves onto the toilet.

This gentleman has developed the DARTS system where you can actually take your own device around with you. It has two armrests and it allows you to approach a WC from either side and to get far better support than you would get from a bracket on the wall. This has now been installed in a number of nursing homes, hospitals and other places and it is particularly helping those people who are confined to a wheelchair and find it most difficult to get onto a WC.

The invention is simple. There is no cost of installation. It is simple to use. It is simple to maintain. It simplifies left- and right-hand wheelchair transfers. It is sturdy. It is made of stainless steel and it fits most toilet pans. You can carry it with you when you travel on holidays, because you can bet that when you go to some of these areas they will not have what you need. Peter Dominquez of Wagga invented it. As I said, he has done a great service, particularly for those people who are confined to a wheelchair.

Another invention I want to speak about has been invented by Mr Ken Pagden of Leeton. I must thank the federal government because they have seen a winner and they have put forward $100,000 for him to carry on the project. In the Riverina, as you know, we grow quite a deal of rice. In the past disposing of the rice hulls has been a problem, and they have usually been burnt. There are many areas being investigated to see how these rice hulls can be used to great advantage and not wasted.

Mr Ken Pagden, with the assistance of Peter Klatt of the Rice Growers Association in Leeton in the MIA, has come up with an idea of compressing these rice hulls and making them into dunnage. Dunnage is what is used when you are packing, say, pipes or steel. Normally there is a piece of timber between them so that they carry well, do not move and are not damaged in transit. We are finding that this invention has enabled rice hulls to be compressed together and it is better than timber. It is certainly tougher. It is white-ant proof, fireproof and waterproof. So these pieces of what I suppose you call compressed rice hulls known as dunnage will be of great advantage in the shipping and the transport industries, will save the use of Australian timbers and will save those people who are using them a lot of money.

These rice hulls are being used not only in dunnage or in shipping timber but also in road safety for guide posts. For example, they can be used for barrier boards and they can be used for building panels for ceiling tiles. That is a very exciting development within the Riverina, and Ken Pagden is to be congratulated. The federal government also needs to be thanked for their support of this innovative idea.

We, in Australia, are very fortunate that we have a population that is not only highly educated but also very inventive. In the old days, particularly in my electorate, many people invented implements for use on the farm that were of most import and these implements were later spread not only throughout Australia but also throughout the world. Now we are finding a new wave of inventors or entrepreneurs coming into that area. They are to be congratulated and I hope the federal government gives them some support. I hope that private capital will come into being and that the banks will see these inventive geniuses for what they are and will support them. It can only help Australians in their quality of life and help Australia in its bid to earn overseas capital.

TALK.START.PARA: —In the grievance debate this evening I would like to address a particular grievance not only of mine but also of most Australian citizens I have come in contact with over recent weeks: the testing of nuclear weapons by France in the Pacific. Over recent days I have been travelling around my electorate with an Australian flag. The outline of it has been drawn up on a large sheet of white cloth. I have been encouraging people to sign this flag in blue, where the flag will be blue, and in red, where the flag will be red. The white pieces have been blotted out. Over the past four days I have collected thousands of signatures and the flag is starting to take the appearance of an Australian flag as the colour has been added to it. Every one of those signatures represents a person expressing an opinion opposing nuclear testing in the Pacific by the French government.

PARA.TAB: It has also been very interesting to talk with people as they have been signing the flag and to find out why they oppose the testing. I have spoken to diggers who were present in Japan after the Second World War and who saw the horrors of Hiroshima and Nagasaki. There have been young families most concerned that their children will be able to grow up in a world that will be much the same as the one their parents knew where there is no threat of increasing levels of radioactivity in plant and animal matter, particularly in fish, or increasing radioactive levels of the ocean. Before they go swimming, instead of looking only for faecal coliform counts they will also have to check the background level of radiation or radioactivity. These are some of the concerns. I even spoke with one cancer victim. The origins of cancer are often unknown, but the major concern is that radioactivity can induce cancer and so the concern of that particular person was also one of great concern to me.

This flag is a full-sized flag. I can tell all people that next Saturday I will be marching and carrying this flag at a rally in Tahiti to protest against these nuclear tests by the French in what essentially is our part of the world—the South Pacific. I visited a school last Friday. The school children had seen a report of this on television through the week and they asked me some questions about it. So we happened to have a look at the school atlas. One of the obvious things pointed out by the children was that when you have a look at the map of the world in the rectangular pattern you see that Mururoa Atoll is as far away from France as you can possibly get. That is an interesting fact. It is an interesting fact that the French are quite prepared to test their nuclear weapons but have selected a point on Earth that is almost as far from France geographically as you can get.

Another point that I have made continually is that the French, as a nation, are signatories to the nuclear non-proliferation treaty. Of course, France's being a signatory indicates that it supports the phasing out of nuclear weapons. The obvious question to ask is: if such a nation supports the phasing out of nuclear weapons, why is it prepared to spend the billions of dollars I guess it would cost to test nuclear warheads that it says it is prepared to phase out? Surely, the injection of funds into the economy of Tahiti would be far more sensible and would have far greater effect for the long-term future of the South Pacific.

One family I have spoken with at length has a daughter, a high school student in Australia, with a penfriend in France. She received a letter from her penfriend saying, `I know your government is opposed to France testing nuclear weapons, but please continue to write to me. We do not want the testing either.' We, as a nation, have to continually attempt to get the message through to the French voters. Current polling in France indicates that between 60 per cent and 70 per cent of French people do not support nuclear testing. They do support France as a signatory to the nuclear non-proliferation treaty, but they do not support the unilateral actions of their President. It is only the French people who vote for their President. Although he is in office for some time, we have to continue to reinforce our views to the French voters, because it is only through those actions that these tests will cease.

There are other problems that I have with the French debate. France says that it should continue testing in the Pacific because it is safe. Obviously, it is difficult to measure exactly what the risks are. When I was at university I studied geology, and I know that the rock type involved here is basalt. Most amateur geologists know that basalt is a volcanic rock and, as such, it can be porous and can contain a significant number of vesicles where gas can be trapped. If this is the situation and some of the cracks that emanate from the explosion chamber travel as far as such porous rock can, then who is to say at what rate radiation will leak out into the ocean and the effect it will have on the surrounding environment?

We all know that part of the staple diet of many of the people who live on those atolls is seafood. Many of the insidious effects of radiation over a long period, while not having been studied at great length, are not desirable. France has continually argued that the basaltic rock formations under the atolls will contain the explosions and that it has successfully done so to this stage. Mind you, it has admitted to the occasional partial submarine landslides. On the one hand, it is saying it is safe; on the other hand, it is saying there have been some very negative effects from the 160-odd nuclear explosions that have taken place in that area.

Another problem with basalt is that it is a brittle rock and the shock waves travelling out from the explosion do cause major fractures. Once this solid rock is fractured, it is permanently fractured; it does not grow back together again. We are talking about not the effect of a single explosion but the cumulative effect of a number of explosions which will eventually destroy the whole rock formation and cause it to collapse. If that happens, there is no possibility of science being able to shore up this collapsing sea mountain. So the leaking of radioactive substances into the ocean would be permanent. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Slipper Mr P.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am very pleased to have the opportunity—somewhat unexpectedly—to join in the grievance debate this evening because it gives me the opportunity to put in a plea to the Caloundra City Council for a very important environmental area of Queensland known as the Glasshouse Mountains. The Glasshouse Mountains were seen by Captain James Cook during his explorations, and they are renowned throughout Australia as a very beautiful area. They are within an hour's drive from Brisbane. It is a major horticultural area. Basically, everything that goes into a fruit salad, and some things that do not, are grown there: pineapples, custard apples, ginger, strawberries—you name it, we are fortunate to have them produced in the Glasshouse Mountains. Dairying and beef cattle are also very important to the area.

PARA.TAB: I have been very critical of the state Labor government over its failure to bring in a management plan for the Glasshouse Mountains. Former Minister Robson, who lost her seat at the state election with a swing against her of about 20 per cent, pledged on many occasions that she was going to bring in a management plan and was going to call for comments from the community. It was only in the dying days of her parliamentary term that we saw any evidence that she wanted to have a management plan at all.

My concern relates to a proposal, which is currently before the Caloundra City Council, by Swiss company Excel Quarries to expand quarrying operations in the Glasshouse Mountains area. Quarrying operations have been carried out there for a number of years. The existing quarry employs about 20 people, and the extraction area is currently 16 hectares. In recent times, the quarry company has been buying up other properties. Indeed, I understand that it now owns over 90 hectares, 42 hectares of which it is proposed would be included within the area of a new quarrying permit.

As you can imagine, such a proposal being put forward for such a beautiful environmental and tourist area would create great community concern and debate. I have been approached by very many constituents who are worried about what is proposed.

The existing quarry has a lifespan of about 12 years. I understand from discussions with the quarry company that, even if the permit were granted and the quarrying area were extended from 16 hectares to at least 42 hectares, no additional jobs would be created. The existing quarry has a life of 12 years and the existing jobs are not in doubt, at least not for that period.

The application currently before the Caloundra City Council seeks to extend the life of the quarry from 12 years to at least 50 years, and maybe 75 years. I always like to make a decision based on the facts, so I contacted Excel Quarries and said that I would like to inspect the present quarry and, indeed, the area which is proposed to be subjected to quarrying in the future. I was impressed with what I saw at the quarry operation. In my view, it certainly is a very well-run quarry. The company has gone out of its way to minimise the impact of that quarry on the local community. I had the opportunity of visiting all aspects of the quarry. I thank the company for its courtesy.

However, I do have a concern that such a massive quarrying operation is a use that is totally incompatible with the Glasshouse Mountains as a sensitive and fragile environmental and tourist area. I think it is entirely inappropriate for the Caloundra City Council to commit the community to the presence of such a quarrying operation for 50 or 75 years. I looked at the end use plans for the area to be subjected to quarrying. A number of proposals were put forward. Obviously those proposals, if they were carried out, could in the end be desirable. However, to give a quarry an extended life for 50 to 75 years is effectively to give a blank cheque to the company. None of us will be around in 50 to 75 years to monitor whether the end use proposals of the company are to be implemented. So I believed I had to take a stand and, consequently, along with very many other residents of the Sunshine Coast, I lodged an objection to the quarrying proposals currently before the Caloundra City Council.

It should also be noted that the council admits that it would have no control over any increased production levels at the quarry. The quarrying company claims that the level of production would not increase but the council would have no control over increased quarrying operations, should these occur, and the company itself admits that the level of quarry production will be governed by the marketplace.

I appreciate that the application by Excel Quarries is not in any way, shape or form at present a matter of federal political responsibility. It certainly would have been the easy course of action for me, as a federal member of parliament, simply to advise those who contacted me that they should refer the matter to the Caloundra City Council or perhaps to the local state member. But I think it is important, as a member of parliament representing people in the national parliament, to take an interest in all spheres of governmental activity, be they state, local or federal. I felt it important, therefore, to look at the relevant merits and demerits of the arguments being advanced in favour of and against the quarry expansion. I did not have any hesitation, after considering all the issues, in coming down on the side of the local community.

I would like to refer to an objection lodged with the Caloundra City Council by Mr Ren Hinton of Glasshouse Mountains. His objection is based on seven major grounds. The council, in my view, ought to look very closely at what Mr Hinton has said. He said:

SPEECH.PARA: 1. The quarry expansion is contrary to objectives 6b, 8c, 9a and 10a of the City Strategic Plan.

When one looks at the strategic plan, one sees that objective 6b is `to ensure that extractive industry activities are conducted so as to minimise any detrimental effects on the amenity of surrounding land uses'. Given the fact of primary production, given the fact that an increasing number of people are coming to live in the area, given the fact that there is tremendous tourism potential, it is fairly clear that a massive quarrying operation for 50 or 75 years is totally incompatible with the application which is currently before the council.

PARA.TAB: Objective 8c seeks to `maintain and preserve the amenity and character of rural areas'. That speaks for itself. Objective 9a seeks to `encourage the development of tourist facilities in appropriate locations'. Objective 10a seeks to `conserve environmentally and/or visually significant areas of the city in an appropriate natural or rural state'. When one looks at all those objectives, it is fairly clear that the application fails on all counts. According to Mr Hinton—and I quote:

SPEECH.PARA: 2. The proposal is contrary to the provisions of Clause 46(1)(a), (b) and (c) of the Town Planning Scheme.
3. The land use surrounding the quarry and the haulage route is a mixture of rural and rural residential type development which is incompatible with the quarry expansion.
4. The haulage route (Coonowrin Road) and alternatives are inappropriate in terms of traffic requirements, safety and traffic noise.
5. The quarry expansion would be a desecration of an area that is sacred in Aboriginal Mythology and traditionally important to present-day Aborigines.
6. The further intrusion of extractive industries in this area is inappropriate in that it conflicts with the lifestyle and aspirations of an increasing number of residents. . .

DEBATE.TITLE: COMMONWEALTH AUTHORITIES (AUSTRALIAN CAPITAL TERRITORY PAY-ROLL TAX) BILL 1995

PARA.TAB: Bill returned from the Senate with an amendment.
Ordered that the amendment be taken into consideration forthwith.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Clause 6, page 3, lines 15 to 18, omit the clause, substitute the following clause:

PARA.EMPHASIS: Payments made before commencement of this Act

PARA.TAB: "6. If a Commonwealth authority made any payments before the commencement of this Act on the basis that the payments were payable under the pay-roll tax law of the Australian Capital Territory, the Commonwealth authority cannot recover those payments.".

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Theophanous The Hon A.C.

TALKER.NAME: Dr THEOPHANOUS
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Prime Minister and Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Human Services and Health)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the amendment be agreed to.

SPEECH.PARA: The proposed amendment is to the Commonwealth Authorities (Australian Capital Territory Pay-roll Tax) Bill 1995. This bill ensures that the ACT government can legally collect payroll tax from Commonwealth authorities. Strictly, legislation like this should have been introduced back in 1987 when the ACT gained self-government. Commonwealth authorities have been making payments on account of payroll tax to the ACT as if they had a legal obligation to do so, anyway. The bill will allow the ACT government to keep these moneys; otherwise the ACT's revenue would be seriously affected.

PARA.TAB: The amendment made in the Senate will merely change the words used in the bill to protect the ACT government from having to refund payments made by Commonwealth authorities before the bill comes into effect. This will overcome initial fears that the original words may not have been effective in doing that. The government approves of the amendment.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Debate resumed from 24 August.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cobb Mr M.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —In reopening the debate on the Superannuation Supervisory Levy Amendment Bill, I would like to say that the coalition very strongly supports the concept of superannuation, as I do myself. But that support, of course, is conditional on any superannuation scheme being properly structured, being relatively easily understood by the people who use it, being relatively simple and predictable, and by the scheme being worthwhile. I believe that on many of these criteria, if not all of them, the present government's scheme is shown to fail.

PARA.TAB: I was interested in a recent survey by the Australian Consumers Council which showed that 50 per cent of participants in superannuation believe that it is a very poor investment. Apparently, the government is about to bombard us with an expensive advertising scheme costing $12 1/2 million. If they are going to expend that much of taxpayers' money, I believe the very least they can do is tell the full story on superannuation in this country as proposed by the Prime Minister (Mr Keating).

The Prime Minister this year has given a number of speeches about superannuation which have amounted to little more than hyperbole. We have had speeches on other topics which have fallen flat or on proposals such as changing the flag, bringing in a new republic, the budget that was brought down this year and so on. But when it comes to superannuation—which, it seems to me, is almost his last card on which to go ahead and win the election—he has done little more than exaggerate the benefits of the scheme and gloss over the numerous shortcomings within the scheme.

He has built up a quite inaccurate and unrealistic expectation out there amongst workers who will be participating in the scheme. I believe that this cynical exploitation of vulnerable people with grand undeliverable promises will be seen through well and truly before the election comes about.

I want to quote from a couple of the Prime Minister's speeches. On 12 May this year, at the Collingwood Football Club—what you would be doing talking about superannuation on such an occasion I am not sure—he says:

SPEECH.PARA: But, let me tell you now, I'll give you the punch line, what it all means. It means this, that a person on average weekly earnings—that is $33,000—will end up at the end of their working lives with a lump sum of $470,000 in today's dollars. And they will have an annual annuity of $30,000. If we take somebody on twice average weekly earnings, they will end up with a lump sum of $670,000 and they will have a pension of $42,000.

They are the words of the Prime Minister—a little bit ambiguous but I was left with the clear impression after reading that that you will get both a whacking great lump sum and, on top of that, this very generous annuity. That, of course, is not the case and I will come back to that later. At the launch of the advertising campaign on superannuation, which I earlier referred to, at the Berlei factory at Rydalmere in Sydney on 8 August this year, he said:
To give an example, someone on average weekly earnings now—
I emphasise the word `now'—
that's someone on about $32-$33,000—when they retire, they will retire on a lump sum just under half a million dollars.
He went on to say:
And this will produce an income stream in retirement which will guarantee them a much higher standard of living than they have today.
Again, a little ambiguous, but the only conclusion you can come to is that those people will have a much higher standard of living than they have today.

PARA.TAB: Who would the Prime Minister be addressing at a Berlei factory? I presume the predominant number in the work force would be women. They would need to be earning $32,000 to $33,000, if not more, to have that much higher standard of living that the Prime Minister talked about, and I doubt if very many, if any, of them would be earning that amount. Even if they got the full lump sum and that was turned over into an annuity, they would be earning only $25,892 and, clearly, they would be on a lower standard of living. Again, the Prime Minister's words are found wanting.

By the year 2002 there will be a contribution for every worker of 15 per cent towards superannuation. That will be made up of nine per cent coming from the employer. That is already under way, building up from between four, five and six per cent now. On top of that we will have a one per cent contribution from the employee starting in 1997-98, which will go up to two per cent the next year and three per cent the year after. That will be matched by an equal contribution of one, two and three per cent by the government.

So a person who is, say, 18 years old now and who will turn 25 in the year 2002, if they work full time on average yearly earnings of $33,000, in the year 2042 will have a lump sum accumulated in excess of $461,000. But that is dependent on a number of things.

Firstly, you have to work for 40 years, which not too many people do now. The average male presently works for 39 years, and that is falling away rather rapidly. The average for women is 17 years, and that is increasing. Almost nobody in the future will be working 40 years. Secondly, they will have to be working full time. There will be no room for part-time work to build up this sort of lump sum. Thirdly, no breaks will be allowed in that work pattern.

As I said, you will have to be on average weekly earnings. It is worth noting that 70 per cent of the population today earns something less than average weekly earnings. In other words, 70 per cent will be excluded from getting the sort of lump sum that the Prime Minister was talking about in these speeches.

We also need some explanation from the government as to how average weekly earnings will be calculated. If you start on a lower wage and halfway through that 40 years you suddenly crack the average weekly earnings and go on to earn a greater amount, that still will not qualify you because that average weekly earning will have to commence at an earlier stage. I will not go into the technicalities of that but it is a point that needs to be recognised.

Also, this large lump sum is based on an annual average three per cent inflation rate, which, quite frankly, I doubt will be attained between now and the year 2042. Also, it is based on average wages increasing by four per cent every year on average. Perhaps most remarkably, it is also predicated upon the funds in which the superannuation amounts are invested returning seven per cent on average every year for the full 40 years, which is somewhat fanciful, to say the least. It sounds a bit like Bob Hawke's promise that by 1990 no child would live in poverty.

It is interesting to note that if you took the average wage now, taking into account full-time and part-time workers—25 per cent of workers at present are part-time workers and that percentage is increasing rapidly every month—the average wage is $548.10, a far cry from the full average wage of $650 that the Prime Minister talks about. With an average four per cent increase every year on $548, you would be earning $3,462 in the year 2042. I seek permission to incorporate in Hansard a table showing the real average weekly total earnings over the last 12 years.
Leave granted.
The table read as follows—

TALK.START.PARA: —This table clearly shows that over the last 12 years, from 1982-83 up until last year, there has been a real increase in wages of a male worker of only about $40-odd, which represents something less than half a per cent per year increase. If we can achieve some of the figures that the government is talking about, we will be pleased indeed. Up until now we have not received much of the truth.

PARA.TAB: Incidentally, after the Prime Minister's speech at the Berlei factory, George Megalogenis of the Australian wrote an article saying that the Prime Minister had exaggerated the situation somewhat. The Prime Minister himself replied with a letter to the Australian in which he said:

SPEECH.PARA: I have never suggested that people on average incomes today will be entitled to pay-outs as large as $462,000 overnight.

That is a complete and utter contradiction of what he said at the Berlei factory and on which the journalist was commenting. Here is the Prime Minister in a letter to the paper denying what he said in that particular speech. It is an incredible situation when the Prime Minister denies something that he said only a few days before.

PARA.TAB: I am interested to see what will be included in this television advertising campaign. I do not think there will be much mention of the figures that have to come together for that large lump sum to appear. There will probably be no mention that we have to have no more than three per cent inflation on average every year, a four per cent increase in wages every year, and a seven per cent return on fund earnings. I think the chances of those figures coming together for 40 years would be remarkable.

No doubt very little mention will be made of the fact that the unemployed will miss out altogether. They will not be receiving any lump sum. In fact, it must be very frustrating for unemployed and self-employed people who are struggling now. The farmers in my electorate come to mind. They are already feeling left out. The gap between the rich and the poor will continue to widen. I am told that the average worker on a low income is now getting only about 30 per cent of average weekly earnings. So they will be well and truly left out. They will be contributing to this superannuation scheme only to have the dubious privilege of forgoing part of their pension. I do not see this scheme as being of great benefit to those people.

Women have really been left out by the Prime Minister. I am surprised that he did not mention women when we was talking at the Berlei factory because most of its employees are women. The average woman now earns less than half of what the average male earns. This is simply because women tend to do more part-time work; their work pattern is interrupted with having children and family duties; they tend to be lower paid; they tend to fill the lower ranked jobs; and so on.

If the average woman worked full time, received average weekly earnings for the 40 years, attained the lump sum of $462,000 and turned that lump sum into an annuity, what would she get? This is a poke in the eye for women. Here is sexual discrimination for you. The average male would get $29,000, but the average female would get only $25,000. The average female would get $4,000 a year less than the average male. The average female would get $80 a week less because women tend to live longer. It is an incredible situation, and I dare say that it will not be mentioned in the television advertising campaign.

The other thing that will not be mentioned in the campaign is the fact that, even if you want to take the lump sum, you will not be entitled to get the full amount of $462,000. I am told by the library that you can receive $418,000 of that lump sum tax free but that the high marginal tax rate of 48.4 per cent will apply to the remaining $44,000. In other words, you will pay in excess of $21,000 in tax. So much for getting your claws on the $462,000! You would be able to get only $440,000 of it.

In the Prime Minister's speech at the Collingwood Football Club—I read it earlier—he said that you can get both the lump sum and `an annual annuity of $30,000', which in the case of a woman is only $25,000. But the fact is that you do not get both. You get only one or the other. That should be spelt out clearly in the television advertising campaign.

There are other parts of this scheme which alarm me. For example, if you retired in the year 2042 at the age of 60 and you took the lump sum of $440,000, as I understand it there is nothing to stop you from blowing the lot of it and going on the full pension at the age of 65 anyway. That is a deficiency in the scheme, and the responsibility for that will fall on both sides of the House. That is something that should be debated and addressed in the course of time. It is a weakness in the scheme. In a strict sense, it is more a savings scheme than a retirement scheme.

Also, we have to remember that these superannuation contributions are not just an addition that falls into the lap. You are forgoing wages in a sense. In effect, you will be forgoing 15 per cent of your wages. As I said, low income earners will be hit particularly hard because they are forgoing not only their wages but also the pension that was going to fall due to them anyway.

TALK.START.PARA: —Pay extra tax not to get the pension.

—Indeed. Let us take the average wage of $650 a week, or $33,000 a year, to use the Prime Minister's figures. Fifteen per cent of that amount is $97.50 a week. That is $5,070 a year. If you add that up over the 40 years, the amount of $202,800 will be forgone. That is quite a substantial amount of money. Your sacrifice will be to forgo your pension to get the lump sum of $462,000.

PARA.TAB: As desirable as it might be to have the superannuation scheme in place, let us not delude ourselves that this is going to be absolutely extra to everything else. Of course, this increase will cost jobs because employers will have to outlay the extra nine per cent. It just does not come out of nowhere. Even when it was three per cent when the scheme kicked off, the Australian Chamber of Commerce and Industry, the ACCI, came out with the study saying that that amount alone would cost about 50,000 jobs. As desirable as it might be to start the superannuation scheme—I do not deny that—there will nevertheless be a cost to jobs. If the three per cent contribution cost 50,000 jobs, how many jobs will the 15 per cent contribution cost? Possibly it is in the order of 250,000 jobs.

TALK.START.PARA: —What a load of rubbish!

—The parliamentary secretary says, `What rubbish!' He seems to think that the extra nine per cent can be taken out of employers' bottom lines and that there is no cost to the employer whatsoever. If the employer did not have to pay that amount, he would be able to employ more people. I do not deny that in the end there is a benefit to the country in having a superannuation scheme in place, but to say that it is a total benefit with no offsetting costs is quite deceiving.

PARA.TAB: We would like to hear more from the government about where this money will be invested. The tendency up until now has been to heavily invest in blue-chip companies. If we are going to have vastly increased sums flowing through into superannuation schemes, I for one would not like to see them being invested in blue-chip companies as it would overly inflate their prices. Possibly more money will be invested overseas. I see that major pension funds now invest up to 15 and 25 per cent overseas. Some are projecting that that figure could rise to 40 per cent. I would like to hear more from the government on that particular point and on whether some of this money will eventually be going into infrastructure projects in this country.

There is also a cost to the government. At the moment they are forgoing tax revenue because of tax concessions of about $5 billion a year. That will double to about $10 billion a year. I was interested to learn that the crossover point whereby the savings from pension payment outlays from the government as opposed to taxation forgone does not come until the year 2035. That is 40 years from now. In the meantime, we will have outlaid $400 billion over the next 40 years before we get our first dividend of $2 billion. That is not the world's greatest investment, and it needs to be debated. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Smith Mr Stephen

TALK.START.PARA: —The Superannuation Supervisory Levy Amendment Bill is technical in nature. It opens up the very important national policy question of superannuation. But the bill itself is restricted to the late payment component of the superannuation supervision levy.

PARA.TAB: The Superannuation Supervisory Levy Act 1991 imposed a levy on the superannuation funds. The levy is imposed to recoup costs associated with prudential and other supervision of the superannuation funds by the Insurance and Superannuation Commission. The bill before the House makes some changes to the calculation of the late lodgment penalty for the levy component. The bill raises the general question of superannuation, and it is really in the general areas that debate on the bill has fallen.

I was somewhat bemused to find members of the opposition standing up and criticising superannuation because they really have not had a great deal of interest in superannuation. Until this government came into office in 1983, superannuation was treated by those opposite as a preserve for upper middle and high income people. It was a tax concession for people in those areas. There was no attempt to develop a national superannuation policy either for retirement incomes or for the purpose of national savings. So it was treated by those opposite when they were in government as a nice little tax break for upper income earners. Those opposite were not concerned about access to superannuation for low or middle income earners.

Since 1983 there has been a range of very important effects of this government's policies in the superannuation and retirement income area. Firstly, there has been a massive expansion in the number of employees in the country who have access to superannuation and who take it up. Secondly, we have seen a massive increase in the amount of funds held by the superannuation industry, which of course has a direct positive effect on national savings. Thirdly, we have seen, particularly in recent times, a concerted effort on the part of the government to make sure that low income earners and those people who have small amounts in superannuation funds, particularly where those small amounts are in more than one fund, are treated fairly and equitably. So we have seen a massive expansion of access to superannuation for the Australian working public.

There was a decade of reform. Data from the Australian Bureau of Statistics in June 1993 showed for that 10-year period a massive expansion in superannuation access. The ABS bulletin of 23 June 1993, effectively covering that 10-year period in office, states:

SPEECH.PARA: Superannuation coverage of employed Australians rose to 80 per cent in November 1993. This continues the upward trend reported in November 1991 when the level of superannuation coverage had increased from 51 per cent in November 1988 to 71 per cent.
It goes on to state:
. . . 6.1 million employed people aged 15 to 74 were covered by a superannuation scheme . . . 82 per cent of men had superannuation coverage . . . The level of coverage for women was 78 per cent.
Wage and salary earners reported the highest superannuation coverage rate with 89 per cent.

So those are the figures for the decade.
