We should bear in mind, firstly, that there has been continued expansion since that time and, secondly, that in 1983 when this government came into office the number of employees with access to superannuation was less than 40 per cent of the Australian work force.

PARA.TAB: What has been the net effect of policy to date? It has been a massive expansion of access to superannuation, which brings with it very important consequences for retirement incomes and a massive boost to the potential for contribution to national savings.

The initiatives in the budget for this year build on the previous superannuation policies put in place by the government. We now see a national superannuation policy which seeks to enhance and further expand upon both the access to superannuation and the contribution that that makes to national savings.

The government's superannuation policy was very well and clearly set out by the Treasurer (Mr Willis) in a speech to the Association of Superannuation Funds of Australia on 17 August this year. He clearly outlined the philosophical attitude behind the government's retirement incomes and superannuation policies when he said:

SPEECH.PARA: The Government's retirement incomes policy will continue to have three elements:

PARA.TAB: -the age pension and associated social security arrangements, which provide an income safety net in retirement;
-a compulsory saving element, achieved through the Superannuation Guarantee and now minimum employment contributions required under industrial agreements and awards; and
-a voluntary element of superannuation, encouraged by the substantial tax concessions available for superannuation saving and the Government's matching payments.

SPEECH.PARA: These measures will result in most employees having the equivalent of 15 per cent of their earnings directed towards their retirement savings from 2002.
This will be achieved through a process that does not involve any reduction in employees' existing disposable incomes.

The matching Government contribution is specifically targeted to low and middle income earners. This group includes a significant proportion of women who, prior to 1983, traditionally missed out on access to superannuation benefits and concessions.
The end result will be significantly higher incomes in retirement for ordinary workers.

That is the philosophical approach of the government and is something that stands in stark contrast to the attitude of those opposite when they were in power. In continuing his speech, the Treasurer made some important points about the contribution that the budget superannuation measures will make to increasing national savings and, consequently, reducing the current account deficit. The Treasurer said:
There is no doubt that the boost to savings from superannuation will be very substantial:
the award and Superannuation Guarantee arrangements already in place are estimated to boost national savings by around half a per cent of GDP this financial year;
over the next five years, that is, by the year 2000-2001, the combined effect of all our superannuation measures is estimated to boost savings by two per cent of GDP;
by the year 2005-2006, a decade from now, the impact on savings from superannuation is estimated to be three per cent of GDP; and
by the year 2020-2021 the impact will be more than four per cent of GDP.
He continued:

Thus there will undoubtedly be a rapid build up in national savings from superannuation over the next five years, with a slightly slower build up over the following five years, and more gradual additions over the next 15 years.
These figures demonstrate the complete falsity of Opposition claims that our superannuation policy won't provide a substantial boost to national savings until 2020 or 2042.

Opposition misinformation on the effect of the government's superannuation measures contained in the last budget has become something of an art form. I will refer to an article by Mr Megalogenis in today's Australian. He is a writer to whom the previous speaker, the opposition spokesman and member for Parkes (Mr Cobb), referred. Mr Megalogenis makes some interesting analyses which I think are correct.

PARA.TAB: The third strand of the Treasurer's speech was in respect of retirement incomes. I will again quote from his speech, because it gives the philosophical flavour of the government's approach over a long period. He said that the government's approach had been:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . built up slowly over ten years to improve retirement incomes, to provide for Australia's ageing population, and to increase national saving.
People support the system and want certainty and stability—but the Opposition continually refuses to endorse its main elements.

The Opposition has consistently and over a long period failed to match our commitment to ensuring the adequacy of the age pension. Remember, one of John Howard's first steps as Treasurer was to cease indexation of the aged pension.

Workers are now making plans for their retirement based on the full implementation of the Superannuation Guarantee, without any certainty from the Opposition about a bipartisan approach to this important long term policy.
Indeed, the Opposition's policy appears to be to freeze arrangements under the Super Guarantee and not implement the initiatives announced in this year's budget.
For instance, Mr Howard said in his reply to the Budget "that on a change of government any existing retirement benefits will be preserved."

The Liberals' apparent policy to freeze the superannuation guarantee at present levels and not to match employee contributions would mean a major reduction in retirement incomes for Australian workers.

That sentiment is echoed in the article in today's Australian which I referred to. I was not proposing to refer to it but, given that the shadow spokesman referred to an earlier article by Mr Megalogenis in the Australian, I thought it was timely to pull out today's copy. This article is found on page 11 of today's Australian and is entitled `Battlers will be first to fall into Howard's super trap'. How appropriate! The article starts with the following comment:

PARA.TAB: John Howard and Peter Costello risk the credibility of their economic attacks on the Government if they persist in making misleading outbursts on superannuation.

SPEECH.PARA: So the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Howard) and the Deputy Leader of the Opposition (Mr Costello) are squarely in the frame for their `misleading outbursts on superannuation'. The article continues:

PARA.TAB: Howard tarnished his self-image as an honest politician this month when he said that Keating's promise of a super bonanza is "very deceitful and a distortion of the facts".
Howard said: "He [Keating] runs around Australia saying under his policy workers will be able to retire on $480,000. The problem is it only applies to somebody who's now younger than 11."
Howard was wrong on two counts. The number Keating has been quoting out of the Budget papers is $462,000; and the person it refers to is now 18 years of age.

SPEECH.PARA: So the Leader of the Opposition has given a massive, deliberate and complete distortion of the implications of the superannuation measures introduced by the government in the course of the budget. Mr Megalogenis goes on to say:

PARA.TAB: But Howard compounded his error with his attempt to rebut Treasurer Ralph Willis's claims that workers would lose up to $250,000 in benefits under the apparent Coalition policy.

" He [Willis] was quite dishonestly observing that I was going to snuffle out workers' superannuation entitlements . . . We're certainly not going to leave people worse off as far as superannuation is concerned," Howard said.

SPEECH.PARA: Then there is some helpful analysis from Mr Megalogenis. He says:

PARA.TAB: What Willis was saying was clear enough. If the Coalition maintains its present policy to freeze the Superannuation Guarantee Charge at the levels applying at the next election, then ordinary workers would end up with much lower payouts than under Labor.

SPEECH.PARA: I repeat that `ordinary workers would end up with much lower payouts than under Labor'. That is absolutely correct. Here we have an opposition, which over 10 years ago was only interested in superannuation for upper middle and higher income earners—a tax concession for higher income earners—now embarking on a strategy which will have the effect, according to Mr Megalogenis this morning, of ordinary workers ending up with `much lower payouts than under Labor'. The analysis goes on:

PARA.TAB: The Willis argument is self-evident—a 5 or 6 per cent SGC will deliver a smaller super benefit than the 15 per cent benchmark being phased in by the Government.

Howard will be vulnerable on this point for as long as he continues to put off industry and employer calls to embrace bipartisanship on the SGC. Howard would have a hard time supporting the line run by John Hewson at the last election that a freeze on the SGC somehow preserves people's existing entitlements.

SPEECH.PARA: I repeat that `a freeze on the SGC somehow preserves people's existing entitlements'. It goes on:

It is Howard's battlers—the low-income workers who can't afford to top up their super—who are the most vulnerable. Freezing the SGC and then providing tax incentives for voluntary savings above that level will not help them break out of the small-amounts trap.
I repeat:
. . . the low-income workers who can't afford to top up their super—who are the most vulnerable. Freezing the SGC . . . will not help them . . .

That is pretty consistent with the entire approach that the Leader of the Opposition and the coalition parties take. Because Mr Megalogenis has referred to the Deputy Leader of the Opposition, the shadow Treasurer, let me give you his analysis of Mr Costello:

PARA.TAB: Costello repeatedly misquoted the Treasury estimates on the impact on the Budget measures on national savings; at one stage he got wrong the date for the implementation of the policy; and he suggested that paying the cancelled One Nation tax cuts into workers' super accounts would "be decreasing savings".

SPEECH.PARA: The inaccuracies diminished Costello's performance. The article refers to a debate that the Treasurer comprehensively won on the Lateline program recently.

PARA.TAB: There we see the full array of government measures over more than a decade to massively expand the access of superannuation to ordinary Australian workers, to massively expand the pool of national savings and to ensure that, together with the age pension preserved by Labor, Australia's ageing population will have a much better go at retirement incomes in the future. What do we see from those opposite? We see from those opposite what we have always seen: no interest in superannuation other than how it might apply to higher income earners by way of tax concession arrangements.

The shadow spokesman also referred to the Prime Minister's Berlei speech. I will finish with a quote from the Prime Minister's speech because this very aptly summarises the philosophical position of government members. The Prime Minister said:

SPEECH.PARA: Award superannuation is one of the great undertakings of the last decade, and it is now starting to blossom as a result of the Budget measures we announced just a few months ago. It will be such that by 2002 . . . every Australian working person will have 15% of their income going on their account into a superannuation fund—into a superannuation account for them. What this will mean is when they retire, someone joining the work force will retire on what is now twice the age pension, someone who is in the work force already—in their 30s perhaps—will retire on about three-quarters of the age pension, plus the age pension. So, it's going to mean a dramatic lift in the standard of living of Australians in retirement, and, of course, put together a huge pool of national savings, which can make a country stronger, which means we will rely less on overseas savings and overseas debt, and which means we can power along investment and employment and exports.

That is the approach of those on this side: ensuring that the vast bulk of Australians have access and opportunity as far as superannuation is concerned, ensuring adequate and sensible retirement incomes policies but also ensuring that we have a massive pool of superannuation funds as a boost to national savings and as an offset to the current account deficit.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lieberman The Hon L.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —The government's new-found zeal to push forward with a new model of superannuation rings fairly hollow with many Australians and for good reason. Since 1983, this government, the Hawke and Keating government, has attempted to control the levers, to manage Australia's economic and social policies, but the result has been a disastrous current account deficit, a disastrous foreign debt, increasing taxes, increasing government expenditure and less opportunity for individuals to take initiative and look after themselves and their family.

PARA.TAB: As a result, there is a great feeling of cynicism in the community about the new-found zeal of the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) to introduce another form of compulsory superannuation. This is particularly so because it is accompanied by a grossly expensive advertising campaign that is running prior to calling the federal election. The campaign will cost Australian taxpayers some $12 million at least.

Is it little wonder that Australians see the Prime Minister's posturing in this way as another example of promises from a Prime Minister which can be regarded as pie in the sky? There is good reason for Australians to feel cynical and very disappointed about this government. Yet a debate on savings for this nation and the future should be accompanied by a lot more enthusiasm and a lot more commitment from Australians generally.

They are entitled to feel very cynical because of the way in which they have been treated and the way in which the Prime Minister, since he became Prime Minister, has broken so many promises and left them in the lurch. In this current budget we see the government's proposal to abandon tax cuts that the government promised, that the Prime Minister promised, and that the Prime Minister enshrined in law, referring to them in his infamous statement as l-a-w.

He has abandoned the tax cuts. Now he is saying, `If you elect me'—heaven forbid!—`at the next election, I on behalf of the government will in my next term of office introduce a form of superannuation contribution from the taxpayer to the low income earners of Australia which will make up for the l-a-w tax cuts that I promised them in the last election and that I have now taken away from them.'

There is good reason for people to be very disappointed about this at a time when most Australians would rather see us devoting our time and attention to a bipartisan debate about savings, about encouraging families and about encouraging people to be self-reliant. How can we do that when the Australian people have been treated this way by the Prime Minister?

TALK.START.PARA: —You can't trust the Prime Minister.

—He cannot be trusted, as my friend says. He breaks promises, he brings in law to introduce tax cuts for low income people and then throws them on the scrap heap and now he turns around and spends $12 million of taxpayers' money and says, `Hang on, forget about that, after the next election I'll give you what I said I'd give you in tax cuts, which is what I said you could spend on your family and children, but I will give it to you in another way. Actually, I won't give it to you; I will compulsorily take it from you and put it into a superannuation fund.' There is a hell of a lot of cynicism and a lot of bitter disappointment in the Australian community because of this government's shocking record.

PARA.TAB: The Superannuation Supervisory Levy Amendment Bill that we are debating is an administrative bill designed to allow the superannuation governing authority to introduce a levy for late lodgment of returns. I have no objection in principle to that, but it is important to note that in 1992, when the principal bill was introduced by this government, a ceiling of $30,000 per annum levy was set for the superannuation authority on superannuation funds. Then an amendment was passed which said this could be fixed by regulation. At the moment, the ceiling is $200 per $500,000, or part thereof, of the superannuation fund.

I invite members to think very carefully. That has in fact given particularly this government the opportunity to raid the savings of Australians in the superannuation funds, up to $30,000 per fund. I am not suggesting that they are going to do it now, but it is just an indication of where superannuation has got out of control under this government. It is just another example of the doors they have opened here, there and everywhere to enable them to interfere in the rights of people and to enable them to raid the savings of people when it suits them.

The $12 million advertising campaign that our constituents are being forced to pay for—they were not consulted by the Prime Minister about that either—talks of the collection of compulsory superannuation contributions to begin after the next election using taxpayers' money to pay a levy in conjunction with that. It is all compulsion and it is all using other people's money. I remind people of that. Sometimes people forget that it is not government money—it is other people's money, the people's money—that they are throwing around and making promises about.

The government's promises cannot be relied on because they do not keep them. That is fundamentally the problem. How can you construct a substantial savings policy for this nation when the government cannot be trusted, for good reason, to look after it, to honour its commitments? It cannot be trusted because it will vary them after the election if it gets a mandate—heaven forbid. I hope it does not; I do not believe it will.

The other problem I find is that we have the lowest level of saving in this economy since we started to record details of saving levels. Also, we have had very high unemployment—one million, now down to 800,000. I am happy that a lot of people have now found employment—we all are—but a lot of those people who have found employment are in part-time work or in training programs and, thus, not in unemployment statistics. There is a great deal of concern about that.

I believe—I try to regard myself as a practical person—that what the government should be concentrating on as a matter of urgency is ways to stimulate employment and ways to overcome the deterrents to employment that have been far too evident under the last 12 or 13 years of Labor government, and it has been getting worse.

Small businesses are the engine of the economy. They have the potential to provide hundreds of thousands of new jobs in Australia. They cannot do that because they are being pushed back and down as a result of this government's bad policies. The recession has hurt them very badly. Many of them have not recovered and will not be back in business again. Those that have survived are finding it almost impossible to carry on because they have not recovered. They have used their reserves; they have borrowed more. They have had three interest rate rises under this government and they fear another one, by Christmas or early in the new year. They have no confidence any longer to make further investments, to take risks and to offer people, particularly young people, new jobs, which is what we would want them to do.

The government's answer to that is very inadequate. The government's policy of spending $12 million to sell this compulsory superannuation scheme is only going to add to the cost of business and small business in Australia and therefore deprive many Australians, especially young Australians, of a job opportunity in 1996-97. That is the bottom line.

So why is this government not addressing the oncosts to employment and giving that at least equal billing, at least equal priority, in its dying months of government in Australia? Why is it not addressing the very important debate on retirement policy and savings? The government is not doing that at all. If you have a look at the business the government proposes to bring into the House this session and at the comments by the ministers, the senior ministers particularly, you will see that very little attention is being paid to the bottom line that Australia needs to address urgently.

That bottom line is: why are our savings so low, why are our unemployment rates constantly too high, why are the compliance costs for taxation too high, why are industrial laws not encouraging people to employ, to take risks and to make new investments, why is our current account deficit the worst it has been and almost the worst in the world, why is our foreign debt so high, how are we going to control this and what are we going to do about it? There is very little attention paid to that. But we do have a $12 million glitz campaign, paid for again by my constituents and yours, to sell this government's new found zeal in respect of superannuation.

The previous speaker, the member for Perth (Mr Stephen Smith), attempted to reduce this debate to a class war and made mention that he had not heard anyone on this side talk about savings, retirement policy or superannuation. That is absolute nonsense and humbug. I do not think he does himself any credit to try to reduce the debate to a class war. In fact, you might remember in another place, Mr Deputy Speaker, in the Victorian parliament in the 1970s and 1980s, debating equal opportunity law and debating the need for superannuation to be reviewed so that women in Australia could have equal opportunity to save through superannuation.

We have all had a fairly long-term commitment to do with superannuation. I do not want to hear any more nonsense such as that from the member for Perth, who attempts to muddy the water by turning the debate into a class war. If he wants to fight that way, the figures are too stark for him to defend. Out in the hustings, when the real election campaign starts, the truth of his government's mismanagement will destroy his political career. If he wants to hasten the process, that is fine by me.

There are other matters that Australian people are expressing caution about in relation to the government's approach to superannuation. One of them is: what is going to happen with the management of all the money this superannuation policy is designed to attract? We have to get used to the expression `trillions of dollars'. That is, in fact, what we are talking about.

By compulsion, this government is proposing to the nation that huge chunks of people's private funds and their efforts from working, for wages and in business, are to be taken from them by compulsion, invested by people into investments that the individual does not have much say in at all. If the Prime Minister does not believe me and does not think that is what the Australian people are worrying about, then I suggest he come down from his lofty tower and talk to the people. There is a heck of a lot of concern about that.

How is this to be managed and by whom? Some of the people who have enormous say already in the placement of superannuation investment funds have already made some rather unfortunate statements about the approach to investment of these trillions of dollars that will come their way.

I will quote from the Financial Review of Tuesday 4 August. An article headed `Cautious Capitalists' attempted to analyse some of the views of people who are heavily involved in the management of superannuation fund investments in Australia. One of the quotes came from the industry fund guru of superannuation in Australia: none other than the ACTU Secretary, Bill Kelty. I am sure we all know Mr Kelty—a very interesting person, a very strong personality and a director of one of the major union funds in Australia. He is associated with many of the directors of other industry and union funds in Australia.

In this article, Mr Kelty talked about the question of corporate governance, about whether investment moneys entrusted in their care by Australians in the superannuation funds should be dovetailed and placed in certain types of investment, selected by the board for criteria other than financial performance and expectation. He talked about important matters, such as the environment and human rights, and so on. They are all important things. I, for one, believe that corporate governance always should have regard to moral and ethical issues. But the bottom line must be that the financial safety of shareholders' funds has to be ensured. That is a principle of business.
However, in this article Mr Kelty is quoted as saying `we must not get carried away' with corporate governance—thanks for the warm, comforting statement, Bill. He went on to say:

SPEECH.PARA: We . . . own the shares on behalf of the members of the funds. We are entitled to ask questions.
He also said:
Companies cannot assume that simply because they do not like unions, they can exercise policies of de-unionisation without question.
That is a threat to corporate Australia that, if you want to bid for the trillions of dollars—

TALK.START.PARA: —I thought was it was a matter of commonsense and the blindingly obvious.

—Let us just go through it slowly. That was a threat. In the future you want to apply for equity capital or loan funds from the trillions of dollars of superannuation money that will be entrusted into the care of these various funds. If you do and you happen to take the view of no union compulsion in the workplace, for example, Mr Kelty says that companies cannot assume, simply because they do not like unions, they can exercise policies of de-unionisation without question. That can only mean one thing: retaliation. So if you are a union fund and you have trillions of dollars to invest each year, and a company comes along and says, `We have a major infrastructure proposal for Australia requiring loan funds and equity' and it puts it up to the board of this particular superannuation fund, and the company happens to have a freedom of choice policy in that it is not compulsory to belong to a union, Mr Kelty is saying that from his point of view, `We can't ignore that.'

PARA.TAB: That is a very stark, frightening expose of the minds of some of these people who are already in control of very substantial sums of money belonging to ordinary Australians. That is why the debate, in my view, should be broadened to encompass just what sort of corporate governance principles will be allowed to be put in place in Australia in the emerging field of investment of trillions of dollars of Australian workers' money. Are we going to stand by idly and allow people with strong ideological viewpoints—and they are entitled to have them; I do not object in any way at all to that—to make the investment decisions for other people's money and to be able to discriminate against investment and growth in Australia because they do not like the non-compulsory union policy, for example, of some players in our economy in Australia?

I believe that the bulk of Australians would reject wholeheartedly decisions on investment of retirement funds being in the hands of people who will make those sorts of discriminatory judgments. But it is on the record for Mr Kelty to explain what he meant by it. I am very interested in knowing what he meant by it, and obviously the Financial Review is—that is why it published the article.

Another point is that, in all of the changes that have occurred since 1983, very few people with the investment of their hard won investment savings and retirement funds have profited a lot by it. There has been an enormous amount of money made by the commission agents and by the brokers—and, sure, they have the right to be remunerated for their work. But this government's management of superannuation over the last 13 years has been attended by huge changes, lurches, from one policy to another, all of which have cost the savings of the ordinary worker enormously. I think that is most tragic and something for which this government should be brought to account.

The government is proposing now that it should be entrusted once again with the trillions of dollars that will come from this policy of increased compulsion. In fact, the government is proposing that it should be entrusted to the point where the Prime Minister with his $12 million is virtually saying, `Look, I'll pass the act before I call the election, and I'll implement all this policy after the election.' That has a very familiar ring to the l-a-w that before the last election he put forward so vigorously and then after the election repudiated, without any apology at all.

The other point that I think is lacking in this debate is the squaring up with the self-funded retirees and the people who are already in the work force for whom these proposals will not help at all in any shape or form. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —We are here tonight debating the Superannuation Supervisory Levy Amendment Bill 1994, which is another government change to superannuation legislation—one of the myriad of changes introduced by this government, which has created absolute confusion amongst people who want certainty in retirement and who need to be able to make decisions for which they can plan. The government has a fetish with superannuation as being the only acceptable form of saving. Locking up funds with insurance companies seems to be the government's favourite ploy in claiming that it has a real retirement policy. Of course, nothing could be further from the truth.

PARA.TAB: If one looks at the decisions of the government over the last 10 or 12 years, one can see that it has fluctuated in its commitment to superannuation. The government says that it is committed to superannuation, but it has failed to take it up strongly even in this budget. For instance, the government, if it really wants employees to contribute to funds, has failed to legislate on behalf of them. The money tree will not exist. It will be working through the award system; it will not be working through legislation here in the House.

The government is not committed. There is a drop-off of around 10 or 12 per cent in the number of people who will be covered by superannuation, who will make a contribution towards their own retirement. The government will play favourites in this matter. For some, the government will say that if you are a member of a union, you will be forced to make a contribution, and if you are not a member of a union, you do not have to put in any money at all. What strange logic. What a queer way of conducting the affairs of this House, if the government has a real policy towards superannuation. I just cannot understand the logic of the way in which the government—and the Treasurer (Mr Willis) in particular—has approached this whole matter of superannuation.

The government has made decisions in regard to superannuation as a smokescreen to hide the fact that it has failed to deliver on the tax cuts that were offered at the last federal election. The Prime Minister (Mr Keating) at the last federal election said that all Australians could have what the Liberals had promised: no GST and tax cuts as well. The tax cuts have gone. He put them into l-a-w, law, and nobody received them. As for the goods and services tax: no, we have not got that, but we have a Keating sales tax instead. That tax covers food, commodities and clothing—all of the dreadful things that the Prime Minister through the election campaign said that the opposition's goods and services tax would pick up. We have, in effect, a goods and services tax; it should be called the Keating sales tax because it covers a wide range of commodities as part of an indirect tax system.

But this superannuation proposal in the budget was really to soften the decision the government had taken that it would not deliver on its tax cuts. Instead, the government is proposing some long distance plan of superannuation that is supposed to bring forward the money tree—and it is supposed to bring great results for all Australians if they water their money tree. If it were in private enterprise, this current government would be up for false advertising in the way it is presenting its money tree.

The facts of the matter are that what is said on television is far from the truth, and it is nothing short of a political campaign by the government, using taxpayers' money, to ensure its re-election. We have seen this before. We have seen the use of taxpayers' funds in this obnoxious way before. This is self-promotion, advertising of government policies, and using taxpayers funds to do so. We have seen it before, and it is starting again. Here is an information kit on the money tree.

TALK.START.PARA: —You called for this.

—The minister obviously has not read this. The minister is not interested in superannuation. He would rather play around on the marginal fringes of justice in Australia—self-promoting again, with information kits going out. He is good at information kits too. This is a taxpayer funded self-promotion program for the government, costing $12 1/2 million.

PARA.TAB: I will go through some of the details so that it is easy to see why taxpayers of Australia and those who pay superannuation should be most unhappy about the claims of the government. In his speech for the national superannuation education campaign launched on 8 August, the Prime Minister said that someone on average weekly earnings now—that is, someone on about $32,000 to $33,000—will retire with a lump sum just under half a million dollars.

I believe that the community has been sold a pup. Why would anyone want to believe the Prime Minister on any of these matters? He dumped on Australia on the l-a-w, law, tax cuts. He is going to dump on this too. Why should anybody believe that something is going to be delivered by this Prime Minister in the year 2050? For goodness sake, he could not deliver on stuff two years ago; how is he going to deliver on stuff in over 50 years time? It is impossible to even imagine that the Prime Minister cares or believes he is going to be in this parliament, or anywhere in Australia for that matter, to have any influence on superannuation that far ahead in time.

On the Treasury's own estimates, to achieve the sum the Prime Minister has used, somebody would have to enter the work force in seven years time at the age of 25, when the government's superannuation scheme is fully implemented. So only such people can achieve the target that the Prime Minister spoke about. They must begin in seven years time at the age of 25. If you are over the age of 25 in seven years time or if you begin work prior to that date and you are now 25, these sums do not add up for you.

The Prime Minister's sums are not real sums. The very narrow starting point is that a person must be 25 years of age or younger and enter the work force in seven years time. That means that young people now at the age of 18 stand the prospect of this promise coming true. So, in seven years time, in the year 2002, the government's superannuation scheme will be fully implemented, but full-time workers who will have been on average wages for at least 40 years by then just cannot expect to own the Prime Minister's heavily fertilised money tree. There is no way today's workers are going to be able to earn anything like what is suggested in that false advertising that appears each night on television. It is a con—like everything else the Prime Minister does.

Australians hope and yearn for realism from their Prime Minister, but he constantly lets them down. The promise sounds great, and it is what we really need. We need a savings scheme that has some options but which is not linked as strongly to superannuation as this government is linked; nor should it make the promises that the government or the Prime Minister make. They are false promises; they are misleading promises. I would say that the Prime Minister is practising the deception on the Australian community that he has tried time and time again.

TALK.START.PARA: —You would, wouldn't you?

—You do not believe, Minister, surely that a government can go to the people of Australia and say, `You can have all of this, no GST and tax cuts as well,' and then renege on every part of that promise and say that it is good government. You cannot say that is good government, because the Australian people do not want that. They would prefer to believe you; I acknowledge that. But the fact is that they are so cynically sore and bruised from the pummelling they have had from this government that they will not believe a promise that is coming into fruition in 50 years time and commences in seven—a promise of a Prime Minister who has broken promise after promise.

PARA.TAB: The Prime Minister has made a number of assumptions in his estimate of what the superannuation package will be. The assumptions that he made are these: that there will be a steady CPI rate of three per cent over the period, and that is a long time to run a CPI at three per cent; that wages growth will be four per cent—one per cent above the cost of living—and that there will be a generous fund earning rate of seven per cent. If there is any variation on any of these figures, the payout of half a million dollars will be inoperable.

So we have so many factors that are improbable, yet the Prime Minister brushes the facts aside and, with some sleight of hand, produces round figures that he expects Australians to believe. They are flawed figures. That money tree is a figment of the Prime Minister's imagination, because a CPI rate of three per cent has not been achieved over the last 10 years. We are looking at the long term here. Superannuation and retirement benefits are in the 20- and 30-year term, and we need funds and investment processes to be able to handle that term and that length of investment. We do not have proper processes in Australia, and we need to have them. But the Prime Minister has assumed that three per cent CPI rate and wages growth of four per cent for that period.

To make an assessment of the earnings of funds, it is very interesting to note how superannuation has worked, and I do not believe that there is any likelihood of change. Let us look at how well superannuation funds have earned interest. As at 30 June 1994—and these facts were produced by super funds in February 1995—over a 25-year period there was a real yield of only two per cent. Yet the Prime Minister has based his calculations on seven per cent. Over a 30-year period it was only three per cent, yet he has based it on a seven per cent yield.

The margins are so tight—they are right on the border—that it is just a figment of the Prime Minister's imagination to expect that his calculations will come through and that after a 30-year period people will receive a payout of half a million dollars. It is not borne out by any facts at all. It is an ad campaign drawn up as part of the re-elect Keating campaign.

It is a fact that for shorter periods, for 10 or 15 years, there are reasonable yields from superannuation funds. But, for the length of time that the Prime Minister needs—that is, somebody commencing work at the age of 25, in seven years time, and then working beyond the year 2002 for 40 years from the date of commencement—a working life of 40 years is nearly finished these days, but we will say that that is achievable—the yields the Prime Minister claimed cannot be met. If one looks at the effect of changes in real earning rates—that is, say, a superannuation contribution of 10 per cent of income—one has to realise that the end benefits, as a multiple of the final salary, can be substantial but their earning rates are as low as two or four per cent.

What of the superannuation funds themselves? Where are they investing to achieve such modest results? The superannuation funds, as of December 1994, were putting about 15 per cent of their money overseas, about 14 per cent into short-term and liquid assets, about 21 per cent into fixed interest rates, 37 per cent into equities and units in trusts, and about nine per cent into land, buildings and non-financial assets. So they are basically playing the money market, and a lot of the superannuation funds of Australians are being invested overseas.

I think this whole process should sound the warning alarms for any Australians. We need to get superannuation right; I am not denying that. The government has fiddled and played with superannuation as its sole cause and its sole attraction for people seeking retirement. Once you start to criticise the government, the Prime Minister flies into a rage and starts to deal with people, as he did with the business community before the last election, making the sorts of comments that caused Dick Warburton to say that we have been getting much closer to the politics of hate—in other words, `If you don't agree with me, I'll not only hate you but I'll destroy you.' Those are the comments that the Prime Minister makes. We should look at the Business Council of Australia and some of the treatment it has had. CRA chief executive John Ralph agreed that serving on two coalition committees brought the threat of penalties against his organisation.

The Prime Minister cannot adopt these processes. He can lead by example and accurate information, but to slag people and abuse them because they disagree with the hyperbole of his retirement program is unrealistic. The facts do not stack up. They cannot be achieved. The narrow gateway of entry for superannuants in seven years time and the Prime Minister's predictions of the package which assumes a CPI growth rate of three per cent, a wages growth of four per cent and a fund earning of seven per cent cannot be realised over a 20- to 30-year period, which is the period that is essential for the Prime Minister's package to be realised.

I guess the thing that really hurts most people is the fact that between now and the year 2002 the retirees who would otherwise have had the benefit of income tax cuts which were to start on 1 January this year will not receive the full benefit of the government's superannuation promises and will remain largely dependent on the age pension. That is a promise that anybody over the age of 40 can just forget. This is not a commitment for the over-40s.

For the under-40s, you have to believe that the Prime Minister will deliver something in 50 years, when he is living in Switzerland, France or somewhere else and not giving a continental about Australia. Why should we believe Keating on this issue? He will not even be around to see that these things come into place. He will wobble out from some retirement hole, with the press there, and say, `The current government has let me down. I planned superannuation to survive and give a real return of half a million dollars in 40 years time.' He will not be in Australia; he will be gone. He will be out of it because he thinks this place is the backside of the earth, and he has said that and he has written that. We need to be realistic about what the Prime Minister has in mind for the workers of Australia.

No worker in their 40s on average weekly earnings has got a chance under the compulsory superannuation scheme. For self-funded retirees, there is nothing. For those who have worked and saved and scrimped, there is nothing. Forget them and write them off. Many women will not benefit by this process because a great proportion of women do not earn average weekly wages and the Prime Minister's commitment and that money tree are based on average weekly wages. That is the con of the whole thing. There are many people on lower incomes who will not achieve that amount. If they are over 40 there is nothing for them at all. If they are over the age of 25 in seven years time, they will not get the half a million dollars anyway. The con for workers is realistic.

Under the Accord Mark VIII a worker on the lowest award rate who received the accord safety net pay increases but makes employee superannuation contributions in 1998 will be $8.25 a week worse off in real terms. Where is this going? We have a problem that the Prime Minister does not talk about. Current workers are paying for unemployment benefits, they are paying for retirement benefits for those who are currently retired and they are contributing towards their own superannuation as well. This is the dilemma that the Prime Minister will not confront.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Superannuation Supervisory Levy Amendment Bill that we are dealing with here today is relatively minor, but it opens up the entire issue related to the government's policy on superannuation. Over a long period the issue of compulsory superannuation has been discussed and has been the subject of numerous reports. People try to say that during the Fraser and previous governments the matter was considered and abandoned and that that is some form of criticism. The simple fact is that it was abandoned because it did not seem to produce the benefits that the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) now seeks to give it.

PARA.TAB: The Prime Minister and everybody else who supports this system does so on the basis that Australia has to do something about its abysmal savings record and its substantial overseas debt. That debt represents a significant risk to Australia, even in terms of our independence. I quote frequently Hartcher, the Japanese correspondent for the Australian Financial Review who—I think it was on 8 or 11 November 1994—reported in that paper how during the trade negotiations between Japan and America a very senior Japanese official threatened people, including Lloyd Bentsen, the then Treasury secretary, that if America was not prepared to pull back from its attitude on trade negotiations, Japan would encourage its financial institutions to withdraw their money out of America. The interview quotes the person who told this story to the journalist. The journalist said to this fellow Koo, from Nomura Securities, after this threat had been made to the Americans, `What did the Americans say?' The answer was, `Nothing.'

If a country of the financial power of Japan is prepared to make that sort of threat against a country of the financial power of the United States, one might wonder if at some time in the future, for whatever reason, a particular country in the world, holding a large amount of Australian paper, which it could simply acquire, were to require something of Australia that the government of the day was not anxious to provide, how quickly our government could be brought to heel in terms of threats of that nature. When one has to start worrying about whether our so-called head of state is a person living in England, I would find the threat to our independence much more concerning in regard to our established debt.

There is another piece of wonderful childish folklore that is constantly published on this particular issue by our Prime Minister—that is, that you cannot blame this federal government in any way for the terms of our overseas indebtedness; that is all achieved by the nasty private sector and its irrational behaviour. The Prime Minister quite rightly points out that in this regard the federal government owes practically no money overseas. That is absolutely true. Over many decades federal governments have only gone to the foreign money markets when our balance of payments or our holdings of a particular currency—be it yen or something else—at the Reserve Bank were not sufficient to finance our activities and as a consequence have raised a bond issue in that currency to get our foreign currency levels back into balance.

Otherwise, why would a federal government, even ahead of a state or local government, bother to borrow on international markets with all the associated risks when it has first call on the national savings of Australians? Contrary to popular opinion, whilst our savings levels are low, they are not nil. The simple fact is that governments have first call on those for various reasons—namely, that they appear to offer the best form of security. As is the current case in the federal government's accumulated debt, if you have the federal government sucking about $100 billion out of the domestic savings pool, it is pretty obvious that those wishing to advance their business through borrowings might find themselves going offshore to borrow their money for the simple reason that there is none left in Australia.

When we start to moralise on the level of Australian savings, we find there is an obligation on a government that owes $100,000 million and is paying $10.077 billion in interest, according to the budget this year. Public debt interest is listed, I think, at $10.077 billion. That exceeds defence. That amount of money is having a severe effect on our overseas indebtedness. I think it is reasonable to argue that, notwithstanding the impossibility of the circumstances, if the government were to pay back its $100,000 million in debt tomorrow, Australia's overseas debt would fall by $100,000 million. That is a simplistic presentation.

On the other hand, any government that stands up, sticks out its chest like a great big kid and says—and I have heard both the Minister for Finance (Mr Beazley) and the Prime Minister make this claim—`We don't owe any money overseas. Don't blame us for the overseas debt,' is being foolish and childish and demonstrates absolutely no understanding of the fundamental economic issue that, if you have a major borrower in your domestic market, in the end they will drive less powerful borrowers offshore. The first issue when we consider this process of forcing Australian individuals to save is that there is a substantial responsibility on government.

I have made the point time and again that the fundamental of Keynesian economic theory was that governments borrowed in recession at extremely cheap interest rates, which usually followed that situation, to restart the economy. When the policy was first proposed, politicians of that era found it imperative that they also invest in infrastructure. Roosevelt built the great Boulder Dam, et cetera. Today we tend to borrow the money and pay it out to people to do nothing, and that is not very smart. That is just another aspect of it.

It has always been accepted that governments would borrow in bad times. But the other side of that theory was that, as the effect of that borrowing and spending became apparent, it was time for government to get out of the borrowing field and start to run surplus budgets to repay the debts of bad times and gain the revenue from the increased private sector activity.

That has not happened in recent years. The trouble is that too many people have been put on one gravy train or another during the recession, some are not too anxious to leave and a government that is purely focused on seeking votes turns around and accommodates them with borrowed money. Last year, as records and the budget papers show, borrowings in what was probably the five minutes of economic sunshine was $12 billion. If we readjust the figures for this year, as the Australian Bureau of Statistics has, with regard to assets we find the net effect is that the government is borrowing some $8 billion.

Isn't it amazing—we have got back a little bit of money on our foreign debt because we sold to foreigners over 50 per cent of Qantas in the Qantas float—more than we were promised. The simple fact is that all of the money that came out of Australia—$750 million or something like that—came out of someone's savings account, came out of their resources, or they borrowed to make the purchase.

In every one of those cases, the sale of an asset like Qantas or for that matter the Commonwealth Bank within the domestic situation in Australia clearly does not improve national savings. It is just a matter of simple arithmetic. It appears the Prime Minister does not understand that. The first factor is that, if all this superannuation deal is to do with improving national savings, we are squeezing dollars out of individuals when the government of the day could make a genuine contribution if it looked to its own activities and followed accepted economic principles and just did not borrow—be it good times or bad.

The debate then goes to what we are doing to people. It then goes to process. I find the process amazing because we still do not have a proper response to how people might benefit from their superannuation by giving them a clear and unambiguous opportunity to invest in a single policy throughout their working life. It is fine for someone who, as the Prime Minister envisages, just happens to turn 25 in the year 2002, or whatever it is, and just happens to be earning average weekly earnings. Not too many people who vote Labor earn average weekly earnings—$33,000 to $34,000 a year. My family runs businesses and employs some 30 to 40 people. Very few of those, as hard working as they are, earn anything like that sort of money. A top wage for sub-managers is about $25,000.

The simple fact is that the first assumption of the Prime Minister's calculation is that you have all these people on $33,000 to $34,000 a year. I have usually found, although I have not checked recent statistics, that the number of people who earn average weekly earnings or better are in only the top 10 per cent of taxpayers. All the rest earn substantially less. Many earn less than $20,000 a year.

The Prime Minister is out there painting this picture of almost half a million in returns. We know the conditions by which that might be achieved, including all the protections about inflation and wage rises. What is it—three per cent inflation and four per cent wage increases? Not too many people around the world are experiencing that sort of situation. To suggest that that will apply for 40 years, commencing in 2002, is a pretty optimistic situation and quite simply one the Prime Minister will not be answerable for. So we have the issue of the process and where it is leading in terms of its ability to succeed.

Then we have in relation to the issue of process whether superannuation in isolation should be the sole means of generating savings or generating people's retirement income. Superannuation and managed funds typically and traditionally have invested in very large enterprises, particularly blue chip. You cannot blame them for that. The simple fact is that those people are charged with protecting the public's money. When one has that responsibility, one generally tries to invest very cautiously. The more cautious your investment, the less your return.

For many years in recent times inflation looked after that. Asset values in nominal monetary terms grew dramatically, and these companies could declare big profits. That has ceased. The Prime Minister again tells us how wonderful it is that he has low inflation, but he also has low asset growth and low growth on people's investments—ask any typical self-funded retiree who has been devastated by this process. The simple fact is that the fund managers found the ease with which they could declare substantial returns became extremely difficult and they next found themselves obliged to go out and gamble.

I will not give you a full run-down on derivatives, but derivatives are just another form of bookmaking unless you retain it as it was originally intended: for people in trade to take a position that allowed them to meet a contract or repayment, or do something. One would still be a winner and one would still be a loser but they both achieved their aim of fixing either a price for the goods they were selling or a price for the goods they were buying at some time in the future, which allowed them to meet other contractual arrangements, be it repayment of debt or meeting a contract to provide goods. That was quite proper.

When the money managers stepped into the market and tried to second-guess people in those trades, anything was possible. We saw it with the Leeson case. We have seen it here in Australia where, in dealing on the bond market in that particular regard in what is basically a fairly artificial proposal, huge losses were sustained. People have been getting letters in the mail. People I know are being told that the value of their accumulated superannuation in recent years has not gone up. It has in fact gone down because people made mistakes.

The only certainty of moving outside of those very secure investments is that there is always a loser for wherever there is a winner. And that is what the Prime Minister is telling Australians. We see these little cartoon advertisements back on with people pouring these coins into little flowerpots. I understood we were going to have a $12.5 million campaign so that people might understand how the system works and why it is good for Australia. We get a cartoon that, after you have turned five, would not be of great interest. But it is also very misleading because, as I have said, it predicts all these wonderful results in cartoon form when in fact the experts—and there are now a legion—are raising some fair questions about it. I find this as something that is a grave problem.

We have now taken another step. The Prime Minister had to duck out of his l-a-w tax cut promises and he had to put something forward that looked like he was not ducking out of his tax cut promises—some sort of a con trick, if you like. The simple fact was that he said, `I'm not going to give you your tax cuts, but I'm going to give you something much, much better: I'm going to put some money into superannuation so in 50 years time you can get the benefit of that tax cut you did not get.' I have to tell him, in political terms, that that will be very unconvincing. I think the Treasury estimate is that by the year 2002 some government has to find something like $4.5 billion for the government's contribution to this program, compared with something like a $1.8 billion tax cut. In fact, the government contribution could be in the order of $10 billion.

I find all of this very worrying, because the other point I always like to make in this particular debate is the fundamental issue of this super investment strategy. I have mentioned the aspect of how they so frequently invest in very large enterprises. They also invest substantially offshore. I read the other day that AMP, one of the better-known fund managers and longstanding vendor of superannuation in its various forms, had a dreadful time at home and, if it were not for its offshore investment in Pearl insurance in the United Kingdom, it would have had some very sad news for its policyholders in Australia.

In fact, now we find major funds taking 15 and 25 per cent of their funds offshore. This is one of my major complaints, with a small business background. When the employees of a small business employer put their savings into a bank, there was a fair chance that the small business employer could go and borrow some money at the bank and probably expand his or her operation and create more jobs and more savings.

But when all this money is forced to be diverted into superannuation funds—and as you start to take three per cent of the wages of people, as you propose in the next couple of years—they will see that money as the money they would have otherwise saved. They will refuse to save it, because they will say, `The government is looking after that.' The end result is that their employer will have a further narrowing of borrowing options through the bank and if he goes around to the superannuation fund he will be laughed out the door. They would say, `How many hundred million did you say you wanted?' when he wants $100,000. They are not geared to handle that sort of business as the banks are.

The government missed a great opportunity to allow people to open prescribed deposits instead of their own response to multiple funds for workers such as shearers and other seasonal and part-time workers. Some of this money needs to go into the banks. It is more tragic when you think that these small business people I am putting the case for are the ones who are forced to pay money into these accounts and, when they need it to expand their business, they cannot even go and borrow that money back—it is not available to them. It is just silly.

Furthermore, when you set out to generate investment within your country, the first thing you have to be able to do is have some flexibility. It is quite obvious that a good retirement income policy would give individual Australians a number of options—not just the one that Bill Kelty liked because he felt there was an opportunity to pick up some revenue for the trade union movement.

The family home, as the Singaporeans have recognised, is a component of a viable retirement situation and I think there should be, as part of a program, the opportunity for people for a period to claim tax deductions for investing in their home. I think they should be able to invest in the bricks and mortar component of their own small business. That is quite practical if you keep to those sorts of assets because the tax man can put a caveat on it to see that that money is preserved if there is a sale of the property. But all of these things are quite complex. The simple fact is that the government has not succeeded. (Time expired)
Debate (on motion by Mr Ronaldson) adjourned.

Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER (Mr Newell)—I advise the House that the Deputy Speaker has fixed 10.00 a.m. Wednesday, 30 August 1995 as the time for the next sitting of the Main Committee unless an alternative day or hour is fixed.
Motion (by Mr Elliott) proposed:
That the House do now adjourn.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Pyne Mr C.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —Tonight I wish to record the grief of Adelaide's Jewish community and my own distress over the desecration of Jewish graves in Adelaide last month. On Friday, 7 July, 62 graves in the Jewish section of the West Terrace Cemetery in the city were attacked. Some graves were so badly damaged that the names of the people that they commemorated were unreadable.

PARA.TAB: The Jewish section of the West Terrace Cemetery has a history as old as South Australia itself. The first Jewish settlers arrived in 1836, the year of Adelaide's foundation, and the first Jewish burial took place at West Terrace in 1843. Several prominent members of the South Australian Jewish community are buried at West Terrace. The grave of Sir Lewis Cohen, Lord Mayor of Adelaide from 1889 to 1901, was amongst those damaged. Other vandalised graves included those of a stillborn baby girl and a one-day-old boy.

The desecration of the graves was not an act of random vandalism. Instead, the evidence suggests that it was carried out by an organised group consisting of at least three teams of two people each. Somewhere in Adelaide there are well-organised anti-Semites prepared to carry out such a cowardly and contemptible act.

Adelaide has a small Jewish community, with around only 2,000 members. Some of its facilities, including a school and a synagogue, are located in my electorate of Sturt. Earlier this year I was shocked to receive a copy of answering machine messages to the synagogue. I hate to have to repeat it, but I will put it into the record. One went:

SPEECH.PARA: Now instead of Good Friday we should be celebrating Gas Friday. We take great pleasure in the fact that your ancestors sat in this chamber with their arms blowing up, with their legs shrivelling, with fat dripping from their bodies, with Adolf sitting in his chair saying, `Wa, wa, look at the Yid.'

And this is one of the milder messages. Also disturbing was a message from the National Action organisation in which they warned `that the Jewish community will become a political target of National Action'. I do not make any allegation that either the obscene message or the desecration of the graves was committed by National Action, who have denied involvement in both.

PARA.TAB: But, despite this, there is no doubt that someone is conducting a campaign of persecution and harassment against Adelaide's Jewish community. Jewish homes and businesses are being vandalised or daubed with swastikas and slogans. Members of the community who have publicly aired these problems have had rocks thrown through their windows. An elderly Holocaust survivor who told her tale on ABC television anonymously has been tracked down and subjected to threats and harassment. If these events occurred in Germany or in Poland they would be national crimes.

I am concerned that the Jewish community was not immediately notified by the police about the vandalism. The South Australian police appeared to have been unable to adequately deal with this problem and there are no leads in this case. The Adelaide attacks have not gone unnoticed in the international community. Israeli Prime Minister Yitzhak Rabin described them as an `ugly, dastardly deed which is the violation of every civilised law'.

A fortnight after the attack, over 1,000 people—including politicians, leaders from all faiths and members from ethnic groups as diverse as the Shi'ite Muslims and Ukrainians—attended a memorial service at West Terrace Cemetery. Premier Dean Brown spoke for all South Australians when he said, `I join with you at this time of mourning.'

Mr Norman Schueler, President of the Jewish Community Council of South Australia, told the meeting that South Australians must work together to prevent such mindless acts. He said, `We must not allow a detestable few to unravel the fabric of Australian society.' He also spoke of the tremendous support that the Jewish community has received.

Restoration of the graves began last week. The state, federal and local governments have contributed $15,000 each towards the graves' repair, and members of the public have offered their expertise or donated money. It is heartening to see how true Australians have reacted to this outrage. But it cannot undo the hurt and the sorrow that the Jewish community has suffered.

TALK.START.PARA: —In recent weeks I have sought to bring to the attention of the people of my electorate of Leichhardt, in Cairns in Far North Queensland, a little known Treasury publication called Do we have any of your money?. This book is a statement of unclaimed moneys. Under the Banking Act 1959, the contents of bank accounts that have not been used in seven years with balances over $500 are transferred in trust to Treasury.

PARA.TAB: In previous years, the names, addresses and amounts were published in the government Gazette, but this did not attract very much attention, so Treasury released a statement in a book format. Apart from my office making an effort to write to all people of Leichhardt in the book, the Cairns Post also cooperated by publishing a list of names, and it even tracked down the owners of some of the larger bank accounts.

The article sparked a huge amount of interest in Cairns. Behind each name in the book is a different story, covering the spectrum of life's experiences. My office had a phone call from a man who had opened up a bank account into which employers could deposit his wages. Several jobs later, he had forgotten the bank account. One couple had several phone calls from people who had seen their daughter's name in the newspaper list, long after she had moved interstate. Another woman's daughter had died and she was trying to locate her bank accounts.

The Cairns Post also found a woman, now living in a nursing home, who had unfortunately forgotten her bank account, and a man who had never known his deceased wife had been saving for a rainy day until the Cairns Post contacted him. It certainly was an interesting exercise. I simply thought it was a chance to let people know how they could claim their money and a chance to prod a few memories.

Unfortunately, this exercise stirred up some other problems. I was inundated with phone calls from people who had received letters from so-called money finders, who vaguely alluded to lost or bequeathed money and offered to retrieve this money for a fee of up to 15 or 20 per cent. What these organisations are doing is not illegal, but the information is freely available by buying the statement of unclaimed funds. But these letters are deliberately vague and certainly neglect to mention that people are able to claim the money themselves without paying any fee. They exploit those who think there is no other way to retrieve lost money.

The other problem is that many of the banks seem to have failed to write to any of these people before closing their accounts. I can understand the banks having problems tracing people, particularly if they have moved, but many of these people who have contacted my office have been living at the same address for the last 20 years and still have accounts with the same bank. I cannot think of any reason why the banks cannot check open bank accounts and send out a letter, at least, before transferring the contents to Treasury.

My advice in relation to the Banking Act is that there is no legal requirement for the banks to write to their customers, but the banks should have the common courtesy and sense of duty that would compel them to write to all customers before transferring the contents of their accounts that have not been used in seven years. We are not talking about trifling amounts. The largest amount listed in this year's statement was over $400,000.

I totally agree with the statements that were made by the Minister for Consumer Affairs (Ms McHugh), the Treasurer (Mr Willis) and the honourable member for Lilley (Mr Swan) on the adjournment last week about the excessive fees that banks are charging. But we should also look at the basic customer service. I cannot see why banks cannot perform the simple service of writing to people before transferring their bank accounts to Treasury. I hope to see this happening in the future.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Smyth Mr B.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I did not have the opportunity during last Tuesday's condolence debate to say a few words on behalf of me and the people of the electorate of Canberra in farewell to their self-adopted son, Fred Daly. I did not have the occasion to meet Fred personally but knew of him through his political life, his good works and his love of Canberra—in that, he was rare, for it is very rare indeed to find a federal politician who expresses a love for Canberra. The people of Canberra returned this feeling of goodwill by making Fred the King of Canberra, a duty in which he revelled.

PARA.TAB: He loved the political life of Canberra and this is highlighted through his `Fred Daly political discovery tour map' and, with Murrays, a local Canberra tour bus operator, he conducted a political bus tour—a very successful venture. Indeed, his contribution to ACT tourism was great. His good friend from ACT Tourism, David Marshall, asked that I pass on that Mr Daly's contribution to tourism and the image of Canberra was fantastic. In particular, he developed the political discovery tour map and the Murrays coach political tour. Both exercises provided tremendous insight into the intriguing world of politics in the nation's capital. He was a great contributor to the tourist infrastructure in the ACT and gave it a new dimension.

Fred was also patron to many organisations in the ACT. One particular organisation was 1RPH, the local radio station for the print handicapped, and all at the station were most grateful for Fred's interest and support over the years. At their annual general meeting on Friday night, speeches were made in honour of Fred Daly.

His love of politics was great, but his generosity was renowned. Deputy Chief Minister of the ACT, Tony De Domenico, remembered Fred's advice to him, `Son, when you get elected—clock on, go for the jugular politically, clock off, then buy the first beer.'

As many recounted last Tuesday, his love of Rugby League was well known, firstly for Newtown and then for the Canberra Raiders. I wish to record in the Hansard the comments of the chief executive of the Canberra Raiders, Kevin Neil, on behalf of the club. He said,

SPEECH.PARA: The late Fred Daly, who was patron of the Canberra Raiders since inception, will be greatly missed by our organisation.
Although Fred is no longer with us, he forever remains part of the Raiders' family spirit.

PARA.TAB: The people of Canberra will not forget Fred Daly. Indeed, Chief Minister of the ACT, Kate Carnell, has written to the local planning minister, Gary Humphries, to say that she has received numerous requests from individuals and organisations for a landmark in Canberra to be renamed, or newly named, in Fred's honour. She further said:

SPEECH.PARA: It is my strong view that the late Mr Daly be considered when names for local landmarks are considered.
On behalf of all his friends from the electorate of Canberra, thanks, Fred, and farewell.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Department of Human Services and Health

TALK.START.PARA: —On Wednesday, 16 August, seeking information from the Department of Human Services and Health on behalf of a church welfare agency—which was urgently awaiting its emergency relief grant—my staff and I had the distinct impression that we were being given the run-around. My staff were given information that there had been some delay in getting the July payments out but that the cheques were in the mail. There was a reluctance to discuss detail with my staffer, who said that he felt the information was being deliberately withheld.

PARA.TAB: On Thursday, 17 August, I rang the department myself and received a number of evasive answers. I pointed out that there was a press release already in the marketplace and that, therefore, it was public information. In fact, that morning a journalist had sent me a copy of the duty senator's press release, dated 15 August, which I understand was received in the newsroom at around 8.00 a.m. on 17 August, two days after the release was prepared.

I was told it would take some time to get the information together for my electorate, despite the fact that areas of my electorate had media releases, in the name of the duty senator, already being sent to them in quite comprehensive and detailed form. When I said, in exasperation, that I had welfare agencies that had approached me for information, I was asked, `Why didn't you refer them to me?'—`me' being a departmental officer concerned. In other words, the information had been in the marketplace—the duty senator had it, some media had it and the department would answer individual inquiries from potential recipients—but the elected representative had this important information concerning church and welfare agencies deliberately withheld.

When I asked the blunt question, `Was the officer under instruction not to provide coalition members with the information?', I received the reply `No, but there is an embargo.' `Embargo'—what is that, other than a deliberate withholding of information?

When I expressed my dismay, I was told that I should not be too upset and `I think yours'—that is, the embargo—`is lifted at lunchtime today; some are kept on for two weeks.' This is an admission from the department—` for two weeks'. Despite this, I still did not receive the information until after 4 p.m. that day—presumably by which time the electronic media would have lost interest in my response.

This is not the first time I have experienced this treatment. It has happened in relation to an aged care grant. On that occasion, the information was in the marketplace but I was told that I could get the data from the ALP duty senator. On that occasion his staff were cagey—obviously not sure whether the local media had used his release. Again, I objected and was told by the department, `That's the way it works.' When I asked how we might get around this I was told, `How you know the big dark secrets, I wouldn't know'—in other words, the surrender of professionalism to subservience and outright bias by the department.

In this current instance my protest is twofold. I object to the withholding of information on cheques—already some six weeks late—when three charity agencies were totally out of emergency funds and were dipping into other scarce resources to keep the organisation going. I object to organisations like the Salvation Army, Lifeline, women's crisis centres, Aboriginal housing cooperatives and teams of voluntary people being used in such a shabby and manipulative way just to suit the government's grubby political agenda, scoring cheap points and using, if not exacerbating, human misery to achieve it.

Further, it staggers me that officers of the Department of Human Services and Health have become so imbued with the party political processes of the government that they think it is the right thing to do to deliberately withhold legitimate information from elected members. No doubt some officers do this unwittingly, others unwillingly; nonetheless it happens. It shows that the infamous guideline in the department's October 1993 handbook—I refer you to the Senate estimates on this matter—that says, `Under no circumstance should advice letters to opposition MPs be prepared' is still alive and well under Minister Carmen Lawrence. In fact, it is worse—departmental officers are instructed or induced to withhold legitimate information already in the marketplace from elected members of parliament. Mr Deputy Speaker, this is nothing short of a perversion of the political process and I object to it.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is now eight months since the report into the Child Support Agency was released, in December 1994. In that time, many thousands of people throughout Australia have raised serious concerns about the Child Support Agency, but not much has changed. Most of us would know that the CSA is one of the most contentious and problematic government agencies, ruled by flawed legislation. I meet with a steady flow of constituents most weeks who believe that the Child Support Agency is a major problem in their lives. Most of all, constituents are angry about the federal government's tardy response to the inquiry into the CSA.

PARA.TAB: Many people held out hope that the inquiry into the CSA would change things. They believed the CSA would be sorted out, client service would improve, payments would be made on time and payment requirements would not be so harsh. Instead, they are seeing a too tardy response from the government.

The government tabled an interim response in March this year, four months after the original inquiry report was tabled. The government stated that the inquiry report had raised many `sensitive issues' which also had `budgetary implications' and that it needed to `seek expert advice, both legal and technical'. The government estimates that it will not have a final response to the CSA report until the first half of 1996, over a year from the tabling of the original report. In the meantime thousands of Child Support Agency clients have to wait for improvements.

There are at least five main issues of concern about the CSA which people bring to my attention. There is the fact that the child maintenance formula takes very little account of non-custodial parents beginning new lives, and that is becoming an issue of increasing concern.
