Another issue of concern is that child maintenance levels are too high and discourage non-custodial parents from working at all. Regularly, I have people in the office telling me that they are just going to disappear out of the system. The CSA cannot ensure that the payments are made on time. In one case, one of my constituents was owed $4,000 by her ex-partner. While she was earning $23,000, he was earning more than $50,000. By the time the CSA caught up with him, he had declared that he was only earning $8,000 and the CSA wrote off the debt.

The next concern is the fact that the CSA is located in the taxation department, has very little concern about anything the clients are going through and is merely focused on the dollars. The last concern I have here is the location of the CSA in metropolitan areas. People living in my electorate of Grey would appreciate the opportunity to discuss their cases face to face with CSA staff. But, instead, they queue on the telecentre answering line. If they are lucky, the waiting time may be only half an hour—half an hour too long. That is a system we know does need looking at in a number of other government departments.

In conclusion, from the point of view of most parents—custodial and non-custodial, male and female—the CSA is not delivering the service it was established to deliver. The CSA and the legislation it enforces are causing frustration, anger and hurt in the community. While they continue to do so, we must continue to remind the government that the job has not been finished. People want the CSA to change, they want the CSA to work and they want it to work fairly. They want the federal government to act now and not in another year's time.

TALK.START.PARA: —On a number of occasions in this House I have had cause to criticise the actions of state governments. I guess I do not really have a terribly high opinion of a lot of state governments around Australia. But tonight I am in the not so pleasant position of having to criticise a state Labor government—that being, of course, the New South Wales government—and its recent decision to abandon its promise to lift the tolls on the M4 and M5 motorways.

PARA.TAB: As members of this House will recall, it was the Fahey coalition government that introduced these unfair and inequitable tolls on the M4 and the M5, despite the fact that the federal government over time has provided plenty of funds to the New South Wales government to provide for first-class major highways. It was a fairly dishonest move at the time by the then conservative government to shift those funds into another part of Sydney to fix up another problem on the North Shore, while deciding that it, therefore, had to raise money through private means to fund what is a very good road—although a half-finished road—now called the M5. It made it a tollway, which means that the people of south-western Sydney—and, for that matter, western Sydney with the M4—have to pay for the privilege of driving to Sydney, whereas people on the North Shore these days do not. It was a disgraceful decision.

The Labor Party—not just before the state election, but for almost four years before—promised, quite rightly, to remove those tolls. Indeed, I can recall significant protests occurring when the tollgates were first put in near Moorebank on the M5. The former mayor of Liverpool, now the member for Werriwa (Mr Latham), was, quite rightly, at the forefront of those protests.

But what do we find now? The state Labor Party under Bob Carr won the state election by one seat on the basis of a number of things, including the unequivocal, fairly clear and fundamental promise to lift the tolls on the M4 and M5. Now we find that they have not done that, that they find it a bit difficult and that all sorts of excuses are being made, particularly by the minister responsible, Michael Knight, for why they cannot lift the toll. They say they are sorry. I do not think that is good enough. I think people are getting a bit tired of the cynicism of people elected on a specific promise. We have seen it before on the other side of politics, but now we are seeing it, unfortunately, on this side of politics.

As a federal member for a seat that is affected by this, I know that a lot of my constituents, Labor Party branch members and party voters—I mean genuine Labor Party branch members, not the people who have been stacked into the party and who have never voted Labor in their lives around my area—are very concerned about the fact that the state Labor government that they worked so hard to elect has gone back on this fairly fundamental promise.

I note from the Sydney Morning Herald this morning that Bob Carr is going out to the electorate of Badgerys Creek to open an electorate office for the local member there, Diane Beamer. I hope that on Wednesday, Bob Carr takes the opportunity to announce, following public pressure—there has been a lot of it—that he will lift the tolls. That was a fundamental promise. The tolls are an unfair burden on the working class families in western and south-western Sydney. I think it is appropriate that those tolls be lifted.

I issued a press release some six weeks ago about this matter. I was also on ABC radio talking about the need for this promise to be kept. I was attacked by the minister, Michael Knight, who accused me of being motivated by sour grapes because I lost federal preselection. What a pathetic response from a minister responsible for such an important thing!

Mr Knight should be aware that the preselection is over. One thing that is not over is the toll on the M5 and M4. Obviously, I would have preferred to have been the Labor Party candidate for the next election, but I still want the Labor Party to win seats in western and south-western Sydney. It is making it very difficult for this government, with all the talk about honesty in politics, when a state Labor government breaks a fundamental promise that affects people in their everyday lives.

I say to Mr Knight, Bob Carr and the whole state Labor government: think again. I hope the Olympic Games are not stuffed up the way this has been stuffed up. I urge the state government to respond, to look after its voters and to lift those tolls. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy Speaker, clearly, the Labor governments in New South Wales and Queensland have one thing in common, and that is that word `tollway'. It is creating political havoc in the state of Queensland for Premier Goss, as I indicated earlier in the day in this place.

PARA.TAB: This evening I want to talk very briefly about an aeroplane. It will come as no surprise to a number of my colleagues in this place that this is not the first, second or third occasion on which I have spoken about this particular aeroplane. I have lost count of the number of occasions on which I have.

I refer, of course, to the Australian designed and built Nomad aircraft, about 180 of which were built at the old Government Aircraft Factories, now Aerospace Technologies of Australia, over the last 20 years. A large proportion of those aircraft are still in service in Australia in military guise and on the civil register and are also overseas, in both military situations and on the civil register.

Firstly, I want to remind the House of a crash in March 1990 in which a young RAAF flight lieutenant was killed near Edinburgh. His widow and her parents, his brother and his brother-in-law have been in touch with me constantly since March of 1990, so we are looking at something that has gone on over five years, and for many that is too long.

The second point I want to mention is the continual sloping of shoulders—if that is the right terminology—of ministers. Ministers, in particular defence ministers, have continued to abrogate their responsibilities in relation to that aircraft. I hope that we will shortly come to the point where the present Minister for Defence (Senator Robert Ray) announces that those aircraft are to be retired from service in the Australian Defence Force. I will come back to that in a moment.

I also want to mention negligence. I refer to negligence on the part of the Australian Defence Force, and the air force in particular—which is being brought out in fairly large measure by the ongoing Senate Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade References Committee which is hearing at the moment about the circumstances of that fatal crash in 1990—and negligence on the part of Aerospace Technologies of Australia which, I understand, has given very poor evidence to that committee.

I also want to refer to the Ombudsman's 1994 report of that particular crash which was the result of a reference by the Minister for Defence on 25 November 1991. It took a long time to get to the Ombudsman; it took a long time for the Ombudsman to report on the matter. The issue continues to bounce around in terms of an incomplete response to the relatives. That leads me to another point, and that is the persistence of those relatives. I pay tribute to those relatives tonight.

Therefore, it comes as no surprise to find that the Defence Force grounded those aircraft in November last year. The previous Chief of the General Staff, prior to his retirement in July, recommended to the minister that they be retired from service. I only hope that Senator Ray will take up that advice—as he indicated he would several weeks ago—and announce that those aircraft, the so-called `widow makers', will be retired from the Australian Defence Force in the very near future. I also hope that Minister Brereton will take appropriate action corresponding to that taken by the Minister for Defence in terms of those Nomad aircraft on the civil register.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to talk about a group of young Australians who have won international and national acclaim because of their incredible talent, their hard work and their tenacity. Of course, I am talking about the kids involved with the Flying Fruit Fly Circus. They have been aptly described by Tony Wright of the Sydney Morning Herald, who has had a long-term interest in the circus since it first developed in Albury-Wodonga many years ago, as `ordinary kids doing extraordinary things'.

PARA.TAB: The Flying Fruit Fly Circus is doing an extraordinary thing at the moment: its supporters are circulating lizards to all federal members of both the House of Representatives and the Senate. The idea of the lizard is to draw to the attention of members of parliament from all sides the plight that the children in the circus find themselves in. That is because the federal government has, despite two or three years of intense effort by the circus, failed to resolve the funding problems of the circus. In fact, the government has subjected the circus to not one, not two, but now three separate inquiries as to the basis on which its funding should be developed for the future.

I understand that two major reports were done at Commonwealth request in the last three or four years, both of those reports recommending that the Commonwealth provide funds to enable both the circus and the training part to continue. Yet those reports appear to have been substantially ignored. When media attention began to focus earlier this year on the circus's plight, the government commissioned another study. I might say that the circus has no objection at all to another study. But the problem is when does this end and, in the meantime, the circus's reserves are being depleted.

Last year I think the circus performed to 300,000 people in Australia, which is more than the Australian Opera and the Australian Ballet together. Incidentally, while they got $7 million worth of taxpayers' money, these kids got $150,000 or thereabouts—I am a bit rusty on that figure but it is in that area. I do not think those children in the circus are being treated properly.

I hope that all members when they get their lizard take the trouble to ask the minister for the arts what on earth the government is doing, why can it not resolve the issue and why can it not be honest with these kids. If there is something that the government does not want to do—that is, if the government does not want to fund the circus because it does not have the aura of the opera or the ballet—then it should come out and tell the truth. In my view, the Commonwealth should fund them so that the Flying Fruit Fly Circus can continue to be the treasure of Australia's circus performing children and an organisation which continues to gain increasing international recognition and acclaim.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Human Services and Health, upon notice, on 28 March 1995:

PARA.TAB: Does the Commonwealth subsidise the use of interferon alfa for the treatment of hepatitis C; if so,(a) at what cost, (b) how long has interferon alfa been subsidised, (c) what was the cost of interferon alfa to patients (i) before and (ii) after the subsidy was implemented and (d) what steps will the Government take to further reduce the cost to patients of interferon alfa.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

PARA.TAB: (a) The Federal Government estimated that the cost of subsidy for interferon alfa-2b for use in the treatment of Hepatitis C would be approximately $5.6m in 1994/95.

(b) Interferon alfa-2b (Intron A) was listed as a highly specialised drug, and therefore subsidised, from 1 October 1994. An alternative product, interferon alfa-2a (Roferon-A) was listed for subsidy from 1 February 1995.
(c)(i) Before the introduction of the Federal Government subsidy patients were paying $570.00 for a month's supply of interferon alfa.

(ii) After subsidy commenced patients now pay charges similar to those on the PBS i.e. concessional beneficiaries pay $2.60 per prescription for a month's supply until they reach the safety net then their medication is free and general patients pay approximately $16.00 for each prescription for a month's supply until they also reach the safety net.

(d) The Federal Government is committed to monitoring and reviewing the usage of interferon alfa for the treatment of Hepatitis C. Access may be possible in the future for a larger patient population if the impending review recommends a broadening of the usage criteria. This will lessen the cost considerably for patients who may not currently qualify for subsidy. There are no plans to further reduce the cost to patients who currently receive subsidy under this program as the cost to these patients is consistent to those applying elsewhere in the Pharmaceutical Benefits Scheme.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Assistant Treasurer, upon notice, on 11 May 1995:

PARA.TAB: (1) Is it a fact that there is (a) significant concern within the Australian Taxation Office (ATO) about the effectiveness of the Tax File Number (TFN) system in Queensland and (b) a high incidence of abuse involving the TFN system in Queensland.

(2) Did a Queensland based ATO officer send a minute directly to Mr Michael Carmody, the Commissioner of Taxation, in January 1995 in which he detailed concerns about the operation of the TFN system in Queensland; if so, will he make the minute available to the House.
(3) What action is the ATO taking in respect of alleged abuses of the TFN system in Queensland.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

PARA.TAB: (1)(a) & (b) No. The Commissioner of Taxation advises that there are no concerns specific to Queensland, either in terms of the effectiveness of the TFN system or the incidence of abuse of the TFN system.

(2) The Commissioner advises that he has no record of the Minute apparently sent to him in January 1995. The ATO contacted Mr Aldred's Office on 6 June to request a copy of the above mentioned Minute in order to investigate the allegations. The request was refused.
(3) The ATO takes any allegation of abuse of its systems very seriously. Information regarding alleged abuses of the TFN system are investigated fully and prosecutions mounted where appropriate.

I am unable to provide a specific answer to this question without the benefit of the Minute referred to. If the honourable member will make this minute available, the ATO will investigate the matters raised.
The ATO recognises that the integrity of the TFN system is of paramount importance to efficient taxation administration and the effectiveness of the Data Matching Program.

The integrity of the TFN system is built on a rigorous regime of Proof of Identity checking prior to TFN registration and an exacting registration system utilising sophisticated search/matching software to ensure applicants are not already registered. TFNs quoted to employers on employment declarations and to investment bodies when opening accounts are validated.
The ATO also operates continuous data integrity assurance activity.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Investment Committee of the Officers' Superannuation Fund

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Treasurer upon notice, on 8 June 1995:

PARA.TAB: (1) Has the Reserve Bank of Australia implemented written guidelines for the participation of members of the Investment Committee of the Officers' Superannuation Fund (OSF) in the committee's asset allocation decisions; if so, what are the guidelines.
(2) How often does the Investment Committee (a) meet to make asset allocation decisions and (b) communicate with its investment consultant, Towers Perrin.
(3) What was the average duration of the fixed interest portfolios held by the (a) Reserve Bank on its own account and (b) OSF at the end of each quarter in (i) 1993-94 and (ii) 1994-95.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Willis The Hon R.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

PARA.TAB: (1) The Reserve Bank has written guidelines on staff behaviour, which apply to all staff, including members of the Investment Committee of the OSF. These require that staff should, inter alia, act in ways which avoid possible conflicts of interest. In keeping with this basic requirement, the OSF Investment Committee acts only on the basis of information which is available generally to the market, and avoids dealing in the market when there could be a conflict of interest. To further minimise the possibility of conflicts of interest, the management of cash and short-term securities (investments which, unlike the bond market are very sensitive to the Bank's domestic market operations) is not undertaken by the Investment Committee but is delegated to the staff of the OSF, who are quarantined fully from information bearing upon possible developments in monetary policy. The Investment Committee is not involved in

ANSWER.PARA: managing these investments, apart from setting broad guidelines for the control of credit risk.

PARA.TAB: The OSF does not invest in the shares of banks or other institutions which the Reserve Bank supervises.
(2)(a) The Investment Committee works within investment guidelines set by the Board of Trustees. It meets every second week to review the OSF's investments.

ANSWER.PARA: These meetings deal with a range of issues, including administrative matters relating to the OSF's holdings of property. Decisions to change asset allocation are made only infrequently; during 1994-95, for example, decisions to change the Fund's asset allocation were made on six occasions.

PARA.TAB: (b) Towers Perrin is not, and never has been, an investment adviser to the OSF. Towers Perrin is contracted by the OSF to undertake actuarial studies of the Fund.
(3)(a) and (b) The information requested is contained in the table below:

ANSWER.PARA: End of (years) face value) (years) face value)

PARA.TAB: The Reserve Bank holds a very large portfolio of bonds, including some of most issues of bonds. The average duration of its portfolio, therefore, tends to be close to the average duration of all bonds on issue, and is relatively steady. The main variations occur as a result of its purchases of near maturing bonds from the market, which temporarily lower the average duration. This was the case, for example, in the June quarter 1994.

The OSF, in contrast, holds only a small portfolio of bonds and the average duration tends to vary substantially in response to purchases and sales of individual bonds. No meaningful comparisons can, therefore, be drawn between the average duration of the portfolios of the Reserve Bank and the OSF.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Administrative Services, upon notice, on 26 June 1995:

PARA.TAB: (1) How many persons have been gaoled in Australia for not voting in each federal election held since I January 1983.
(2) Will he provide details of each person gaoled for not voting in the 1993 federal general election.
(3) How many cases involving not voting in the 1993 federal general election are pending in which a gaol sentence may result.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walker The Hon F.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

PARA.TAB: (1) The AEC administers the legislative provisions of the Commonwealth Electoral Act 1918 with respect to non-voting which may result in some electors being issued with a summons. It is then up to the individual Magistrate of a Court to either impose a penalty or not. The preliminary point that needs to be made is that there is no gaol sentence imposed by the law for failure to vote. However persons who are in contempt of a Court order can be gaoled for that contempt.
Wilful refusal to pay a fine imposed by the Court may also result in seizure of goods, loss of drivers licence, or community service as imposed by a Court Magistrate in accordance with State laws.

It has not been the policy of the AEC to maintain a record of all Court prosecutions and therefore information cannot be provided on the number of persons who have been gaoled in Australia for not voting since 1 January 1983. However, given the recent interest in this issue, the AEC has indicated that it will endeavour to put in place procedures whereby this information may be sought where possible.
(2) Recent investigations reveal that the number of gaol sentences imposed by the Courts were one in New South Wales, 11 in South Australia with an

ANSWER.PARA: additional nine people ordered to perform community service; 34 in Western Australia of which five people only served part of the time and opted to pay the amount due to the Court; and one in the Northern Territory with an additional person ordered to perform community service.

PARA.TAB: (3) Recent investigations also reveal that the number of outstanding warrants imposed by the Courts are 496 in New South Wales; 275 in Victoria; 241 in Queensland; 135 in South Australia; 109 in Western Australia; three in Tasmania and 18 in the Northern Territory.
It will be a matter for each Court to decide whether or not gaol sentences will be imposed in these cases.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Treasurer, upon notice, on 28 June 1995:

PARA.TAB: (1) Do former university students with Higher Education Contribution Scheme (HECS) debts pay off the debt in instalments through the PAYE tax system as PAYE tax is deducted.

(2) Does the Australian Taxation Office index the HECS debt of former university students on 1 June each year to reflect CPI movements; if so, (a) does the indexation apply to the previous end of financial year balance not taking into account regular PAYE instalments which have subsequently reduced the debt and (b) will the Government ensure that debts are not indexed on more than what is owed.
(3) How many HECS debtors were there at 1 June 1995.
(4) What average sum was owed by debtors.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

PARA.TAB: (1) Taxpayers with accumulated HECS debts whose salary or wages exceed a minimum amount ($508 per week in 1994/95) are required to have additional PAYE deducted to cover their anticipated compulsory HECS repayment. PAYE is not credited to individual HECS accounts until after the compulsory HECS repayment has been established.
(2) The Australian Taxation Office indexes HECS debts which are at least 12 months old on 1 June each year to reflect movements in CPI in accordance with the Higher Education Funding Act.
(2)(a) Yes. PAYE deducted for HECS is in anticipation of a compulsory HECS repayment and is not credited to a taxpayer's HECS account until the taxable income of the taxpayer has been determined.

(b) The Government is aware of concerns that have been raised regarding this matter. The issue is currently being examined, having regard to the policy, administrative and compliance implications of any change in this area.
(3) The number of HECS debtors at 1 June 1995 was 709 914.
(4) The average sum owed by HECS debtors is $4 463.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Human Services and Health, upon notice, on 29 June 1995:

PARA.TAB: (1) What factors are used to determine whether to establish new Competitive Employment Training and Placement (CETP) agencies.

(2) What is the (a) name, (b) address, (c) establishment cost, (d) capital funding level, (e) recurrent funding level, (f) target number of clients and (g) staff establishment of each CETP agency established since 1 January 1994.
(3) Have any CETP services closed; if so, why.
(4) Are CETP services required to prepare annual audited statements.
(5) Has her Department ever sought an independent audit of a CETP service.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Lawrence The Hon C.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

PARA.TAB: (1) The factors taken into account when deciding on whether to seek or recommend the establishment of a new CETP service include:
the approved funding priorities determined under section 5 of the Disability Services Act 1986;
the number of new places which can be funded;

the results of a needs based planning process which identifies regions within a State or Territory which are poorly serviced compared to others, and the overall demand for services by people in the target group;
the capacity of existing services in an area to respond to the demand from within their existing funding levels; and

the selection criteria established in the guidelines formulated under section 5 of the Disability Services Act, which provides the basis for deciding on competing tenders from both new and existing services.
(2) The table at Attachment A details the CETP agencies established since 1 January 1994. The following definitions were applied to ensure consistent reporting:
establishment costs are start up costs other than capital;
capital funding relates to cars, land and buildings etc;
recurrent funding figures are for the 1995-96 financial year;
target number of places as at time of approval, plus any subsequent variations; and
equivalent Full Time (EFT) Staff includes administration staff and may be approximate.

(3) No CETP service has closed since the introduction of the Disability Services Act in 1987, although fourteen services have been re-auspiced by mutual agreement between the Department and the organisations concerned. In each case, there was no disruption to the support being provided to clients.

(4) All organisations funded under the Disability Services Act 1986, including those providing CETP services, are required under the Terms and Conditions of Grant to provide annual financial statements which have been independently audited.
(5) See answer to (4)
